text: Foreword
label: BODY

text: The purpose of this manual is to provide guidance on the development and implementation of a
label: BODY

text: cross-connection control (CCC) program that will comply with the drinking water regulations,
label: BODY

text: Chapter 246-290-490 Washington Administrative Code.  This manual was prepared for Group A
label: BODY

text: public water systems with less than 1,000 connections.
label: BODY

text: Although the elements of a CCC program for small, medium, and large water systems are
label: BODY

text: essentially the same, a small water system program may often be streamlined to:
label: BODY

text: Suit the lower health risk posed by a predominantly residential customer base; and
label: BODY

text: Reduce the purveyor's program administration, and thus, operating costs.
label: BODY

text: This manual is divided into the following general areas:
label: BODY

text: Chapters 1 through 5 provide an overview of cross-connection control;
label: BODY

text: Chapter 6 outlines the decisions to be made when starting a CCC program;
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7 addresses day-to-day program operation;
label: BODY

text: Chapter 8 contains the CCC regulations and related reference materials; and
label: BODY

text: The appendices provide reference materials, including sample written program plans.
label: BODY

text: This manual may be viewed and downloaded from Washington State Department of Health Office
label: BODY

text: of Drinking Water website: http://www.doh.wa.gov/ehp/dw
label: BODY

text: For purveyors without Internet access, a CD of the manual is available upon request from the Office
label: BODY

text: of Drinking Water.
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: for permission to use the diagrams shown as Illustrations 1 and 2.

text: Chapter 1. Purpose
label: H4

text: The purpose of this guidance manual is to:
label: BODY

text: Explain the need for a cross-connection control (CCC) program;
label: BODY

text: Summarize Washington State Department of Health (DOH) regulatory requirements for
label: BODY

text: developing and implementing a CCC program;
label: BODY

text: Outline the options available for complying with CCC regulations; and
label: BODY

text: Provide information to assist purveyors with the day-to-day implementation of a CCC
label: BODY

text: program.
label: BODY

text: This manual is designed to provide guidance and resource information on cross-connection control
label: BODY

text: to DOH-certified cross-connection control specialists, CCC program managers, public water system
label: BODY

text: managers, water system governing bodies, public water system legal counsel, and Local
label: BODY

text: Administrative Authorities (building/plumbing officials).  The manual was developed for Group A
label: BODY

text: public water systems with less than 1,000 connections.
label: BODY

text: For small water systems that contract with a DOH-certified cross-connection control specialist
label: BODY

text: (CCS) for development of a program, this manual can be used as a resource to help ensure that the
label: BODY

text: contractor’s program includes all the elements discussed in Chapters 6 and 7.
label: BODY

text: Throughout this manual, the terms must, shall, and required are used to indicate a Washington State
label: BODY

text: regulatory requirement.  The terms should or recommend are used to indicate recommended
label: BODY

text: procedures, schedules, and/or criteria.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems

text: Chapter 2

label: BODY

text: Chapter 2. Introduction
label: H4

text: Overview of Cross-Connection Control
label: H4

text: A cross connection is defined as any actual or potential physical connection between a public water
label: BODY

text: system or the consumer's water system and any source of non-potable liquid, solid, or gas that could
label: BODY

text: contaminate the potable water supply by backflow.  Cross connections exist in all plumbing
label: BODY

text: systems. Cross connections may also exist in the purveyor’s water system facilities.
label: BODY

text: There are numerous well-documented cases where drinking water has been contaminated via
label: BODY

text: unprotected cross connections.  These cases have caused illness, injury, and in some cases, death, to
label: BODY

text: consumers served by the system.
label: BODY

text: The task of eliminating all cross connections is enormous.  However, all purveyors can implement
label: BODY

text: CCC programs that reasonably reduce the risk of contamination to their systems.  For a drinking
label: BODY

text: water (potable water) supply to become contaminated via a cross connection, three things need to
label: BODY

text: happen simultaneously:
label: BODY

text: 1. The potable water supply piping must be unprotected (or improperly protected) from a cross
label: BODY

text: connection;
label: BODY

text: 2. A physical cross connection must be made between the potable water supply piping and a
label: BODY

text: contaminant source; and
label: BODY

text: 3. Backflow conditions must occur.
label: BODY

text: Backflow is the flow of water (or other solid, liquid, or gas from any source) back into the potable
label: BODY

text: water supply.  Backflow may be due to either:
label: BODY

text: Backsiphonage; or
label: BODY

text: Backpressure.
label: BODY

text: Causes of Backflow:  Backsiphonage
label: BODY

text: Backsiphonage is backflow caused by a negative pressure (vacuum or partial vacuum) in the supply
label: BODY

text: piping.  Backsiphonage occurs when system pressure is reduced below atmospheric pressure.  The
label: BODY

text: effect is similar to sipping water through a straw.
label: BODY

text: The following scenario illustrates how backsiphonage backflow conditions could occur in a public
label: BODY

text: water system:
label: BODY

text: • A public water system main is shut off to repair a leak.  The water main is at the base of a
label: BODY

text: hill.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 2
label: BODY

text: Page 4
label: BODY

text: • The water main is at a lower elevation than the homes on the hill.  This creates a situation
label: BODY

text: where water in the plumbing in the homes on the hill can drain into the public water
label: BODY

text: system main.
label: BODY

text: • When a customer at the bottom of the hill uses water, a siphon is created at households at
label: BODY

text: the top of the hill and water drains out of their plumbing systems.
label: BODY

text: • At one household at the top of the hill, a garden hose is being used to fill a child's wading
label: BODY

text: pool.  The hose is submerged in the pool.  See Illustration 1.
label: BODY

text: • When the backflow conditions occur, the non-potable water from the wading pool is
label: BODY

text: siphoned through the cross connection (submerged hose) into the household plumbing
label: BODY

text: and then into the water main.
label: BODY

text: • The water from the wading pool contaminates the water main.
label: BODY

text: • When water service is restored, contaminated water is delivered to customers served by
label: BODY

text: the public water system.
label: BODY

text: See Illustration 1.
label: BODY

text: Illustration 1
label: BODY

text: Backsiphonage Backflow Hazard
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 2
label: BODY

text: Page 5
label: BODY

text: Causes of Backflow:  Backpressure
label: BODY

text: Backpressure is backflow caused by pressure in the customer's plumbing being greater than the
label: BODY

text: pressure in the water supply piping.  The higher pressure in the customer's plumbing may be from a
label: BODY

text: booster pump, heating boiler, etc.
label: BODY

text: The following scenario illustrates how backpressure backflow could occur in a water system:
label: BODY

text: 1. The fire department withdraws water from a hydrant.  This reduces the pressure in the
label: BODY

text: public water system main from 50 pounds per square inch (psi) to 20 psi.
label: BODY

text: 2. A customer served by the public water system installed a lawn irrigation system.  The
label: BODY

text: customer’s irrigation system is supplied with water from a pond.  The pump supplying the
label: BODY

text: irrigation system operates at 30 psi.  To ensure a supply for the irrigation system when the
label: BODY

text: pond is dry, the customer installed a standby connection to the household plumbing (potable
label: BODY

text: water piping).
label: BODY

text: 3. On the day of the fire flow situation, the normally closed valve between the household
label: BODY

text: plumbing and irrigation piping is accidentally left open.
label: BODY

text: 4. Backflow wouldn’t normally occur at this customer’s connection, because the pressure in
label: BODY

text: the public water system is greater than the pressure supplied by the irrigation pump.
label: BODY

text: However, during the fire flow situation, the pressure from the irrigation pump is greater than
label: BODY

text: the pressure in the water main.  Water from the pond is pumped into the household
label: BODY

text: plumbing, and then into the public water system main.  See Illustration 2.
label: BODY

text: 5. When the fire flow ends, pressure in the public water system water main increases, and
label: BODY

text: contaminated water is delivered to customers served by the system.
label: BODY

text: See Illustration 2.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 2
label: BODY

text: Page 6
label: BODY

text: Illustration 2
label: BODY

text: Backpressure Backflow Hazard
label: BODY

text: Methods of Backflow Prevention
label: BODY

text: Backflow can be prevented in two ways, either through installation of:
label: BODY

text: 1. An approved air gap (AG) that provides a physical separation between the contaminant and
label: BODY

text: the drinking water supply; or
label: BODY

text: 2. Mechanical devices or assemblies that prevent backflow from occurring.
label: BODY

text: Air gaps (AGs) are commonly used to prevent backflow in household plumbing systems.  Examples
label: BODY

text: of AGs can be found in typical household kitchens and bathrooms.  The physical separation
label: BODY

text: between the kitchen faucet and kitchen sink rim is an approved AG.  Similarly, the physical
label: BODY

text: separations between the bathroom faucets and rims of the sinks and bathtubs are approved AGs.
label: BODY

text: Current plumbing codes require all sinks and bathtubs sold in the United States to have “built in”
label: BODY

text: approved AGs (designed for above the rim faucets) to prevent contamination of the household
label: BODY

text: plumbing.
label: BODY

text: In addition to AGs, there are several methods of preventing backflow by mechanical means.
label: BODY

text: These range from simple single check valves to elaborate approved backflow prevention
label: BODY

text: assemblies.  All mechanical devices and assemblies will prevent backflow to some degree when
label: BODY

text: properly installed and maintained.  However, not all mechanical devices and assemblies are
label: BODY

text: created equal.  Thus, not all mechanical devices and assemblies provide equivalent backflow
label: BODY

text: protection.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 2
label: BODY

text: Page 7
label: BODY

text: In fact, backflow preventers can be differentiated by a number of characteristics:
label: BODY

text: 1. Backflow application conditions;
label: BODY

text: 2. Degree of hazard;
label: BODY

text: 3. Design;
label: BODY

text: 4. Approval requirements; and
label: BODY

text: 5. Use for premises isolation.
label: BODY

text: These characteristics are important to consider when deciding which type of backflow preventer
label: BODY

text: to use to protect the public water system from contamination.  The discussion below provides
label: BODY

text: further detail.
label: BODY

text: Regarding backflow application conditions, some devices and assemblies are designed to
label: BODY

text: prevent backsiphonage backflow only.  These are not effective in preventing backflow under
label: BODY

text: backpressure conditions.  Others are designed to prevent both backsiphonage and backpressure
label: BODY

text: backflow.  When selecting a backflow preventer to protect the public water system, the purveyor
label: BODY

text: must make sure that the preventer is suitable for the backflow application conditions likely to
label: BODY

text: occur for a particular connection (or fixture).
label: BODY

text: Backflow preventers must also be commensurate with the degree of health hazard (high vs. low)
label: BODY

text: posed by the customer’s plumbing system (or fixture) to the public water system.  For example,
label: BODY

text: some backflow preventers (i.e., assemblies) are manufactured to a very high standard, and thus,
label: BODY

text: are more reliable in preventing backflow than devices manufactured to a lower standard.  The
label: BODY

text: more reliable assemblies must be used to prevent backflow in high hazard cross-connection
label: BODY

text: situations.
label: BODY

text: Regarding backflow preventer design, an important difference between various types of
label: BODY

text: backflow preventers is whether the design allows them to be tested and repaired while in-line.
label: BODY

text: The purpose of the testing is to determine whether they are properly functioning to prevent
label: BODY

text: backflow.  Preventers that are not testable are called devices, whereas assemblies are preventers
label: BODY

text: designed for in-line testing and repair.  Assemblies include isolating valves and test cocks.
label: BODY

text: Regarding approval status, in Washington, backflow preventers that protect public water systems
label: BODY

text: from contamination via cross connections must appear on the Backflow Prevention Assemblies
label: BODY

text: Approved for Installation in Washington published by DOH.  Yet, not all backflow preventers
label: BODY

text: appear on the approved list.  The list identifies only those assemblies that have successfully
label: BODY

text: completed rigorous laboratory and field tests conducted by the University of Southern California’s
label: BODY

text: Foundation for Cross-Connection Control and Hydraulic Research.  It is important for purveyors to
label: BODY

text: ensure that all assemblies relied upon to protect the public water system appear on the above named
label: BODY

text: list.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 2
label: BODY

text: Page 8
label: BODY

text: The last difference between the various types of backflow preventers is whether they can be used to
label: BODY

text: isolate the customer’s plumbing from the public water system distribution system.  This concept is
label: BODY

text: called premises isolation.  Premises isolation assemblies are usually located at the meter or property
label: BODY

text: line.  Some assemblies can be used for premises isolation, whereas others are used to prevent
label: BODY

text: backflow at fixtures only.  The concept of installing a backflow preventer at a particular fixture,
label: BODY

text: such as a boiler, is called fixture protection.  When selecting a backflow preventer for a specific
label: BODY

text: situation, it is important to consider whether the preventer is to be used for premises isolation or
label: BODY

text: fixture protection.  Note:  Washington Administrative Code (WAC) 246-290-490(4) mandates
label: BODY

text: premises isolation for high hazard premises.
label: BODY

text: The following list identifies mechanical backflow preventers available on the market and their
label: BODY

text: respective acronyms.  The list identifies non-testable devices first and then identifies testable
label: BODY

text: assemblies.
label: BODY

text: 1. Devices
label: BODY

text: a. Residential Meter Check / Single-Check Valve (CV)
label: BODY

text: b. Dual-Check Backflow Preventer (DCV)
label: BODY

text: c. Dual-Check with Atmospheric Vent (DCAV)
label: BODY

text: d. Hose Bibb Vacuum Breaker (HBVB)
label: BODY

text: e. Atmospheric Vacuum Breaker (AVB)
label: BODY

text: 2. Assemblies
label: BODY

text: a. Spill-Resistant Vacuum Breaker Assembly (SVBA)
label: BODY

text: b. Pressure Vacuum Breaker Assembly (PVBA)
label: BODY

text: c. Double-Check Valve Assembly (DCVA)
label: BODY

text: d. Double-Check Detector Assembly (DCDA)
label: BODY

text: e. Reduced-Pressure Backflow Assembly (RPBA)
label: BODY

text: f. Reduced-Pressure Detector Assembly (RPDA)
label: BODY

text: Note:  The term "detector" in the above assemblies list refers to a small water meter installed in a
label: BODY

text: by-pass arrangement for detection of water use.  These are most often used for fire sprinkler
label: BODY

text: installations.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 2
label: BODY

text: Page 9
label: BODY

text: For protection of a public water system from contamination, DOH recognizes as acceptable
label: BODY

text: methods of backflow prevention approved:
label: BODY

text: 1. Air gaps (AG);
label: BODY

text: 2. Reduced-pressure backflow assemblies (RPBA);
label: BODY

text: 3. Reduced-pressure detector assemblies (RPDA);
label: BODY

text: 4. Double-check valve assemblies (DCVA);
label: BODY

text: 5. Double-check detector assemblies (DCDA);
label: BODY

text: 6. Pressure vacuum breaker assemblies (PVBA);
label: BODY

text: 7. Spill-resistant vacuum breaker assemblies (SVBA); and
label: BODY

text: 8. Atmospheric vacuum breakers (AVB).
label: BODY

text: As mentioned previously, WAC 246-290-490 (4) requires premises isolation for high-hazard
label: BODY

text: premises.  These premises must be isolated from the public water system by an approved AG or
label: BODY

text: RPBA.  Other assemblies, such as DCVAs, may be used for premises isolation for lower hazard
label: BODY

text: situations.  Table 1 shows which backflow preventers are suitable for various combinations of
label: BODY

text: backflow application conditions and health hazards that purveyors may encounter.
label: BODY

text: For premises that are not considered high hazard, the purveyor may rely on assemblies and/or
label: BODY

text: devices installed within the customer’s plumbing system to protect the public water system.
label: BODY

text: Note:  The latter is allowed, because the backflow assemblies and/or devices installed within the
label: BODY

text: customer's plumbing system reduce the health risk to a level where an approved assembly is not
label: BODY

text: required at the meter to protect the public water system.  Devices may be used where an approved
label: BODY

text: assembly is not required.

text: Chapter 3. State and Federal Regulations and Jurisdictions
label: H4

text: Overview of Federal and State Drinking Water Regulations
label: H4

text: The Safe Drinking Water Act (SDWA) passed by Congress in 1974 authorized the development of
label: BODY

text: national regulations to ensure safe drinking water for consumers served by public water systems.
label: BODY

text: The 1974 Safe Drinking Water Act and subsequent amendments (through 2002) do not
label: BODY

text: specifically address the topic of cross-connection control.  However, the U.S. Environmental
label: BODY

text: Protection Agency is currently considering development of federal CCC rules.  Thus, federal CCC
label: BODY

text: rules may be promulgated sometime in the future.
label: BODY

text: Current federal drinking water rules do not
label: BODY

text: specifically require the purveyor to have a cross-
label: BODY

text: connection control program.
label: BODY

text: Confusion about cross-connection control has arisen, due to the belief by some purveyors that,
label: BODY

text: under the SDWA, the "purveyor is responsible for water quality to the last free-flowing tap."  This
label: BODY

text: confusion may have resulted from some federal rules that require purveyors to monitor certain water
label: BODY

text: quality parameters (i.e., lead and copper levels) in samples collected at the customer's tap.
label: BODY

text: However, under the SDWA, purveyors are only responsible for the water quality delivered to
label: BODY

text: customers at the meter.  The purveyor is not responsible for contaminants added to the water by
label: BODY

text: circumstances under the control of the customer (i.e., beyond the meter).
label: BODY

text: Under federal rules, the purveyor is only
label: BODY

text: responsible for the water quality delivered to the
label: BODY

text: customer’s meter.
label: BODY

text: Under the SDWA, the federal government may grant state governments "primacy" for the
label: BODY

text: administration and enforcement of the federal drinking water regulations.  States with primacy must
label: BODY

text: adopt drinking water regulations that are at least as stringent as the federal drinking water rules.
label: BODY

text: Washington is a primacy state.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 3
label: BODY

text: Page 12
label: BODY

text: Besides adopting the federal drinking water rules, primacy states may adopt additional (or more
label: BODY

text: stringent) drinking water regulations as long as they are not in conflict with the SDWA and/or
label: BODY

text: federal rules.  In Washington, CCC requirements are state-imposed.  Similarly, lower levels of
label: BODY

text: government (e.g., counties and cities) within the state, with the authority of the state, may impose
label: BODY

text: additional (or more stringent) regulations as long as they are not in conflict with the state
label: BODY

text: regulations.
label: BODY

text: Both federal and state governments regulate the public health aspects of drinking water “to protect
label: BODY

text: the health, safety, or welfare of the users of water.”  These regulatory entities “govern the
label: BODY

text: manufacturers and distributors of water” (e.g., water utilities, bottled water plants, etc.).
label: BODY

text: Regulations apply to the entity that owns (controls) the facilities for the manufacture and/or
label: BODY

text: distribution of water.  The higher level of government (the State) regulates government entities (e.g.,
label: BODY

text: a city or water district) that own water utilities.  Figure 1 illustrates the hierarchical relationship in
label: BODY

text: the regulatory authority of the federal and state levels of government with respect to public water
label: BODY

text: systems.
label: BODY

text: Figure 1
label: BODY

text: Regulation of Drinking Water
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: In Washington State, the laws (statutes) enacted by the legislature are published in the Revised
label: BODY

text: Code of Washington (RCW).  The RCWs establish general statutory authority.  Subordinate to the
label: BODY

text: RCWs, state agencies or boards, such as the State Board of Health adopt administrative rules
label: BODY

text: through the Washington Administrative Code (WAC).  The WACs provide details consistent with
label: BODY

text: the RCWs.  In addition to administrative rules, state agencies may issue guidance documents and/or
label: BODY

text: other reference materials on how to comply with the RCWs and WACs.  RCWs and WACs are
label: BODY

text: enforceable by the State, whereas guidelines are not enforceable.
label: BODY

text: Chapter 43 of the Revised Code of Washington assigns to DOH the responsibility to "Review and
label: BODY

text: approve plans for public water system design, engineering, operation maintenance, financing, and
label: BODY

text: emergency response, as required under State Board of Health rules."  The RCW defines a public
label: BODY

text: water system as “any system, excluding a system serving only one single-family residence and a
label: BODY

text: system with four or fewer connections all of which serve residences on the same farm, providing
label: BODY

text: piped water for human consumption, including any collection, treatment, storage, or distribution
label: BODY

text: facilities under control of the purveyor and used primarily in connection with the system."  This
label: BODY

text: definition is consistent with the federal SDWA definition of a public water system.
label: BODY

text: The definition of public water system goes to the heart of the regulatory authority of DOH and the
label: BODY

text: purveyors it regulates.  For most purveyors, control ends at the water meter to the customer's
label: BODY

text: premises.  The meter would be located within a public street right-of-way or within a utility
label: BODY

text: easement.  Public water systems where the owner controls (owns) the collection through distribution
label: BODY

text: facilities and the plumbing system would be considered exceptions.  These could include both non-
label: BODY

text: transient (e.g., schools) and transient (e.g., gambling casino) non-community systems as well as
label: BODY

text: some community systems.
label: BODY

text: WAC 246-290 (Group A Drinking Water
label: BODY

text: Regulations) applies only to the purveyor and not
label: BODY

text: to the purveyor’s customers.
label: BODY

text: Jurisdictions of Washington State Department of Health and Other
label: BODY

text: State Agencies Relating to Cross-Connection Control
label: BODY

text: The state legislature may assign the administration and enforcement of statutes and regulations to
label: BODY

text: different departments (agencies) within state government.  In Washington, several state departments
label: BODY

text: have responsibilities for the administration and/or enforcement of CCC-related regulations.
label: BODY

text: These agencies include, but are not necessarily limited to:
label: BODY

text: • Washington State Department of Health (DOH);
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 3
label: BODY

text: Page 14
label: BODY

text: • Washington State Building Code Council (SBBC);
label: BODY

text: • Washington State Department of Labor and Industries (L&I);
label: BODY

text: • Washington State Department of Agriculture; and
label: BODY

text: • Washington State Department of Ecology.
label: BODY

text: The following discussion provides basic information about the respective jurisdictions of DOH, the
label: BODY

text: SBCC, and L&I.  In addition to DOH, the SBCC and L&I have the most potential to impact
label: BODY

text: purveyors.  Figure 2 identifies these agencies and their respective cross-connection related program
label: BODY

text: responsibilities.

text: 3.2.1 Washington State Department of Health Regulates Cross-Connection
label: H4

text: Control for Public Water Systems
label: BODY

text: As mentioned above, DOH is one of several agencies with regulations pertaining to cross-
label: BODY

text: connection control.  DOH Office of Drinking Water administers and enforces drinking water
label: BODY

text: regulations for public water systems as set forth in Chapter 246-290 WAC.  The mission of the
label: BODY

text: Office of Drinking Water is to protect the health of the people of Washington State by ensuring safe
label: BODY

text: and reliable drinking water.
label: BODY

text: The requirement for public water systems to develop and implement CCC programs as set forth in
label: BODY

text: WAC 246-290-490 is consistent with the mission of the Office of Drinking Water.  Except for
label: BODY

text: certain types of public water systems where the consumption of water is solely within the property
label: BODY

text: owned by the purveyor, the jurisdiction of WAC 246-290-490 ends at the purveyor's water meter.
label: BODY

text: 3.2.2 Other State Agencies with Plumbing-Related Cross-Connection Control
label: HH3

text: Responsibilities
label: BODY

text: The primary regulation of plumbing and plumber certification falls under the jurisdiction of two
label: BODY

text: different agencies.  These agencies are the:
label: BODY

text: • Washington State Building Code Council (SBCC); and
label: BODY

text: • Washington State Department of Labor and Industries (L&I).
label: BODY

text: The SBCC adopts the Uniform Plumbing Code (UPC) with state amendments specific to
label: BODY

text: Washington (under RCW 19.27).  The UPC applies within the property lines of the customer's
label: BODY

text: premises.  Labor and Industries enforces plumber certification requirements (under RCW
label: BODY

text: 18.106).  The plumber certification requirements apply within buildings only.  Information on
label: BODY

text: the full text of these statutes is available through the following website:
label: BODY

text: http://www.access.wa.gov/
label: BODY

text: Further information about the respective jurisdictions of these agencies is provided below.
label: BODY

text: WAC 246-290 applies to the collection, treatment, storage
label: BODY

text: and distribution facilities under the purveyor’s control.
label: BODY

text: RCW 19.27 (Uniform Plumbing Code) applies within the
label: BODY

text: property lines of the customer’s premises.
label: BODY

text: RCW 18.106 (requirement for certified plumbers) applies
label: BODY

text: within buildings only.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 3
label: BODY

text: Page 16
label: BODY

text: Washington State Building Code Council
label: BODY

text: Washington State Building Code Council (SBCC) establishes the minimum requirements for the
label: BODY

text: design and installation of plumbing in Washington through adoption of the Uniform Plumbing Code
label: BODY

text: (often referred to as the UPC).  The UPC is applicable statewide.  As mentioned above, the UPC
label: BODY

text: applies within the property lines of the customer’s premises.  The UPC in effect in Washington
label: BODY

text: includes amendments specific to Washington.  These include a number of CCC amendments.
label: BODY

text: The various departments of state government are not supposed to adopt contradictory regulations,
label: BODY

text: including regulations on cross-connection control.  Thus, during the most recent major revision
label: BODY

text: process of the CCC regulations for Group A public water systems, DOH worked closely with the
label: BODY

text: SBCC to ensure greater consistency between WAC 246-290-490 and the UPC (as amended for
label: BODY

text: Washington).  To ensure this consistency, DOH has continued to work closely with the SBCC on
label: BODY

text: subsequent revisions to the UPC.
label: BODY

text: In fact, starting with the 1997 Uniform Plumbing Code, the SBCC has adopted a number of CCC
label: BODY

text: amendments to maintain or enhance consistency with WAC 246-290-490.  Information on
label: BODY

text: Washington State’s amendments to the UPC can be found on the SBCC website.  Their web address
label: BODY

text: is:  http://www.sbcc.wa.gov/
label: BODY

text: Although the SBCC is responsible for adoption of the UPC, Local Administrative Authorities (i.e.,
label: BODY

text: local building and/or plumbing officials) administer and enforce the UPC.  Customers (i.e., owners
label: BODY

text: of potable water plumbing) must comply with the UPC in effect at the time of installation, whether
label: BODY

text: or not the Local Administrative Authority inspects the plumbing.
label: BODY

text: Note:  RCW 19.27 does not provide authority for purveyors to regulate plumbing.  In fact, most
label: BODY

text: purveyors have no authority, and thus, no responsibility, beyond the meter for the customer's
label: BODY

text: compliance with the UPC.  The only exception to this would be systems where the purveyor owns
label: BODY

text: the water supply through distribution facilities and the plumbing.
label: BODY

text: Washington State Department of Labor and Industries
label: BODY

text: Washington State Department of Labor and Industries (L&I) requires persons engaged in the craft
label: BODY

text: of plumbing to be certified.  The craft of plumbing includes installing, repairing and replacing
label: BODY

text: plumbing and applies within buildings only.  Some plumbing activities require a journeyman’s
label: BODY

text: plumber certificate, whereas other plumbing activities, such as backflow assembly repair, require
label: BODY

text: only a specialty plumber certificate.
label: BODY

text: The plumber certification requirements may impact some DOH-certified Backflow Assembly
label: BODY

text: Testers (BATs) working in a purveyor’s service area.  WAC 246-290-490 and the UPC (WAC 51-
label: BODY

text: 0603.3) both require DOH-certified BATs to conduct backflow prevention assembly (BPA) testing.
label: BODY

text: RCW 18.106 requires certified journeyman plumbers to install backflow prevention assemblies
label: BODY

text: within buildings.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 3
label: BODY

text: Page 17
label: BODY

text: In 2001, RCW 18.106 was amended and a new specialty plumber certification for backflow
label: BODY

text: assembly maintenance and repair was created.  Effective January 1, 2003, BATs that repair
label: BODY

text: backflow prevention assemblies within buildings must hold a valid specialty plumber certificate
label: BODY

text: issued by L&I.  Further information on the plumbing certification laws and regulations can be
label: BODY

text: obtained by accessing the following website:
label: BODY

text: http://www.lni.wa.gov/scs/plumbing/
label: BODY

text: Summary
label: H4

text: In summary, a DOH-certified BAT must test any assembly that the purveyor relies upon to protect
label: BODY

text: the public water system.  However, only a journeyman plumber or a DOH-certified tester holding a
label: BODY

text: current specialty plumbing certification may repair the assembly if it is located within a building.
label: BODY

text: Purveyors may wish to recommend that any customer with one or more in-premises assemblies hire
label: BODY

text: a DOH-certified BAT that also holds a specialty plumbing certificate (in case the customer’s
label: BODY

text: assembly needs to be repaired).  Illustration 3 shows, for a typical community water system, the
label: BODY

text: respective jurisdictions of the water purveyor, Local Administrative Authority and L&I.
