text: History of Cross-Connection Control Regulations in Washington
label: BODY

text: Chapter 246-290 WAC is the primary document currently used by DOH to administer the RCWs
label: BODY

text: that address public water systems and the protection of drinking water.  Since 1970, public water
label: BODY

text: systems in Washington have been required to develop CCC programs to protect their systems from
label: BODY

text: contamination.  In fact, the 1978 cross-connection regulations (WAC 248-54-820) included
label: BODY

text: essentially all the program requirements of the current WAC 246-290-490.  Specifically, WAC 248-
label: BODY

text: 54-820 included the following statement:
label: BODY

text: "A continuing and aggressive program of cross-connection investigation, surveillance and
label: BODY

text: control shall be implemented according to good CCC practice such as Accepted Procedure
label: BODY

text: and Practice in Cross-Connection Control Manual - Pacific Northwest Section - American
label: BODY

text: Waterworks Association, Second Edition."
label: BODY

text: The current WAC 246-290-490 differs from previous regulations by:
label: BODY

text: Clarifying the jurisdiction of the water purveyor versus Local Administrative Authority
label: BODY

text: (e.g., local building and plumbing officials) with regards to cross-connection control;
label: BODY

text: Listing and providing details on the minimum elements of a CCC program, rather than
label: BODY

text: merely referencing the CCC manual published by the Pacific Northwest Section of the
label: BODY

text: American Water Works Association (PNWS-AWWA); and
label: BODY

text: Identifying specific categories of high hazard premises for which premises isolation is
label: BODY

text: mandated.
label: BODY

text: Details on the current CCC regulations are provided in Chapter 4.  A copy of WAC 246-290-490 is
label: BODY

text: provided in Chapter 8.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 4
label: BODY

text: Page 19
label: BODY

text: Chapter 4.  Cross-Connection Control Regulations for Public Water
label: H4

text: Systems in Washington State
label: BODY

text: This chapter contains detailed information about the CCC requirements set forth in WAC 246-290-
label: BODY

text: 490.  A copy of the WAC (including CCC-related definitions from WAC 246-290-010) is included
label: BODY

text: in Chapter 8.
label: BODY

text: Applicability
label: BODY

text: All Group A community and non-community public water systems must comply with the CCC
label: BODY

text: requirements of WAC 246-290-490.
label: BODY

text: Overview of Regulations
label: H4

text: WAC 246-290-490 requires purveyors to develop and implement CCC programs to protect their
label: BODY

text: systems from contamination via cross connections.  The specific purpose of a CCC program is to
label: BODY

text: protect public health by helping to ensure the quality of water delivered to customers.  This is
label: BODY

text: accomplished by protecting the collection, treatment, storage and distribution facilities under the
label: BODY

text: control of the purveyor from contamination via cross connections.
label: BODY

text: Regarding program development, WAC 246-290-490 requires purveyors to include a written
label: BODY

text: description of the CCC program in the purveyor’s Water System Plan (required in WAC 246-290-
label: BODY

text: 100) or Small Water System Management Program (required in WAC 246-290-105).  If you are
label: BODY

text: unsure whether your system must develop a Water System Plan or Small Water System
label: BODY

text: Management Program, consult WAC 246-290-100 and 246-290-105 respectively and/or your DOH
label: BODY

text: regional engineer.
label: BODY

text: In addition to the written program plan, the regulations specifically require purveyors to implement
label: BODY

text: their CCC programs.  This is because implementation is the key to protecting the health of
label: BODY

text: consumers served by the water system.  Implementation activities include, but are not limited to:
label: BODY

text: • Hazard surveys;
label: BODY

text: • Installation of backflow preventers to protect the public water system;
label: BODY

text: • Establishing a record-keeping system;
label: BODY

text: • Tracking assembly test reports; and
label: BODY

text: • Public education.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 4
label: BODY

text: Page 20
label: BODY

text: Note:  No public health protection is obtained when a system develops but fails to
label: BODY

text: implement its cross-connection control program!  The WAC gives purveyors the option to
label: BODY

text: implement their cross-connection programs, or any part, directly or by means of a contract with
label: BODY

text: another agency or party acceptable to DOH.
label: BODY

text: Regarding program development and implementation, the general CCC program requirements
label: BODY

text: established by WAC 246-290-490:
label: BODY

text: 1. Require purveyors to use good engineering and public health protection practices.
label: BODY

text: 2. Give purveyors the option to use as guidance the most recently published editions of the
label: BODY

text: following publications (in addition to DOH publications):
label: BODY

text: a. Manual of Cross-Connection Control, published by the University of Southern
label: BODY

text: California Foundation for Cross-Connection Control and Hydraulic Research; and
label: BODY

text: b. Cross-Connection Control Manual, Accepted Procedure and Practice, published by
label: BODY

text: the Pacific Northwest Section, American Water Works Association.
label: BODY

text: 3. Give purveyors the option to establish CCC program requirements that are more stringent
label: BODY

text: than the requirements specified in the WAC.
label: BODY

text: Under WAC 246-290-490, purveyors must ensure that cross connections between the distribution
label: BODY

text: system and a consumer's water system are eliminated or controlled.  In most cases, eliminating cross
label: BODY

text: connections is almost impossible.  Thus, control of cross connections is the more common approach
label: BODY

text: used to protect public water systems from contamination.  Under the WAC, control of cross
label: BODY

text: connections must be accomplished by the installation of approved backflow preventers
label: BODY

text: commensurate with the degree of hazard.
label: BODY

text: The WAC offers purveyors flexibility in CCC program implementation.  Under the WAC,
label: BODY

text: purveyors have the option to implement two different types of programs.  Purveyors must
label: BODY

text: implement either:
label: BODY

text: 1. Premises Isolation Program, where all backflow prevention assemblies that protect the
label: BODY

text: public water system are located at the customer’s meter to isolate the customer’s plumbing
label: BODY

text: system from the public water system distribution system; or
label: BODY

text: 2. Combination program, where premises isolation backflow preventers are installed for high
label: BODY

text: hazard facilities, and for other types of facilities, backflow preventers are installed for fixture
label: BODY

text: protection (or area isolation) within the customer’s premises.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 4
label: BODY

text: Page 21
label: BODY

text: Regardless of the type of program implemented, WAC 246-290-490 requires all purveyors to
label: BODY

text: comply with the mandatory premises isolation requirements for high hazard facilities of the type
label: BODY

text: listed on Table 9 of WAC 246-290-490.  Thus, purveyors that implement combination programs
label: BODY

text: must ensure that all high hazard facilities they serve are isolated from the public water system with
label: BODY

text: an approved backflow preventer commensurate with the degree of hazard (RPBA or AG).
label: BODY

text: Where mandatory isolation is not required under the WAC, purveyors may rely on in-premises
label: BODY

text: protection in lieu of premises isolation.  Purveyors implementing combination programs often
label: BODY

text: choose this option for non-high hazard premises with limited internal cross-connection hazards.
label: BODY

text: This option is usually less costly for the customer, since the assemblies used for fixture protection
label: BODY

text: are smaller than assemblies used for premises isolation.
label: BODY

text: In situations where the purveyor relies upon fixture protection to protect the public water system,
label: BODY

text: the WAC requires purveyors to ensure that the level of protection provided by the in-premises
label: BODY

text: assemblies is equivalent to the level of protection that would be provided by a premises isolation
label: BODY

text: assembly.  The WAC specifies a number of conditions that must be met to ensure the equivalent
label: BODY

text: protection.  In-premises backflow preventers relied upon by the purveyor to protect the public water
label: BODY

text: system must:
label: BODY

text: Be commensurate with the degree of hazard;
label: BODY

text: Appear on the list of assemblies approved by DOH; and
label: BODY

text: Be installed, inspected, tested, maintained, and repaired in accordance with the same
label: BODY

text: requirements that premises isolation backflow preventers must meet.
label: BODY

text: In addition to the above conditions, the WAC requires purveyors to keep the same type of records
label: BODY

text: on in-premises backflow preventers as for the premises isolation assemblies.  Last of all, where the
label: BODY

text: purveyor relies on in-premises preventers to protect the public water system, the purveyor must
label: BODY

text: have access to the consumer’s premises to conduct an initial hazard survey and periodic resurveys.
label: BODY

text: In summary, under WAC 246-290-490, purveyors are only required to maintain records on the
label: BODY

text: assemblies that are relied upon to protect the public water system from contamination.  Thus, for
label: BODY

text: connections with premises isolation assemblies, the purveyor must maintain records on the premises
label: BODY

text: isolation assembly only.  For connections without premises isolation, the purveyor must maintain
label: BODY

text: records on all in-premises assemblies that are relied upon to protect the public water system from
label: BODY

text: contamination.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 4
label: BODY

text: Page 22
label: BODY

text: To protect their systems from contamination, purveyors must take “corrective action” when they
label: BODY

text: become aware of unprotected cross connections and/or customers fail to comply with the
label: BODY

text: purveyor’s CCC requirements.  Specifically WAC 246-290-490 requires purveyors to take
label: BODY

text: appropriate corrective actions when:
label: BODY

text: 1. Cross connection exists and is not controlled commensurate with the degree of hazard;
label: BODY

text: and/or
label: BODY

text: 2. Customer fails to comply with the purveyor's requirements for installation, inspection,
label: BODY

text: testing, maintenance or repair of approved backflow preventers.
label: BODY

text: Under the WAC, purveyors have flexibility in what corrective action to take to protect their
label: BODY

text: systems from contamination.  Corrective actions may include, but are not limited to the
label: BODY

text: purveyor:
label: BODY

text: 1. Denying or discontinuing water service to the non-complying customer;
label: BODY

text: 2. Requiring the customer to install an approved backflow preventer commensurate with the
label: BODY

text: degree of hazard; or
label: BODY

text: 3. Installing an approved backflow preventer for premises isolation.
label: BODY

text: WAC 246-290-490 requires purveyors to coordinate with the Local Administrative Authority
label: BODY

text: (e.g., building or plumbing official) on CCC issues.  Similarly, the Uniform Plumbing Code
label: BODY

text: amended for Washington requires Local Administrative Authorities to coordinate with purveyors on
label: BODY

text: CCC issues.  Coordination can range from information sharing to implementation of joint programs.
label: BODY

text: Under WAC 246-290-490, purveyors must document the level of coordination with the Local
label: BODY

text: Administrative Authorities, including the delineation of CCC responsibilities, in the required written
label: BODY

text: CCC program plan described above.  Although recommended, written agreements with the Local
label: BODY

text: Administrative Authority are not required under WAC 246-290-490.  As part of the coordination
label: BODY

text: efforts, the cross-connection regulations require purveyors to notify the Local Administrative
label: BODY

text: Authority when denying or discontinuing water service to a customer.
label: BODY

text: Backflow results in the unintended return of used water, i.e., water that has left the control of the
label: BODY

text: purveyor, into the distribution system.  However, some customers may have heating and/or cooling
label: BODY

text: systems that are designed to intentionally return water to the purveyor’s distribution system.  The
label: BODY

text: WAC requires purveyors to prohibit the intentional return of used water to their distribution
label: BODY

text: systems.  This is because used water has left the control of the purveyor, is of unknown quality
label: BODY

text: (may contain contaminants) and may be at a significantly different temperature than the purveyor’s
label: BODY

text: water supply.  Customers with these types of heating or cooling systems must dispose of the water
label: BODY

text: in some other manner in lieu of returning it to the purveyor’s distribution system.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 4
label: BODY

text: Page 23
label: BODY

text: Minimum Elements
label: BODY

text: To be acceptable to DOH, the purveyor’s CCC program must include the minimum elements
label: BODY

text: specified in WAC 246-290-490(3).  There are 10 minimum program elements listed in the WAC.
label: BODY

text: The requirements for each of the minimum elements are provided below.  Guidance for
label: BODY

text: implementing each of the minimum elements is provided in Chapter 7 of this manual.
label: BODY

text: Element 1:  Establish Legal Authority
label: BODY

text: The purveyor must adopt a local ordinance, resolution, code, bylaw, or other written legal
label: BODY

text: instrument that:
label: BODY

text: 1. Establishes the purveyor's legal authority to implement a CCC program;
label: BODY

text: 2. Describes the operating policies and technical provisions of the purveyor's CCC program;
label: BODY

text: and
label: BODY

text: 3. Describes the corrective actions used to ensure that consumers comply with the purveyor's
label: BODY

text: CCC requirements.
label: BODY

text: Guidance for implementing each of these elements
label: BODY

text: is provided in Chapter 7.
label: BODY

text: Element 2:  Procedures/Schedules for Hazard Evaluations
label: BODY

text: The purveyor must develop and implement procedures and schedules for evaluating new and
label: BODY

text: existing service connections to assess the degree of hazard posed by the consumer's premises to the
label: BODY

text: purveyor's distribution system and notify the consumer within a reasonable time frame of the hazard
label: BODY

text: evaluation results.  At minimum, the program shall meet the following:
label: BODY

text: 1. For new connections made on or after the effective date of the DOH CCC regulations (i.e.,
label: BODY

text: April, 1999), procedures shall ensure that an initial evaluation is conducted before service is
label: BODY

text: provided;
label: BODY

text: 2. For existing connections made prior to the effective date of the DOH CCC regulations
label: BODY

text: (April, 1999), procedures shall ensure that an initial evaluation is conducted in accordance
label: BODY

text: with a schedule acceptable to DOH; and
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 4
label: BODY

text: Page 24
label: BODY

text: 3. For all service connections, once an initial evaluation has been conducted, procedures shall
label: BODY

text: ensure that periodic re-evaluations are conducted in accordance with a schedule acceptable
label: BODY

text: to DOH and whenever there is a change in the use of the premises.
label: BODY

text: Element 3:  Procedures/Schedules to Eliminate/Control Cross Connections
label: BODY

text: The purveyor must develop and implement procedures and schedules to ensure that:
label: BODY

text: 1. Cross connections are eliminated whenever possible;
label: BODY

text: 2. Cross connections are controlled by installation of approved backflow preventers
label: BODY

text: commensurate with the degree of hazard (when the cross connections can’t be eliminated);
label: BODY

text: and
label: BODY

text: 3. Approved backflow preventers are installed in accordance with the requirements of WAC
label: BODY

text: Element 4:  Provide Qualified Personnel
label: BODY

text: The purveyor must ensure that personnel, including at least one person certified as a CCS, are
label: BODY

text: provided to develop and implement the CCC program.
label: BODY

text: Element 5:  Procedures/Schedules for Backflow Preventer Inspection and Testing
label: BODY

text: The purveyor must develop and implement procedures to ensure that approved backflow preventers
label: BODY

text: are inspected and/or tested (as applicable) in accordance with WAC 246-290-490(7).
label: BODY

text: Element 6:  Assembly Testing Quality Assurance/Quality Control (QA/QC)
label: BODY

text: The purveyor must develop and implement a BPA testing quality assurance/quality control program
label: BODY

text: including, but not limited to, documentation of tester certification and test kit calibration, test report
label: BODY

text: contents, and time frames for submitting completed test reports.
label: BODY

text: Element 7:  Backflow Incident Response Plan
label: BODY

text: The purveyor must develop and implement (when appropriate) procedures for responding to
label: BODY

text: backflow incidents.
label: BODY

text: Element 8:  Public Education
label: BODY

text: Purveyors must include information on cross-connection control in their existing programs for
label: BODY

text: educating consumers about water system operations.  Such programs may include periodic bill
label: BODY

text: inserts, public service announcements, pamphlet distribution, notification of new consumers and
label: BODY

text: consumer confidence reports.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 4
label: BODY

text: Page 25
label: BODY

text: Element 9:  Establish/Maintain Cross-Connection Control Records
label: BODY

text: The purveyor must develop and maintain CCC records including, but not limited to, the following:
label: BODY

text: 1. A master list of service connections and/or consumer's premises where the purveyor
label: BODY

text: relies upon approved backflow preventers to protect the public water system from
label: BODY

text: contamination, the assessed hazard level of each connection, and the required backflow
label: BODY

text: preventer(s);
label: BODY

text: 2. Inventory information on:
label: BODY

text: Approved AGs installed in lieu of approved assemblies including exact AG location,
label: BODY

text: assessed degree of hazard, installation date, history of inspections, inspection results,
label: BODY

text: and person conducting inspections:
label: BODY

text: b. Approved backflow assemblies including exact assembly location, assembly
label: BODY

text: description (type, manufacturer, model, size, and serial number), assessed degree of
label: BODY

text: hazard, installation date, history of inspections, tests and repairs, test results, and
label: BODY

text: person performing tests; and
label: BODY

text: Approved AVBs used for irrigation system applications including location,
label: BODY

text: description (manufacturer, model, and size), installation date, history of
label: BODY

text: inspection(s), and person performing inspection(s).
label: BODY

text: 3. Cross-connection program annual summary reports and backflow incident reports
label: BODY

text: required under WAC 246-290-490(8).
label: BODY

text: Element 10:  Meet Additional Reclaimed Water Requirements
label: BODY

text: Purveyors who distribute and/or have facilities that receive reclaimed water within their water
label: BODY

text: service areas must meet any additional CCC requirements imposed by DOH under a permit issued
label: BODY

text: in accordance with Chapter 90.46 RCW.
label: BODY

text: Examples of written programs containing the
label: BODY

text: above elements are included in
label: BODY

text: Appendices A and B.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Page 26
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 5
label: BODY

text: Page 27
label: BODY

text: Chapter 5. Reasons for Cross-Connection Control Programs
label: H4

text: Health Aspects
label: BODY

text: The first and foremost reason for developing and implementing a CCC program is to protect the
label: BODY

text: health of consumers served by the public water system.  This is accomplished by preventing
label: BODY

text: contamination of the public water system via cross connections.
label: BODY

text: The purveyor of a public water system has the responsibility to deliver water to its consumers that
label: BODY

text: meets all health standards in the Safe Drinking Water Act and the Washington State Drinking Water
label: BODY

text: Regulations for Group A systems (Chapter 246-290 WAC).  The water should also be desirable
label: BODY

text: from an aesthetic standpoint to reduce the likelihood of consumers turning to an unapproved water
label: BODY

text: supply.
label: BODY

text: Both the drinking water regulations (Chapter 246-290 WAC) and the DOH Water System Design
label: BODY

text: Standards contain many requirements that help ensure a safe water supply for consumers served by
label: BODY

text: public water systems.  These requirements include:
label: BODY

text: Source protection requirements (watershed control, wellhead protection);
label: BODY

text: Treatment design and performance standards (filtration, chlorination);
label: BODY

text: Distribution system design and construction (covered reservoirs, pressure standards); and
label: BODY

text: Proper operations (certified personnel, water quality monitoring, cross-connection control).
label: BODY

text: The greatest health risk to consumers served by public water systems lies in the introduction of a
label: BODY

text: contaminant into the public water system.  By design, the water distribution system is an efficient
label: BODY

text: means of transporting drinking water to consumers served by the system.  However, the distribution
label: BODY

text: system can also become the conduit for the spread of a contaminant to a large population.
label: BODY

text: Once introduced into the distribution system, a contaminant can move as a “slug.”  This type of
label: BODY

text: situation may result in extremely high concentrations in the drinking water.  In other situations, the
label: BODY

text: contaminant may become diluted quickly.  If this occurs, lower concentrations of the contaminant
label: BODY

text: will be present in the drinking water.  Without extensive knowledge of flows in a distribution
label: BODY

text: system, such as those provided by a hydraulic modeling program, purveyors will have a difficult
label: BODY

text: time predicting what will happen once a contaminant enters the water distribution system.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 5
label: BODY

text: Page 28
label: BODY

text: There are three categories of contaminants of importance to purveyors from a CCC standpoint.
label: BODY

text: These are:
label: BODY

text: 1. Microbiological contaminants;
label: BODY

text: 2. Chemical contaminants; and
label: BODY

text: 3. Physical contaminants.
label: BODY

text: The following sections discuss the various types of contaminants of concern and their effects on the
label: BODY

text: health of consumers and other aspects of a water system.  Figure 3 illustrates the three hazard types
label: BODY

text: and provides examples of each.
label: BODY

text: Figure 3
label: BODY

text: Types Of Hazard
label: BODY

text: 5.1.1 Microbiological Contaminants
label: HH2

text: In cross-connection control, waterborne diseases are the primary public health concern (e.g.,
label: BODY

text: cholera, typhoid, giardiasis, and cryptosporidiosis).  Microbiological organisms that may cause
label: BODY

text: waterborne disease include:  bacteria, viruses, protozoa, and parasitic helminths (worms).
label: BODY

text: The risk of a waterborne disease transmitted through the public water supply is a major concern
label: BODY

text: because of the:
label: BODY

text: Large population that may be exposed to the disease in a short timeframe;
label: BODY

text: Inability to immediately detect contamination (in fact, the first indicator may be the outbreak
label: BODY

text: of disease); and
label: BODY

text: Physical
label: BODY

text: Compressed Air
label: BODY

text: Steam
label: BODY

text: Hot Water
label: BODY

text: Chemical
label: BODY

text: Pesticides
label: BODY

text: Organics
label: BODY

text: Inorganics
label: BODY

text: Microbiological
label: BODY

text: Giardia
label: BODY

text: Cryptosporidium
label: BODY

text: Potential
label: BODY

text: Hazard
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 5
label: BODY

text: Page 29
label: BODY

text: Difficulty in tracing the contaminant source (e.g., Giardia cysts may enter the distribution
label: BODY

text: system from a reservoir or through a cross connection with an auxiliary supply).
label: BODY

text: Contributing to the problem of assessing the relative risk to public health of a microbiological
label: BODY

text: contaminant is the issue of infectious dose.  The severity of the health effect experienced by an
label: BODY

text: individual consuming drinking water containing a disease-causing microorganism varies by the:
label: BODY

text: 1. Type of organism;
label: BODY

text: 2. Quantity ingested; and
label: BODY

text: 3. Strength of the person's immune system.
label: BODY

text: Individuals with underdeveloped or weakened immune systems, such as infants, the elderly, and
label: BODY

text: persons receiving treatment for cancer, are more vulnerable to waterborne diseases than persons
label: BODY

text: with fully functioning immune systems.
label: BODY

text: All microbiological contaminants in drinking water are not necessarily disease-causing organisms.
label: BODY

text: However, their presence in the public water distribution system may be an indirect concern to the
label: BODY

text: purveyor.  For example, any coliform bacteria detected through the purveyor's monitoring program
label: BODY

text: will require mitigation measures.  These measures include re-sampling and possible further action
label: BODY

text: such as flushing, disinfection and issuance of a boil water advisory.  In addition, some
label: BODY

text: microbiological contaminants may cause taste and odor problems or cause an increased chlorine
label: BODY

text: demand.
label: BODY

text: In assessing the problem of bacteria entering the distribution system, the following system-specific
label: BODY

text: issues should be considered (at a minimum):
label: BODY

text: 1. Source water quality.  The quality of the source water, if poor, may enhance bacterial
label: BODY

text: growth and re-growth in the distribution system.  For example, sources with high levels of
label: BODY

text: organics will provide a food source for bacteria that may enter the distribution system due to
label: BODY

text: a backflow incident.  Other quality concerns include water with high turbidity, sulfide
label: BODY

text: bacteria, iron and manganese, etc., that provide a biofilm (slime) or biomass (sediment) in
label: BODY

text: water mains to harbor bacteria.
label: BODY

text: 2. Condition of distribution system piping.  The condition of distribution system piping, if
label: BODY

text: poor, may aid bacterial growth and re-growth in the distribution system.  For example,
label: BODY

text: corrosive water may cause tuberculation formation on old, unlined cast iron and steel water
label: BODY

text: mains.  The tubercles provide a rough surface that shelters bacteria from chlorine.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 5
label: BODY

text: Page 30
label: BODY

text: 3. Status of disinfection.  Some purveyors use groundwater as a source of supply and do not
label: BODY

text: chlorinate.  The ability and willingness of the purveyor to carry a chlorine residual in the
label: BODY

text: distribution system directly impacts bacterial survival and growth within the distribution
label: BODY

text: system.  Purveyors that do not routinely chlorinate their systems should be prepared (have
label: BODY

text: the necessary means and a plan of action) to apply emergency disinfection to address
label: BODY

text: unexpected microbiological contamination.
label: BODY

text: Concerns about microbiological contamination may be somewhat different from system to system,
label: BODY

text: since each system is unique.
label: BODY

text: 5.1.2 Chemical Contaminants
label: H4

text: With chemical contaminants, the issue of toxic dose must be considered just like with
label: BODY

text: microbiological contaminants.  Every chemical will have some effect on the person being exposed.
label: BODY

text: The severity of the health effect experienced by an individual consuming drinking water containing
label: BODY

text: a chemical contaminant depends on the type of chemical, amount of chemical in the water and the
label: BODY

text: duration of exposure.  With chemical contaminants, the severity of health effects increases with
label: BODY

text: dose, i.e., the higher the dose, the more significant the health effects.  Similarly, longer exposures
label: BODY

text: result in more significant health effects.
label: BODY

text: Acute toxic conditions from chemical contaminants are of most concern in cross-connection
label: BODY

text: control.  Similar to microbiological contaminants, the health effect to an individual consuming a
label: BODY

text: toxic chemical varies by the:
label: BODY

text: 1. Type of chemical;
label: BODY

text: 2. Quantity ingested; and
label: BODY

text: 3. Immune system of the person exposed.
label: BODY

text: For most people, the ingestion of drinking water with a high copper level will likely cause nausea,
label: BODY

text: diarrhea, abdominal pain and/or headache.  However, in a small portion of the population, i.e., those
label: BODY

text: individuals with an allergy to copper, the health effects can be far worse (causing death).
label: BODY

text: Some chemicals may normally have low levels of toxicity to humans.  However, when these
label: BODY

text: chemicals are introduced into the water system via cross connections, they may react to form more
label: BODY

text: toxic chemicals.  This occurs when the chemicals introduced via backflow combine with the
label: BODY

text: chemicals intentionally added by the purveyor to treat the water supply.  Chemical contaminants
label: BODY

text: may also react with the piping material in the plumbing or distribution system to leach toxic metals
label: BODY

text: into the water.  Other chemicals, such as gasoline, may damage piping materials (e.g., permeation of
label: BODY

text: polyvinyl chloride (PVC) pipe) and lead to structural failure of the pipe.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 5
label: BODY

text: Page 31
label: BODY

text: Some chemical contaminants may adhere strongly to the distribution piping walls and/or plumbing.
label: BODY

text: Once a backflow incident has introduced chemicals with this characteristic into the water system, it
label: BODY

text: is extremely difficult and/or virtually impossible to completely clean/remove the contaminant from
label: BODY

text: the system.  There have been well-documented backflow incidents where the purveyor’s only viable
label: BODY

text: remedy was to replace the water main affected by the chemical contaminant.
label: BODY

text: Concerns about chemical contamination may be somewhat different from system to system, since
label: BODY

text: each system is unique.
label: BODY

text: 5.1.3 Physical Hazards
label: H4

text: In addition to microbiological and chemical contaminants, purveyors need to be aware that physical
label: BODY

text: contaminants can also be introduced into the water supply via cross connections.  Most physical
label: BODY

text: hazards are also chemical hazards.  Examples of "pure" physical hazards are compressed air, hot
label: BODY

text: water and steam.  Hot water and/or steam, when present in the potable water supply, may result in
label: BODY

text: the burning of the skin, eyes, etc., of consumers served by the water system.
label: BODY

text: Gas is another type of physical hazard.  The public health risks posed by a gas, such as propane, are
label: BODY

text: of an entirely different dimension and magnitude compared to the risks posed by hot water and/or
label: BODY

text: steam.  In addition to toxic effects, propane gas may cause an explosion.
label: BODY

text: Thus, when conducting hazard evaluations, purveyors need to be aware of potential physical
label: BODY

text: hazards as well as microbiological and chemical hazards.  Just like the other types of cross-
label: BODY

text: connection hazards, physical hazards may cause injuries and even death in consumers served by the
label: BODY

text: system.
label: BODY

text: Multiple Barrier Concept
label: BODY

text: Protection Afforded Through the Purveyor’s Programs
label: BODY

text: Public health protection of drinking water emphasizes prevention of contamination and disease.
label: BODY

text: This preventative approach is based on the multiple barrier concept to public health protection.
label: BODY

text: With this concept, purveyors create multiple barriers or “roadblocks” between disease- causing
label: BODY

text: organisms (and other contaminants) and public water system consumers.  With the multiple barrier
label: BODY

text: concept, the greater the number of barriers, the greater the public health protection afforded.  Most
label: BODY

text: programs implemented by purveyors, including CCC programs, are barriers in the multiple barrier
label: BODY

text: concept to public health protection.
label: BODY

text: The major barriers established for public water systems include:
label: BODY

text: Protecting Sources of Supply.  Source protection programs are designed to prevent
label: BODY

text: microbiological, chemical, and physical contaminants from entering the water supply.
label: BODY

text: Source protection is accomplished through implementation of watershed control (surface
label: BODY

text: water sources) and/or wellhead protection programs (wells).
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 5
label: BODY

text: Page 32
label: BODY

text: Providing Treatment.  Treatment processes, such as filtration and primary disinfection,
label: BODY

text: remove, reduce, and/or inactivate contaminants (naturally-occurring and human-related)
label: BODY

text: from the raw water.  Treatment is provided to comply with the maximum contaminant level
label: BODY

text: (MCL) and treatment technique requirements established by the drinking water regulations.
label: BODY

text: Secondary Disinfection.  Secondary disinfection is used to maintain a disinfectant residual
label: BODY

text: in the distribution system to control microbiological water quality (e.g., bacterial re-growth).
label: BODY

text: • Storage.  Storage reservoirs provide covered storage and prevent microbiological
label: BODY

text: contamination of the treated water through openings in the reservoir (e.g., screened vents,
label: BODY

text: hatch seals are provided).
label: BODY

text: Distribution System Design.  Purveyors comply with the design, installation and material
label: BODY

text: standards, and provide minimum operating pressures (e.g., greater than 20 psi during fire
label: BODY

text: flow conditions) to prevent contaminants from entering the distribution system.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control Programs.  These programs help protect the public water
label: BODY

text: system from becoming contaminated via cross connections.  Purveyors require premises
label: BODY

text: isolation with approved backflow preventers to prevent contaminants from entering the
label: BODY

text: system from high hazard premises.
label: BODY

text: Water Quality Monitoring.  Monitoring programs provide a means of surveillance of the
label: BODY

text: public water system to detect microbiological and/or chemical contaminants in the water
label: BODY

text: supply.
label: BODY

text: Operation by Qualified Personnel.  Purveyors provide DOH-certified treatment plant
label: BODY

text: operators, distribution system managers, and CCSs to ensure proper operation of the water
label: BODY

text: system (all facilities under control of the purveyor).
label: BODY

text: Emergency Planning.  Purveyors establish emergency procedures for correcting problems
label: BODY

text: detected in water quality monitoring, caused by natural disasters, or created by backflow
label: BODY

text: incidents.
label: BODY

text: Public Health Protection Afforded Through the Plumbing Code and Plumber Certification Law
label: BODY

text: On the customer's premises, the Uniform Plumbing Code establishes minimum plumbing design,
label: BODY

text: installation and operating requirements.  The purpose of the code is to protect the public health,
label: BODY

text: safety, and welfare of the occupants of buildings.  The major elements in the plumbing code are:
label: BODY

text: Supply.  Owners must ensure that there is an adequate supply of piped potable water for the
label: BODY

text: plumbing system.
label: BODY

text: Distribution.  Owners must install approved materials and follow design requirements to
label: BODY

text: ensure minimum pressure at fixtures.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 5
label: BODY

text: Page 33
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control.  Owners must provide approved backflow preventers at
label: BODY

text: fixtures to prevent contaminants from entering the plumbing system (and drinking water).
label: BODY

text: In addition to the plumbing code, in Washington, there are also laws and regulations that
label: BODY

text: require certified individuals to provide plumbing services within buildings.  According to the
label: BODY

text: plumber certification laws and regulations, plumbing is to be installed and repaired by certified
label: BODY

text: plumbers (with some exceptions).
label: BODY

text: The public health protection requirements established by federal and state officials are very
label: BODY

text: conservative.  They include a high safety factor for both system design (reliability) and for
label: BODY

text: acceptable levels of contaminants.  For example, regulation of chemical contaminants may be
label: BODY

text: based on a possible adverse health effect from the long-term (e.g., 30 years) daily consumption
label: BODY

text: of two liters of water containing a chemical at a level above the maximum contaminant level
label: BODY

text: (MCL).
label: BODY

text: Many of the federal Safe Drinking Water Act requirements address possible long-term health
label: BODY

text: effects of contaminants to consumers.  However, contamination of water distribution systems
label: BODY

text: through backflow often results in immediate adverse health effects (illness or death of one or
label: H4

text: more persons) and/or financial losses.  Although cross-connection control is only one of the
label: BODY

text: multiple barriers to protect water quality, it is one of the most important barriers to protect the health
label: BODY

text: of consumers served by a public water system.
label: BODY

text: Some governing bodies question the need for purveyors to develop and implement CCC programs.
label: BODY

text: Some council and board members feel that CCC programs are a waste of time and money.
label: BODY

text: However, cross-connection control programs are an integral barrier in the multiple barrier
label: BODY

text: concept to public health protection.  In fact, without a CCC program, the purveyor’s distribution
label: BODY

text: system may become the weak link in the multiple barrier approach to disease prevention.
label: BODY

text: It is illogical for purveyors to spend large amounts of money on capital improvements for source
label: BODY

text: water treatment plants, water quality monitoring programs, etc., if the distribution system is
label: BODY

text: vulnerable to contamination via cross connections.  Also, for overall risk and liability management,
label: BODY

text: the benefits of implementing CCC programs are more favorable for purveyors than incurring costs
label: BODY

text: for incident investigation, cleanup, and settlement of claims.
label: BODY

text: Without a cross-connection control program, the
label: BODY

text: purveyor’s distribution system may become the
label: BODY

text: weak link in the multiple barrier approach to
label: BODY

text: disease prevention.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 5
label: BODY

text: Page 34
label: BODY

text: Legal Aspects
label: BODY

text: Once contamination occurs, one or more persons may suffer a loss.  The history of backflow
label: BODY

text: incidents reveals that the loss can range from a minor financial loss (e.g., the cost of flushing a
label: BODY

text: plumbing system) to the death of one or more persons and a significant financial loss.
label: BODY

text: Whenever there is a backflow incident, one must assume that litigation will follow.  The
label: BODY

text: litigation may be based on a violation of regulations, a tort action, and/or a breach of contract.
label: BODY

text: The purveyor's cross-connection control program
label: BODY

text: must be designed to reasonably reduce the risk
label: BODY

text: of contamination of the public water system and
label: BODY

text: should be designed to reduce the purveyor's
label: BODY

text: exposure to legal liability.
label: BODY

text: In general, the purveyor's liability may flow from the following sources:
label: BODY

text: Having a statutory/regulatory obligation and failing to follow it (i.e., breach of the law);
label: BODY

text: Failing to develop a "reasonable" CCC program and/or failing to take follow-up
label: BODY

text: enforcement action, once the purveyor has specific knowledge of a hazard (i.e., negligence);
label: BODY

text: Supplying a customer with contaminated water that causes the customer to suffer a loss
label: BODY

text: (e.g., breach of contract/product liability);
label: BODY

text: Imposing unreasonable requirements on the customer (e.g., requiring an RPBA on all
label: BODY

text: services);
label: BODY

text: Extending a CCC program beyond the purveyor's jurisdiction (e.g., inspecting plumbing and
label: BODY

text: enforcing the Uniform Plumbing Code); and
label: BODY

text: Misrepresenting the actions of the purveyor (i.e., making an implied contract).
label: BODY

text: The purveyor’s liability may include:
label: BODY

text: 1. Fine or imprisonment for a breach of a statute; and/or
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 5
label: BODY

text: Page 35
label: BODY

text: 2. Payment of monetary damages, including:
label: BODY

text: a. Court costs;
label: BODY

text: b. Fees of opposing lawyer;
label: BODY

text: c. Compensatory damages; and
label: BODY

text: d. Punitive damages.
label: BODY

text: The following is an example of a statute pertaining to the purveyor's potential liability (criminal):
label: BODY

text: Section RCW 70.54.020 Furnishing Impure Water - Penalty
label: BODY

text: "Every owner, agent, manager, operator or other person having charge of any waterworks
label: BODY

text: furnishing water for public use, who shall knowingly permit any act or omit any duty or
label: BODY

text: precaution by reason whereof the purity of healthfulness of the water supplied shall become
label: BODY

text: impaired, shall be guilty of a gross misdemeanor." [1909 c 249 {291;RRS} 2543]
label: BODY

text: Other statutes pertain to the purveyor’s liability for payment of penalties for violation of laws or
label: BODY

text: rules regulating public water systems.  Under Section RCW 70.119A.030, DOH has statutory
label: BODY

text: authority to impose penalties for violations of laws or rules (regulating public water systems) that
label: BODY

text: are determined to be a public health emergency.  Under this RCW, purveyors may be penalized up
label: BODY

text: to $10,000 per day per violation.
label: BODY

text: In addition to the public health emergency penalty provision, Section RCW 70.119.040 grants DOH
label: BODY

text: general authority to impose penalties for violation of laws or rules regulating public water systems.
label: BODY

text: Purveyors may be penalized up to $5,000 per day per violation.  Purveyors should note that when
label: BODY

text: monetary damages are computed, every violation is considered a separate offense, and in the case of
label: BODY

text: continuing violations, every day’s continuance is a separate and distinct violation.
label: BODY

text: To reduce the exposure to liability, the purveyor should implement a CCC program that:
label: BODY

text: 1. Complies with regulatory requirements set forth in the drinking water regulations (WAC
label: BODY

text: 2. Follows the "standards" of the water industry for the application of backflow assemblies;
label: BODY

text: 3. Includes the installation of approved backflow prevention assemblies;
label: BODY

text: 4. Includes the installation of backflow assemblies and devices in accordance with industry
label: BODY

text: standards;
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 5
label: BODY

text: Page 36
label: BODY

text: 5. Includes the testing of backflow assemblies by a method and at a frequency stipulated in
label: BODY

text: regulations and recommended by industry standards;
label: BODY

text: 6. Includes the testing of backflow assemblies by certified testers (the certification establishes a
label: BODY

text: minimum level of training of the personnel testing assemblies); and
label: BODY

text: 7. Includes procedures for investigating backflow incidents and restoring water quality after an
label: BODY

text: incident occurs.
label: BODY

text: Recognizing that contamination will occur, the purveyor’s exposure to liability can be reduced by
label: BODY

text: transferring as much responsibility, and hence, the liability, to others.  This may be done by:
label: BODY

text: Requiring isolation of the customer's premises by an approved backflow assembly
label: BODY

text: commensurate with the degree of hazard, since the greatest exposure to liability for the
label: BODY

text: purveyor is in the transmission of a contaminant to its customers; and
label: BODY

text: Entering into a service contract (written agreement) with the customer to provide water
label: BODY

text: service (the agreement spells out the obligations of the purveyor and customer).
label: BODY

text: A written "service contract" provides the
label: BODY

text: purveyor with the best form of enforcement
label: BODY

text: authority, because the customer agrees to the
label: BODY

text: standards imposed by the purveyor, and any
label: BODY

text: enforcement action by the purveyor may be based
label: BODY

text: on the customer's breach of contract.
label: BODY

text: In the absence of specific contract terms to limit liability, all parties involved in cross-connection
label: BODY

text: control will have some degree of implied responsibility.  Each party is assumed to exercise
label: BODY

text: "reasonable" conduct to prevent contamination of the drinking water.  If a case involving damages
label: BODY

text: from contamination came before the courts, assessing liability may be reduced to a question of
label: BODY

text: whether the defendant:
label: BODY

text: 1. Knew (or ought to have known) about the dangerous condition; and
label: BODY

text: 2. Took reasonable steps within his/her control to prevent contamination of the water system.
label: BODY

text: All purveyors have a contract with their customers.  Contracts can be in writing (service
label: BODY

text: agreements) or implied (nothing in writing).  In either case, the purveyor agrees to provide safe,
label: BODY

text: reliable drinking water, and the customer agrees to pay for the water.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 5
label: BODY

text: Page 37
label: BODY

text: As stated previously, the purveyor's jurisdiction ends at the meter.  Thus, the purveyor does not
label: BODY

text: have a right to enter upon the customer's property, require a customer to install, test, or maintain a
label: BODY

text: BPA, etc., except through the terms and conditions established by the purveyor for providing water
label: BODY

text: services, i.e., in the service agreement.  If the agreement is not in writing and/or is not signed by the
label: BODY

text: customer, the purveyor and customer may disagree on the obligations of each party.
label: BODY

text: WAC 246-290-490 establishes the obligation of the purveyor to protect the public water system
label: BODY

text: from contamination via cross connections.  However the WAC does not directly or by implication,
label: BODY

text: establish an obligation of the purveyor's customer to protect the public water system.  For example,
label: BODY

text: where mandatory premises isolation is required under Table 9 of WAC 246-290-490, the purveyor
label: BODY

text: is obligated to have an assembly installed on the service.  The WAC does not address who must
label: BODY

text: install the assembly.  Thus, if the customer refuses to install the assembly, the purveyor must
label: BODY

text: install the assembly and may have to bear the cost associated with the installation.
label: BODY

text: Examples of standard written service contracts for new and existing customers are provided in
label: BODY

text: Appendix D.  The purveyor's attorney should be involved in establishing all forms of contracts.
label: BODY

text: It is less expensive for purveyors to pay attorney
label: BODY

text: fees for advice on how to avoid a lawsuit than to
label: BODY

text: pay fees to defend in a lawsuit.  The purveyor’s
label: BODY

text: attorney should develop or approve all customer
label: BODY

text: service agreements used by the purveyor.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Page 38
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Page 39
label: BODY

text: Chapter 6. Starting a Program
label: H4

text: Overview
label: H4

text: Since 1970, the drinking water regulations in Washington have included the requirement for
label: BODY

text: purveyors to develop a CCC program.  Yet, a 1994 DOH survey of water systems indicated that a
label: BODY

text: majority of small water systems had not started a program.   More recent data for 2001 indicates that
label: BODY

text: even some of the largest community systems in Washington:
label: BODY

text: Had no written CCC program plans;
label: BODY

text: Had written programs that did not contain all of the minimum elements required in WAC
label: BODY

text: Were not implementing their programs.
label: BODY

text: It should be noted that the minimum elements currently listed in the CCC regulations first became
label: BODY

text: effective in April 1999.  However, the basic elements of a cross-connection program, as outlined in
label: BODY

text: water industry reference manuals (e.g., Pacific Northwest Section – American Water Works
label: BODY

text: Association Cross-Connection Control Manual), have not changed significantly since the early
label: BODY

text: Currently, four basic types of programs can be found in Washington.  These are:
label: BODY

text: 1. Combination Programs
label: H4

text: These are CCC programs in which the purveyor relies upon both premises isolation
label: BODY

text: assemblies and in-premises assemblies to protect the distribution system.
label: BODY

text: The purveyor requires premises isolation for premises of the type on the DOH mandatory
label: BODY

text: list (Table 9 of WAC 246-290-490) and may choose to supplement Table 9 of WAC 246-
label: BODY

text: 290-490 by adding other selected customer categories.  For non-high hazard premises, the
label: BODY

text: purveyor relies upon backflow protection at selected points of use (high hazard fixtures)
label: BODY

text: within the customer’s premises.  With this type of program, the purveyor makes the risk
label: BODY

text: assessment.  Combination programs are the predominant type of program implemented by
label: BODY

text: large community water systems in Washington.
label: BODY

text: 2. Premises Isolation Programs
label: H4

text: These are CCC programs in which the purveyor relies solely upon premises isolation.
label: BODY

text: All assemblies protecting the distribution system are located at the meter (or at an
label: BODY

text: alternate location acceptable to the purveyor) to isolate the customer’s entire water
label: BODY

text: (plumbing) system from the purveyor’s distribution system.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 6
label: BODY

text: Page 40
label: BODY

text: For example, in this type of program, in addition to Table 9 of WAC 246-290-490
label: BODY

text: premises, all residential customers with special plumbing and all commercial customers
label: BODY

text: are “isolated” at the meter with a DCVA or RPBA.
label: BODY

text: 3. Joint Purveyor and Local Administrative Authority Programs
label: H4

text: These are programs that rely upon premises isolation for high-hazard premises (Table 9 of
label: BODY

text: WAC 246-290-490 list) and in-premises assemblies and devices at selected points of use for
label: BODY

text: other types of premises.  The risk assessment is made through a joint program between the
label: BODY

text: purveyor and Local Administrative Authority (local building/plumbing official).
label: BODY

text: This type of program is most often selected by municipal systems.
label: BODY

text: 4. Non-Community System Programs
label: H4

text: In these types of programs, protection from cross connections is afforded by compliance
label: BODY

text: with both the Uniform Plumbing Code and WAC 246-290.
label: BODY

text: This type of program is applicable where the purveyor owns the potable water system from
label: BODY

text: the source of supply to the last tap.  An example would be an elementary school supplied by
label: BODY

text: its own well, storage tanks, treatment system, etc.
label: BODY

text: Each type of cross-connection program identified above has significantly different costs, risks, and
label: BODY

text: liability implications to the purveyor.  The selection of the type of CCC program to implement is a
label: BODY

text: major policy decision for the purveyor.  Senior management, in consultation with the purveyor’s
label: BODY

text: attorney, should make the policy decision regarding program type.
label: BODY

text: Program Decisions
label: BODY

text: The following list identifies the fundamental policy decisions the purveyor needs to make regarding
label: BODY

text: the development and implementation of a CCC program.  Once made, the policies may be changed
label: BODY

text: in the future.  However, some policy changes are more difficult to make than others, once a program
label: BODY

text: has been initially implemented.
label: BODY

text: The major policy decisions are:
label: BODY

text: 1. Program Type (e.g., premises isolation only);
label: BODY

text: 2. Extent of Coordination (with Local Administrative Authority);
label: BODY

text: 3. Corrective Action;
label: BODY

text: 4. Service Agreements;
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 6
label: BODY

text: Page 41
label: BODY

text: 5. Location & Ownership of Premises Isolation Assemblies;
label: BODY

text: 6. Cross-Connection Specialist Options;
label: BODY

text: 7. Testing of Assembly Options; and
label: BODY

text: 8. Cost Recovery.
label: BODY

text: Each of these decisions will be discussed in detail below.  At the end of each section, a table is
label: BODY

text: provided for the purveyor to record the policy decision made.
label: BODY

text: 6.2.1 Types of Programs
label: H4

text: A CCC program may be based upon either:
label: BODY

text: Premises isolation protection only; or
label: BODY

text: A combination of premises isolation and in-premises protection.
label: BODY

text: Premises isolation means a method of protecting a public water system (i.e., the purveyor's system)
label: BODY

text: by installation of DOH-approved AGs or backflow prevention assemblies installed at or near the
label: BODY

text: service connection (or alternate location acceptable to the purveyor) to isolate the customer's water
label: BODY

text: system from the purveyor's distribution system.  For high hazard premises, premises isolation is
label: BODY

text: accomplished by installation of an approved AG or DOH-approved RPBA on the service.
label: BODY

text: For all CCC program types, mandatory premises isolation is required for high health hazard
label: BODY

text: premises (hospitals, medical clinics, etc.).  Table 9 of WAC 246-290-490 lists a number of
label: BODY

text: categories of premises where an AG or RPBA is required for premises isolation.  It should be noted
label: BODY

text: that the high-hazard premises table in the WAC is not all-inclusive, and other types of premises
label: BODY

text: considered to pose a high health hazard also require mandatory isolation with an AG or RPBA.
label: BODY

text: Examples of other high hazard premises would include:  airline manufacturing plants, paper mills,
label: BODY

text: and military bases.  Table 2 is a copy of the high-hazard premises list from the WAC.
label: BODY

text: If the customer's property use corresponds to the risk assessment for the category (e.g., medical
label: BODY

text: clinic), premises isolation is mandatory.  The only exception is where a customer's business
label: BODY

text: practices and activities don’t match the category, i.e., the business name or description is
label: BODY

text: misleading. For example, a “medical clinic” may only include psychologists.  The health hazard
label: BODY

text: posed by an office of psychologists is not the same as a typical medical clinic with physicians,
label: BODY

text: laboratories doing blood work, cultures, providing diagnostic services such as x-rays, etc.  In cases
label: BODY

text: where the customer’s business practices aren’t consistent with the hazards normally associated with
label: BODY

text: that category of business, the purveyor may grant an exception to mandatory premises isolation.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 6
label: BODY

text: Page 42
label: BODY

text: Table 2
label: BODY

text: High Health Hazard Premises
label: BODY

text: Requiring Isolation by AG or RPBA
label: BODY

text: Agricultural (farms and dairies)
label: BODY

text: Beverage bottling plants
label: BODY

text: Car washes
label: BODY

text: Chemical plants
label: BODY

text: Commercial laundries and dry cleaners
label: BODY

text: Premises where both reclaimed water and potable water are provided
label: BODY

text: Film processing facilities
label: BODY

text: Food processing plants
label: BODY

text: Hospitals, medical centers, nursing homes, veterinary, medical and dental clinics, and blood plasma
label: BODY

text: centers
label: BODY

text: Premises with separate (i.e., dedicated) irrigation systems that use the purveyor's water supply and
label: BODY

text: with chemical addition*
label: BODY

text: Laboratories
label: BODY

text: Metal plating industries
label: BODY

text: Mortuaries
label: BODY

text: Petroleum processing or storage plants
label: BODY

text: Piers and docks
label: BODY

text: Radioactive material processing plants or nuclear reactors +
label: BODY

text: Survey access denied or restricted
label: BODY

text: Wastewater lift stations and pumping stations
label: BODY

text: Wastewater treatment plants +
label: BODY

text: Premises with an unapproved auxiliary water supply interconnected with the potable water supply
label: BODY

text: *For example, parks, playgrounds, golf courses, cemeteries, estates, etc.
label: BODY

text: +RPBAs for connections serving these premises are acceptable only when used in combination with an in-plant
label: BODY

text: approved AG; otherwise, the purveyor shall require an approved AG at the service connection.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 6
label: BODY

text: Page 43
label: BODY

text: Under WAC 246-290-490, the purveyor has an obligation to protect the public water system from
label: BODY

text: contamination.  The purveyor's customers and the Local Administrative Authority (plumbing
label: BODY

text: inspector/ health inspector) have the obligation to prevent contamination of the potable water
label: BODY

text: system within the property lines of the customer’s premises.
label: BODY

text: When establishing a cross-connection control program, the purveyor must first determine
label: BODY

text: what level of overall risk and potential liability is acceptable.  Whenever the purveyor relies on
label: BODY

text: in-premises backflow preventers, the purveyor accepts increased risk and liability over premises
label: BODY

text: isolation due to:
label: BODY

text: The potential for the plumbing system to be changed by the customer without the purveyor’s
label: BODY

text: knowledge and/or approval of the Local Administrative Authority; and
label: BODY

text: The potential for the customer to fail to test, maintain, and repair the backflow preventers
label: BODY

text: the purveyor relies on to protect the public water system.
label: BODY

text: Purveyors should consider all customers served by the public water system to pose a health risk for
label: BODY

text: contamination of the water distribution system.  The health risk increases with the complexity of the
label: BODY

text: customer's plumbing system, uses of water (i.e., on-site activities, processes), etc.
label: BODY

text: No plumbing system should be considered free of cross connections.  However, for many plumbing
label: BODY

text: systems (e.g., residential homes), with the normal cross-connection protection afforded through
label: BODY

text: compliance with the Uniform Plumbing Code, the risk of contamination to the purveyor’s
label: BODY

text: distribution system is typically relatively low.
label: BODY

text: Premises Isolation Programs
label: BODY

text: For a premises isolation program, an assessment must be made of the degree of hazard posed by
label: BODY

text: the customer to the public water system.  Based on this assessment, if the degree of hazard is such
label: BODY

text: that the purveyor believes premises isolation is needed, an approved backflow prevention assembly
label: BODY

text: commensurate with the degree of hazard must be installed on the service connection.
label: BODY

text: A periodic re-evaluation of customers must be conducted to confirm that the premises isolation
label: BODY

text: decision initially made is still valid.  If not, the appropriate backflow assembly must be installed on
label: BODY

text: the service.  This could be an installation where no assembly was previously required or an upgrade
label: BODY

text: to an RPBA from a previously required DCVA (for a change in the customer's water use).
label: BODY

text: The minimum premises isolation program would consist of:
label: BODY

text: 1. Identifying all customers of the high health hazard type such as those categories listed in
label: BODY

text: Table 9 of WAC 246-290-490; and
label: BODY

text: 2. Ensuring the installation of the required RPBA or AG.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 6
label: BODY

text: Page 44
label: BODY

text: The minimum premises isolation program offers the purveyor the minimum level of public health
label: BODY

text: protection and liability management.  For this reason, a premises isolation program normally
label: BODY

text: includes an expanded list of categories requiring premises isolation.
label: BODY

text: An expanded list of premises isolation categories may be based upon a customer category system of
label: BODY

text: classification for assessing health risk.  For example, a DCVA may be required as the minimum
label: BODY

text: premises isolation for all shopping malls.  The purveyor's risk assessment then reduces to
label: BODY

text: determining if there are any categories of tenants (e.g., dental or medical clinic) in the shopping mall
label: BODY

text: that require the premises isolation requirement to be increased to an RPBA (e.g., the mall could
label: BODY

text: include a medical clinic).
label: BODY

text: When considering additions to Table 9 of WAC 246-290-490, purveyors need to be aware that the
label: BODY

text: expanded list does not need to be limited to shopping malls.  It could also include all commercial
label: BODY

text: customers.  Purveyors could define commercial customers as all customers other than single family
label: BODY

text: and duplex residential customers.  Under this approach, all tall buildings, apartments, etc., would be
label: BODY

text: included in a general risk category requiring at least a DCVA for premises isolation.
label: BODY

text: Combination Programs (Reliance on Premises Isolation and In-Premises Assemblies)
label: BODY

text: In a combination program, the purveyor may rely on in-premises backflow assemblies (at the
label: BODY

text: plumbing fixture) for all non high-hazard connections (i.e., where premises isolation is not
label: BODY

text: mandated).  The need to assess the degree of hazard posed by the customer on the distribution
label: BODY

text: system does not change.  However, the purveyor must determine what individual plumbing hazards
label: BODY

text: (fixtures) must be isolated with approved backflow assemblies to provide protection (equivalent to
label: BODY

text: premises isolation) for the distribution system.
label: BODY

text: Part of the in-premises risk assessment should include the potential for plumbing to be changed
label: BODY

text: without the purveyor's knowledge.  For example, strip malls with frequent changes in tenants pose
label: BODY

text: an increased risk to the public water system.  For example, a clothing retail store could be replaced
label: BODY

text: by a camera store with a photo lab without the purveyor's knowledge.  This would increase the risk
label: BODY

text: to the purveyor's system.  The purveyor would need to conduct relatively frequent re-surveys of the
label: BODY

text: mall to ensure that new cross connections are detected, or add the mall to the supplemental list of
label: BODY

text: customers requiring premises isolation.
label: BODY

text: Part of the overall hazard assessment should also include an assessment of the complexity of the
label: BODY

text: building’s plumbing.  As the complexity of the piping increases, the risk of not identifying a cross
label: BODY

text: connection increases.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 6
label: BODY

text: Page 45
label: BODY

text: Tall buildings or buildings built on a hill above the street (water main elevation) also increase the
label: BODY

text: risk of backflow into the purveyor's system from backpressure.  For example, a small drop in the
label: BODY

text: purveyor's system pressure may allow backflow to occur.  For these reasons, WAC 246-290-490
label: BODY

text: gives purveyors the authority to require premises isolation on premises that have characteristics
label: BODY

text: such as:
label: BODY

text: 1. Complex plumbing arrangements or plumbing potentially subject to frequent changes that
label: BODY

text: make it impractical to assess whether cross-connection hazards exist;
label: BODY

text: 2. A repeat history of cross connections being established or reestablished; or
label: BODY

text: 3. Cross-connection hazards that are unavoidable or not correctable, such as, but not limited to
label: BODY

text: tall buildings.
label: BODY

text: It should be noted that the in-premises protection provided by the customer in accordance with the
label: BODY

text: Uniform Plumbing Code may not be commensurate with the purveyor's assessed degree of hazard.
label: BODY

text: This is often the case with old buildings.  Once the customer complies with the Uniform Plumbing
label: BODY

text: Code in effect at the time of construction, the customer is “vested.”  The Local Administrative
label: BODY

text: Authority can’t require changes/upgrades (e.g., addition of an RPBA) to the existing plumbing
label: BODY

text: system, unless the building is significantly remodeled.  Thus, the Uniform Plumbing Code basically
label: BODY

text: “grandfathers” the plumbing systems of existing buildings, and their owners are essentially exempt
label: BODY

text: from requirements imposed by later versions of the Uniform Plumbing Code.
label: BODY

text: The purveyor can’t require the customer to make plumbing changes, since enforcement of the
label: BODY

text: Uniform Plumbing Code falls under the jurisdiction of the Local Administrative Authority.
label: BODY

text: However, the purveyor may offer the customer the option to voluntarily make a plumbing change
label: BODY

text: (e.g., install a backflow assembly at a fixture) in lieu of installing a larger, more expensive backflow
label: BODY

text: assembly on the service.  The advantages to the customer are:
label: BODY

text: Possibly lower cost of installation (two 3/4-inch assemblies within a building may cost less
label: BODY

text: than a one 1-inch assembly located outside the premises in a vault or above ground
label: BODY

text: enclosure); and
label: BODY

text: Greater health protection for the occupants of the building, since the assembly on the service
label: BODY

text: only protects the neighboring customers served by the public water system and not the
label: BODY

text: occupants of the building.
label: BODY

text: The disadvantage to the customer is that the cost of testing and maintaining multiple in-premises
label: BODY

text: assemblies may be greater than the cost associated with the single-premises isolation assembly.
label: BODY

text: Thus, the customer's long-term testing and maintenance costs for the in-premises backflow
label: BODY

text: assemblies may outweigh the initial savings in purchase price and installation costs.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 6
label: BODY

text: Page 46
label: BODY

text: WAC 246-290-490 requires the purveyor to protect the
label: BODY

text: distribution system from contamination via cross
label: BODY

text: connections.
label: BODY

text: If the customer doesn’t agree to install a premises isolation
label: BODY

text: assembly or equivalent in-premises protection at the
label: BODY

text: fixture, the purveyor must install a premises isolation
label: BODY

text: assembly on the customer’s service.
label: BODY

text: The above sections have discussed two major types of cross-connection programs that purveyors
label: BODY

text: can implement to comply with WAC 246-290-490.  Table 3 (below) summarizes the major
label: BODY

text: advantages and disadvantages of a premises isolation program vs. a combination program.
label: BODY

text: Table 3
label: BODY

text: Type of Program Options
label: BODY

text: Type of Program
label: BODY

text: Premises Isolation Only
label: BODY

text: Combination Program
label: BODY

text: Major Advantages
label: BODY

text: Lowers the purveyor’s costs and
label: BODY

text: workload by reducing the number of
label: BODY

text: assemblies to be monitored and the
label: BODY

text: time spent on re-surveys.
label: BODY

text: Reduces customer’s costs by
label: BODY

text: eliminating an additional, possibly
label: BODY

text: large, assembly on the service.
label: BODY

text: Major Disadvantages
label: BODY

text: Increases customer’s risk.
label: BODY

text: Increases pressure loss in customer’s
label: BODY

text: system.
label: BODY

text: Increases customer’s cost.
label: BODY

text: Increases the purveyor’s risk, due to
label: BODY

text: unreported plumbing changes and
label: BODY

text: undetected/unprotected cross
label: BODY

text: connections.
label: BODY

text: Increases purveyor’s workload and
label: BODY

text: cost for administration.
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: March 2004
