text: Chapter 6
label: BODY

text: Page 47
label: BODY

text: 6.2.2 Extent of Coordination
label: H4

text: WAC 246-290-490 requires purveyors to coordinate with the Local Administrative Authority on
label: BODY

text: CCC matters.  Similarly, the Uniform Plumbing Code (as amended for Washington) requires the
label: BODY

text: Local Administrative Authority to coordinate with the purveyor on CCC matters.  The level of
label: BODY

text: coordination with the Local Administrative Authority may vary.  Coordination options include:
label: BODY

text: A simple exchange of information (minimum effort);
label: BODY

text: Interacting (cooperating) with the Local Administrative Authority; or
label: BODY

text: Operating a combined (joint) purveyor/Local Authority program.
label: BODY

text: Each of these will be discussed in more detail below.
label: BODY

text: Exchange of Information Program
label: BODY

text: For an exchange of information level of coordination, the purveyor should:
label: BODY

text: 1. Notify the Local Administrative Authority (local building official/plumbing inspector) of the
label: BODY

text: purveyor's CCC program type (e.g., premises isolation) and policies;
label: BODY

text: 2. Request to be notified by the Local Administrative Authority of all permits for new
label: BODY

text: premises and for permits for plumbing changes to existing premises served by the public
label: BODY

text: water system; and
label: BODY

text: 3. Notify the Local Administrative Authority of any enforcement action in which water service
label: BODY

text: is discontinued and of any backflow incidents known by the purveyor to have contaminated
label: BODY

text: the public water system or the customer’s plumbing system.
label: BODY

text: Note:  Purveyors that initially select the information exchange option can always upgrade the level
label: BODY

text: of coordination to an interaction type of coordination in the future.
label: BODY

text: WAC 246-290-490 does not require purveyors to enter into
label: BODY

text: written agreements with Local Administrative Authorities.
label: BODY

text: However, written agreements are strongly recommended
label: BODY

text: for purveyors who decide to implement joint programs.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 6
label: BODY

text: Page 48
label: BODY

text: The level of coordination must be described in the purveyor's written CCC program plan.  A sample
label: BODY

text: program plan is provided in Appendix A.
label: BODY

text: Interaction Level of Coordination
label: BODY

text: For an interaction level of coordination (cooperation) with the Local Administrative Authority, the
label: BODY

text: purveyor may:
label: BODY

text: Conduct joint surveys/inspections of the customer's premises; and
label: BODY

text: Share assembly location and testing information.
label: BODY

text: An interaction level of coordination is only feasible where the Local Administrative Authority’s:
label: BODY

text: Staff is knowledgeable about/has expertise in cross-connection control; and
label: BODY

text: Staff resources are adequate to participate.
label: BODY

text: Combined/Joint Program Level of Coordination
label: BODY

text: Purveyors that wish to implement a combined/joint program with the Local Administrative
label: BODY

text: Authority should establish:
label: BODY

text: Which agency (purveyor vs. Local Administrative Authority) will be in overall charge (take
label: BODY

text: the lead) of the joint CCC program;
label: BODY

text: With the Local Administrative Authority, a written agreement that clearly delineates the
label: BODY

text: authority and responsibility of each agency with regards to cross-connection control; and
label: BODY

text: A list of the tasks to be performed by each agency (i.e., the purveyor and Local
label: BODY

text: Administrative Authority).  For example, the purveyor agrees to maintain the database of all
label: BODY

text: assemblies (i.e., premises isolation assemblies and fixture protection assemblies) and their
label: BODY

text: test results, etc.  The Local Administrative Authority conducts all plan reviews.
label: BODY

text: Combined (joint) programs work best in
label: BODY

text: situations where both the purveyor and Local
label: BODY

text: Administrative Authority fall under the same
label: BODY

text: governmental entity (i.e., city or town).
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 6
label: BODY

text: Page 49
label: BODY

text: In joint programs, it is common for purveyors to delegate responsibilities to the Local
label: BODY

text: Administrative Authority.  Similarly, in joint programs, purveyors often accept responsibilities from
label: BODY

text: the Local Administrative Authority.  In both cases, these responsibilities are often not within the
label: BODY

text: jurisdiction of the purveyor or the Local Administrative Authority respectively.  Special care should
label: BODY

text: be taken to consider the purveyor’s potential liability when the written agreement is drafted.
label: BODY

text: Table 4 shows the recommended extent of coordination based on system size and/or situation.
label: BODY

text: Table 4
label: BODY

text: Coordination with Local Administrative Authority Options
label: BODY

text: Extent of Coordination – Recommended Application
label: BODY

text: Information Exchange
label: BODY

text: Interaction
label: BODY

text: Combined (Joint) Programs
label: BODY

text: Most suitable for small water
label: BODY

text: systems.
label: BODY

text: Practical only where Local
label: BODY

text: Administrative Authority has
label: BODY

text: resources.
label: BODY

text: Normally recommended where
label: BODY

text: both the Purveyor and Local
label: BODY

text: Administrative Authority fall
label: BODY

text: under the jurisdiction of the
label: BODY

text: same governmental entity (i.e.,
label: BODY

text: city or town).
label: BODY

text: Written Agreements
label: BODY

text: Although not required in the WAC, purveyors wanting to implement joint programs are encouraged
label: BODY

text: to develop written agreements with their Local Administrative Authorities.
label: BODY

text: There are a number of topics that should be considered when the water purveyor and Local
label: BODY

text: Administrative Authority develop a written agreement to implement a joint program.  At a
label: BODY

text: minimum, the written agreement should:
label: BODY

text: 1. Define the purpose of the joint program;
label: BODY

text: 2. Identify the parties to the agreement;
label: BODY

text: 3. Define terms used in the agreement (e.g., health hazard);
label: BODY

text: 4. Cite the regulations that the combined program is based upon (e.g., WAC 246-290, UPC);
label: BODY

text: 5. Cite the authority (e.g., ordinance or council vote) to enter into a written agreement and
label: BODY

text: implement a combined program;
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 6
label: BODY

text: Page 50
label: BODY

text: 6. List the technical references used (e.g., PNWS-AWWA Manual, USC Manual, etc.);
label: BODY

text: 7. Describe the general policy regarding type of program to be implemented (e.g., premises
label: BODY

text: isolation per Table 9 of WAC 246-290-490 with in-premises backflow protection for all
label: BODY

text: other facilities);
label: BODY

text: 8. Delineate the respective responsibilities of the purveyor and Local Administrative
label: BODY

text: Authority;
label: BODY

text: 9. Identify the responsibilities that have been delegated to or by the purveyor and Local
label: BODY

text: Administrative Authority respectively;
label: BODY

text: 10. Describe administration procedures;
label: BODY

text: 11. Designate the entity/person ultimately responsible for overall program supervision (i.e., who
label: BODY

text: has the lead, the purveyor or the Local Administrative Authority);
label: BODY

text: 12. Provide detailed operating procedures for:
label: BODY

text: a. New construction plan review;
label: BODY

text: b. Authorization for connection of new service;
label: BODY

text: c. Conducting initial and periodic hazard assessments (surveys); and
label: BODY

text: d. Communicating with customers.
label: BODY

text: 13. Include procedures for responding to:
label: BODY

text: a. General water quality complaints;
label: BODY

text: b. Health-related complaints; and
label: BODY

text: c. Backflow incident investigations.
label: BODY

text: 14. Describe enforcement procedures for:
label: BODY

text: a. Addressing Uniform Plumbing Code violations; and
label: BODY

text: b.  Ensuring compliance with WAC 246-290-490.
label: BODY

text: 15. Identify certified backflow assembly tester (BAT) and CCS requirements;
label: BODY

text: 16. Include procedures for record-keeping and notifying customers for testing, etc.;
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 6
label: BODY

text: Page 51
label: BODY

text: 17. Include procedures for meeting all of DOH reporting requirements;
label: BODY

text: 18. Contain provisions for amending and/or canceling the written agreement; and
label: BODY

text: 19. Delineate responsibilities for various program costs, cost recovery and transfer of funds
label: BODY

text: between the purveyor and the Local Administrative Authority.
label: BODY

text: The requirements of a joint program must be
label: BODY

text: consistent with the cross-connection control
label: BODY

text: requirements of the individual purveyor and Local
label: BODY

text: Administrative Authorities.
label: BODY

text: The purveyor can use the following table to document the decision made regarding the extent of
label: BODY

text: coordination with the Local Administrative Authority.
label: BODY

text: Decision - Extent of Coordination (check one)
label: BODY

text: Information Exchange
label: BODY

text: Interaction
label: BODY

text: Combined/Joint Program
label: BODY

text: 6.2.3 Relationship to Customer
label: HH2

text: Another major policy decision for the purveyor is how to formalize the business relationship
label: BODY

text: between the purveyor and the customers.  This applies to more than the CCC program issues.
label: BODY

text: Whether the purveyor is a private individual, a homeowner’s association or a level of government
label: BODY

text: (e.g., water district), good business practices should be followed.
label: BODY

text: Service agreements are one tool that purveyors can use to formalize the business relationship with
label: BODY

text: their customers.  The purpose of a service agreement is to make clear to the customer the:
label: BODY

text: Legally binding conditions of service; and
label: BODY

text: Remedy afforded to the purveyor for the customer's breach of contract.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 6
label: BODY

text: Page 52
label: BODY

text: At a minimum, a service agreement should:
label: BODY

text: 1. Be in writing and signed by the customer or authorized agent of the customer;
label: BODY

text: 2. Be short, but explicit (in that the customer agrees to the service policy of the purveyor
label: BODY

text: including the CCC requirements);
label: BODY

text: 3. Clearly state the corrective action the purveyor will take, when the customer fails to comply
label: BODY

text: with the agreement; and
label: BODY

text: 4. Include by attachment the purveyor's written service policy and standards.
label: BODY

text: Every customer obtains water service by agreement.  The agreement may be verbal or written.
label: BODY

text: Initially the agreement (contract) may be in the form of the customer requesting to purchase a water
label: BODY

text: service connection, his payment of the connection fee, and the purveyor installing the service and
label: BODY

text: meter.  Thereafter, the agreement may continue in the form of the customer's payment of the water
label: BODY

text: bill.
label: BODY

text: At the time of customer's application for service, the purveyor had a policy (terms) for providing
label: BODY

text: service.  The terms may have been limited to the customer's payment of a monthly bill.  Any
label: BODY

text: detailed policy (contract conditions) may not have been communicated to the customer.  The policy
label: BODY

text: may not have expressly covered cross connections.
label: BODY

text: At the time of the application for service, or subsequently, the purveyor may:
label: BODY

text: Review the customer's plumbing plans and/or conduct a cross-connection survey to assess
label: BODY

text: the hazard posed to the purveyor's system;
label: BODY

text: Request, as a result of the hazard assessment from the plan review and/or survey, the
label: BODY

text: installation of premises isolation or in-premises backflow assemblies to protect the water
label: BODY

text: distribution system; or
label: BODY

text: Accept the protection afforded by existing backflow preventers.
label: BODY

text: If the purveyor chose not to conduct a plan review and/or hazard survey, by default, the purveyor
label: BODY

text: accepted the protection afforded by the existing backflow preventers (e.g., provided under the
label: BODY

text: Uniform Plumbing Code).
label: BODY

text: Historically, when requesting a customer to install backflow preventer, purveyors commonly:
label: BODY

text: Notified the customer in writing of the results of a CCC plan review and/or survey;
label: BODY

text: Specified the required backflow preventers; and
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 6
label: BODY

text: Page 53
label: BODY

text: Notified the customer of the requirement for testing upon installation and thereafter
label: BODY

text: annually, etc.
label: BODY

text: This written request to comply with the purveyor's conditions for service was accepted by the
label: BODY

text: customer through the act of installing the backflow preventers.
label: BODY

text: The purveyor then relied upon the customer's installation, testing, maintenance, and repair of the in-
label: BODY

text: premises or premises isolation approved backflow preventers and other in-premises backflow
label: BODY

text: devices to protect the public water system.  This agreement between the purveyor and customer was
label: BODY

text: reaffirmed each year with the request to the customer to have the approved assemblies tested by a
label: BODY

text: DOH-certified BAT.
label: BODY

text: The customer may not have been informed of the purveyor's service policy to:
label: BODY

text: 1. Discontinue water service, if the customer failed to comply with the requirement for testing,
label: BODY

text: maintenance, etc., (unless the customer is issued a second notice);
label: BODY

text: 2. Require the customer to install a backflow preventer for premises isolation on the service
label: BODY

text: pipe; or
label: BODY

text: 3. Install a backflow preventer for premises isolation on the customer’s service line, if the
label: BODY

text: customer failed to do so when requested by the purveyors.
label: BODY

text: If the above scenario is currently applicable to the system, it is recommended that the purveyor
label: BODY

text: request that existing customers sign a written service agreement.  If the purveyor chooses not to
label: BODY

text: pursue this independently, the first opportunity to require the customer to sign a service agreement
label: BODY

text: should be taken advantage of.  The opportunity may arise with:
label: BODY

text: 1. Request for a new or additional connection;
label: BODY

text: 2. Change in ownership of premises; and/or
label: BODY

text: 3. Change of water use on the premises (e.g., through building expansion, change from
label: BODY

text: residential to commercial customer category, etc.).
label: BODY

text: Unless the service agreement is recorded with the title to the property, the new owner of a building
label: BODY

text: is normally not aware of the terms of the service agreement with the purveyor.  The purveyor needs
label: BODY

text: to reaffirm this information with the "new customer.”
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 6
label: BODY

text: Page 54
label: BODY

text: For existing customers without service agreements, the purveyor may incorporate the written
label: BODY

text: service agreement into the notice to the customer to test assemblies or submit a hazard survey.  The
label: BODY

text: letter could include the following statements:
label: BODY

text: In the past, the purveyor requested the installation of one or more backflow assemblies
label: BODY

text: within the customer's premises to protect the water distribution system;
label: BODY

text: By the customer's compliance with the purveyor’s request, the purveyor agreed not to
label: BODY

text: require the installation of a backflow assembly on the service;
label: BODY

text: This benefits the customer by providing protection for both the customer's plumbing system
label: BODY

text: (and family) and the water distribution system;
label: BODY

text: To continue with this arrangement, the customer must have the assemblies tested by a DOH-
label: BODY

text: certified BAT and maintained, repaired, or replaced as needed to assure performance;
label: BODY

text: By completing and returning the attached assembly test report form, the customer agrees to
label: BODY

text: continue the agreement to provide in-premises protection (rather than have the purveyor
label: BODY

text: install an assembly on the customer’s water service and invoice the customer for the
label: BODY

text: installation cost, annual maintenance cost); and
label: BODY

text: The customer may chose to install an assembly on his service pipe in lieu of the in-premises
label: BODY

text: assemblies; however, such installation will not relieve the customer of his responsibility to
label: BODY

text: comply with the requirements of the Uniform Plumbing Code enforced by the Local
label: BODY

text: Administrative Authority.
label: BODY

text: The letter and accompanying assembly test form will likely document the initial agreement now
label: BODY

text: forgotten by the customer, lost by the purveyor, etc.  Sample written service agreements are
label: BODY

text: included in Appendix D.
label: BODY

text: All agreements should be prepared by or
label: BODY

text: approved as to form by the purveyor's attorney.
label: BODY

text: Table 5 summarizes the major advantages and disadvantages of having written service agreements.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 6
label: BODY

text: Page 55
label: BODY

text: Table 5
label: BODY

text: Relationship with Customers Options
label: BODY

text: Relationship with Customers
label: BODY

text: Service Agreements
label: BODY

text: Ordinance and Implied Contract
label: BODY

text: Major Advantages
label: BODY

text: Reduces purveyor’s exposure to
label: BODY

text: liability for enforcement of
label: BODY

text: corrective action.
label: BODY

text: Requires least administration by
label: BODY

text: purveyor.
label: BODY

text: Doesn’t raise any issues with
label: BODY

text: existing customers.
label: BODY

text: Major Disadvantages
label: BODY

text: Increases purveyor’s
label: BODY

text: administrative costs.
label: BODY

text: Increases purveyor’s exposure to
label: BODY

text: legal liability for enforcement
label: BODY

text: action.
label: BODY

text: Purveyors can use the following table to document whether their business relationship with
label: BODY

text: customers will be formalized through written service agreements.
label: BODY

text: Decision - Relationship with Customers
label: BODY

text: Written service agreement/contract signed by customer
label: BODY

text: Ordinance/resolution; implied service agreement with customer
label: BODY

text: 6.2.4 Enforcement of Corrective Actions [Element 1]
label: HH2

text: Per WAC 246-290-490 (3), when establishing authority to implement a CCC program, purveyors
label: BODY

text: must describe the corrective action used to ensure that consumers comply with the purveyor’s CCC
label: BODY

text: requirements.  For reliance on in-premises assemblies and/or premises isolation assemblies owned
label: BODY

text: by the customer, the purveyor must make provisions for corrective action to be taken if the
label: BODY

text: customer:
label: BODY

text: 1. Fails to test or maintain the assemblies; or
label: BODY

text: 2. Makes a change to the plumbing system that necessitates the installation of additional
label: BODY

text: assemblies and/or different types of assemblies.
label: BODY

text: Prior to April 1999, the cross-connection regulations included the following requirement:
label: BODY

text: "When an existing cross connection poses a potential health or system hazard, the purveyor
label: BODY

text: shall shut off water service to the premises, until the cross connection had been eliminated or
label: BODY

text: controlled by the installation of a proper backflow prevention assembly."
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 6
label: BODY

text: Page 56
label: BODY

text: The current WAC (effective April, 1999) states:
label: BODY

text: “The purveyor shall take appropriate corrective action within its authority if:
label: BODY

text: 1. A cross connection exists that is not controlled commensurate to the degree of hazard
label: BODY

text: assessed by the purveyor; or
label: BODY

text: 2. A consumer fails to comply with the purveyor's requirements regarding the
label: BODY

text: installation, inspection, testing, maintenance, or repair of an approved backflow
label: BODY

text: preventer required by this chapter.”
label: BODY

text: The current WAC continues with the following:
label: BODY

text: “The purveyor's corrective action may include, but is not limited to:
label: BODY

text: 1. Denying or discontinuing water service to a consumer's premises until the cross-
label: BODY

text: connection hazard is eliminated or controlled to the satisfaction of the purveyor;
label: BODY

text: 2. Requiring the consumer to install an approved backflow preventer for premises isolation
label: BODY

text: commensurate with the degree of hazard; or
label: BODY

text: 3. The purveyor installing an approved backflow preventer for premises isolation
label: BODY

text: commensurate with the degree of hazard."
label: BODY

text: WAC 246-290-490 states that a purveyor denying or
label: BODY

text: discontinuing water service to a customer's premises for
label: BODY

text: "corrective action" shall notify the Local Administrative
label: BODY

text: Authority (not Washington State Department Of
label: BODY

text: Health) prior to taking action, except in the event of an
label: BODY

text: emergency.
label: BODY

text: The failure of a customer to comply with purveyor's requirement for inspection, testing, etc., may
label: BODY

text: constitute a potential health hazard, but not an actual health hazard.  A backflow assembly that fails
label: BODY

text: the annual test may continue to stop backflow.  However, it may do so with less of a safety factor.
label: BODY

text: The purveyor has the right to discontinue water service to a customer to protect the water
label: BODY

text: distribution system.  However, the unreasonable exercise of this right may expose the purveyor to
label: BODY

text: liability.  The shut off of a water service may cause:
label: BODY

text: 1. A significant financial loss to the customer;
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 6
label: BODY

text: Page 57
label: BODY

text: 2. Backsiphonage conditions that may result in a backflow incident within the customer's
label: BODY

text: premises; and
label: BODY

text: 3. A public health hazard to employees and/or residents of the premises (e.g., apartment
label: BODY

text: building) from a backflow incident; the lack of water supply for domestic use, fire sprinkler
label: BODY

text: systems, kidney dialysis, etc; and the lack of operating sanitary facilities (e.g., toilets).
label: BODY

text: As a corrective action, if the purveyor shuts off water service to a customer, based on an assessment
label: BODY

text: of health risk, the purveyor has the burden of proof that the actions were reasonable.  There are
label: BODY

text: certain situations, i.e., public health emergencies, where the shut-off of water to a specific
label: BODY

text: connection is needed to protect the public water system from contamination.  Examples would
label: BODY

text: include unprotected cross connections to sewage and when a backflow incident is occurring or has
label: BODY

text: just occurred.
label: BODY

text: For situations other than the public health emergencies cited above, rather than face the
label: BODY

text: burden of proof, the purveyor may wish to take an alternate corrective action, i.e., installing a
label: BODY

text: backflow assembly on the service.  Alternatively, the purveyor may wish to establish with the
label: BODY

text: customer service agreements (contracts) that provide a legal protection for corrective action.
label: BODY

text: The purveyor's service policy should include
label: BODY

text: provisions for recovering all of the purveyor's costs
label: BODY

text: associated with the corrective action.
label: BODY

text: Table 6 summarizes the advantages and disadvantages of the two main corrective action options
label: BODY

text: available to purveyors.  Many purveyors include both types of corrective actions in their programs,
label: BODY

text: but limit the use of water shut-off to emergency type situations.
label: BODY

text: 6.2.5 Initial Assessment and Periodic Re-Assessment of Hazard [Element 2]
label: HH2

text: WAC 246-290-490 requires the purveyor to ensure that a CCS:
label: BODY

text: Assesses the degree of hazard posed by the consumer’s water system upon the purveyor’s
label: BODY

text: distribution system; and
label: BODY

text: Determines the appropriate method of backflow protection.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 6
label: BODY

text: Page 59
label: BODY

text: Thus, after the basic foundation of the program has been accomplished, the implementation of an
label: BODY

text: on-going CCC program starts with the assessment of the level of hazard posed by various
label: BODY

text: connections served by the system.  More than any other aspect of a CCC program, the training,
label: BODY

text: expertise and experience of a DOH-certified CCS is called upon to properly accomplish this task.
label: BODY

text: The initial assessment of a service connection or premises refers to either the:
label: BODY

text: 1. Assessment conducted prior to service being initiated for a new service connection; or
label: BODY

text: 2. First time an assessment is performed for an existing service connection.
label: BODY

text: After the initial assessment, the CCC regulations require periodic re-assessment of the service
label: BODY

text: connection to evaluate the appropriateness of the existing level of cross-connection protection.
label: BODY

text: To comply with these regulatory requirements, the following options are available to the purveyor:
label: BODY

text: 1. The purveyor's certified CCS (on staff or contractor) makes the initial assessment of degree
label: BODY

text: of hazard and periodic re-evaluations; or
label: BODY

text: 2. Each customer is required to hire a private CCS (contractor) to conduct the hazard survey
label: BODY

text: and submit a report to the purveyor.
label: BODY

text: Option 2 offers the major advantage to the purveyor of transferring the cost of the initial evaluation
label: BODY

text: and re-evaluation of commercial customers (and other customers with complex plumbing) from the
label: BODY

text: purveyor to the customer.
label: BODY

text: With Option 2, the purveyor's certified CCS should review the hazard evaluation report submitted
label: BODY

text: by the customer's CCS.  The purveyor's CCS review may be done as part of the periodic program
label: BODY

text: review (e.g., once per year), provided the system’s CCC Program Manager is given general review
label: BODY

text: guidelines on reviewing reports from customers.  Table 7 summarizes the advantages and
label: BODY

text: disadvantages of the two hazard assessment options.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: 6.2.6 Location and Ownership of Premises Isolation Assemblies [Element 3]
label: HH2

text: Element 3 of the cross-connection regulations requires the purveyor to develop and implement
label: BODY

text: procedures for ensuring that cross connections are controlled by the installation of approved
label: BODY

text: backflow preventers commensurate with the degree of hazard.  Regardless of the type of program
label: BODY

text: implemented (premises isolation vs. a combination program), the purveyor must decide on the
label: BODY

text: issues of ownership and installation location for all premises isolation backflow preventers.
label: BODY

text: The general options available to the purveyor are premises isolation backflow preventer owned by
label: BODY

text: the:
label: BODY

text: 1. Purveyor and installed with the meter on the public right-of-way (ROW) or in a utility
label: BODY

text: easement along side the public ROW; or
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Page 61
label: BODY

text: 2. Customer and installed on the service line on the customer's side of the property line
label: BODY

text: either:
label: BODY

text: a. Immediately downstream of the meter; or
label: BODY

text: b. Downstream of the meter, before the service line enters the building or in the
label: BODY

text: mechanical room where the service line just enters the building, with no connections
label: BODY

text: between the meter and the backflow preventer.
label: BODY

text: Illustrations 4-6 show three ownership/location combinations for premises isolation assemblies.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: of approved AGs or approved backflow
label: BODY

text: prevention assemblies at or near the service
label: BODY

text: connection (or alternate location acceptable to the
label: BODY

text: purveyor) to isolate the consumer's water system
label: BODY

text: from the purveyor's distribution system.”

label: BODY

text: Purveyors face an increased risk when they accept a customer-installed premises isolation
label: BODY

text: assembly at a location other than immediately downstream of the purveyor's meter (i.e., at the
label: BODY

text: property line).  The risk comes from the potential for connections to be made to the customer's
label: BODY

text: service pipe without the purveyor's knowledge.  A common "alternate location" is the mechanical
label: BODY

text: room of a building where the BPA is protected from freezing.  This may offer a major cost savings
label: BODY

text: for the customer over construction of an insulated, heated enclosure for a BPA immediately
label: BODY

text: downstream of the meter.  However, with this arrangement, the customer receives the benefit,
label: BODY

text: while the purveyor accepts the increased risk.
label: BODY

text: The major advantage to the purveyor's ownership of premises isolation assemblies is the increase in
label: BODY

text: the reliability of the assemblies that protect the public water system.  The increased reliability results
label: BODY

text: from the fact that the purveyor purchases, installs, tests, maintains, and repairs the assemblies.  The
label: BODY

text: major advantage to the purveyor of the customer owning the assembly is avoiding the responsibility
label: BODY

text: (and cost) for purchase, installation, maintenance, repairs, or replacement and the accompanying
label: BODY

text: potential liability for assembly failure.  These advantages and disadvantages are summarized in
label: BODY

text: Table 8.

text: 6.2.7 Cross-Connection Specialist Options [Element 4]
label: H4

text: WAC 246-290-490 (3) requires personnel, including at least one person certified as a cross-
label: BODY

text: connection specialist (CCS) to be provided to develop and implement the CCC program.  The
label: BODY

text: options available to comply with the CCS requirement are:
label: BODY

text: 1. Purveyor's staff member obtains CCS certification;
label: BODY

text: 2. Purveyor contracts with another water utility or agency (e.g., the Local Administrative
label: BODY

text: Authority, satellite management agency, etc.) to use the services of their CCS; or
label: BODY

text: 3. Purveyor contracts with an independent CCS to provide services.
label: BODY

text: RCW 70.119 governs DOH’s certification of CCSs and BATs.  The involvement of a CCS to
label: BODY

text: "develop and implement" a program varies with the type of program.  For example, in a premises
label: BODY

text: isolation program that follows a policy of requiring backflow assemblies only for customers
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: would be minimal.  Table 9 of this manual summarizes the advantages and disadvantages of the

text: 6.2.8 Assembly Testing Options [Element 5]
label: HH2

text: WAC 246-290-490(3) requires the purveyor to develop and implement procedures to ensure that
label: BODY

text: approved backflow preventers are inspected and/or tested.  Thus, regardless of the type of program
label: BODY

text: implemented (premises isolation vs. a combination program), the purveyor must establish a policy
label: BODY

text: for the testing of assemblies relied upon by the purveyor to protect the distribution system.  The
label: BODY

text: general options are:
label: BODY

text: 1. Purveyor's backflow assembly tester (BAT), on staff or a contractor, tests all assemblies; or
label: BODY

text: 2. Purveyor requires the customer to hire a BAT.
label: BODY

text: The purveyor shall ensure that a DOH-certified
label: BODY

text: BAT tests approved backflow prevention
label: BODY

text: assemblies (relied upon by the purveyor) for
label: BODY

text: proper operation. [WAC 246-290-490 (7)]
label: BODY

text: Having the purveyor's BAT (staff or contractor) perform the tests has the advantage of:
label: BODY

text: 1. Increased reliability (quality control over testing) and thus, decreased potential liability
label: BODY

text: (backflow incident);
label: BODY

text: 2. Less administrative cost for the purveyor (notification letters, quality assurance, etc.); and
label: BODY

text: 3. Good public relations, because the customer is not responsible for the task.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 6
label: BODY

text: Page 67
label: BODY

text: Testing by the purveyor's staff or contractor BAT has the disadvantages of the purveyor incurring:
label: BODY

text: 1. Possible liability for an assembly failure; and
label: BODY

text: 2. Increased costs for staff.
label: BODY

text: In programs where the purveyor requires the customer to hire a BAT, the purveyor should provide
label: BODY

text: the customer with a list of local contractor BATs (see Section 7 for details) that have met the
label: BODY

text: purveyor’s criteria to test.  Although not currently available, a public listing of certified BATs
label: BODY

text: should be available from DOH in the future.

text: 6.2.9 Cost Recovery
label: H4

text: The purveyor is required by WAC 246-290-490 to develop and implement a CCC program.  The
label: BODY

text: cost of the program should be identified in the purveyor's operating budget.  To reduce and/or
label: BODY

text: recover the cost of the CCC program, the purveyor may:
label: BODY

text: 1. Assess the general administrative cost of the cross-connection program to all customers, or
label: BODY

text: to one class of customers (e.g., all commercial customers) through use of:
label: BODY

text: a. Commodity or consumption charges (e.g., $/gallon);
label: BODY

text: b. Meter charges (e.g., $/month), based on the size of meter; or
label: BODY

text: c. A supplemental backflow assembly charge (e.g., $/month), based on the size of
label: BODY

text: assembly.
label: BODY

text: 2. Require each customer to directly bear the costs of the hazard surveys and costs associated
label: BODY

text: with the purchase, installation, testing, and maintenance of any backflow assemblies by
label: BODY

text: requiring each customer:
label: BODY

text: a. With a commercial account, to hire a CCS to conduct the initial and subsequent surveys
label: BODY

text: to assess the health hazard;
label: BODY

text: b. To purchase, install, maintain, repair, and/or replace any backflow assemblies required
label: BODY

text: as a result of the hazard survey; and
label: BODY

text: c. With backflow assemblies to hire a BAT for assembly testing.
label: BODY

text: Chapter 6

text: Page 72
label: BODY

text: Programs for Non-Community Systems
label: BODY

text: Per Chapter 246-290 WAC, there are two types of Group A non-community water systems.  These
label: BODY

text: are:
label: BODY

text: 1. Non-transient non-community systems; and
label: BODY

text: 2. Transient non-community systems.
label: BODY

text: The WAC defines these types of systems as follows:
label: BODY

text: 1. A non-transient non-community system (NTNC) is a public water system that provides
label: BODY

text: service opportunity to 25 or more of the same nonresidential people for one hundred
label: BODY

text: eighty or more days within a calendar year (e.g., school, motel with more than 25
label: BODY

text: employees on site); and
label: BODY

text: 2. A transient non-community system (TNC) is a public water system that serves:
label: BODY

text: a. 25 or more different people each day for sixty or more days within a calendar year;
label: BODY

text: b. 25 or more of the same people each day for sixty or more days, but less than one
label: BODY

text: hundred eighty days, within a calendar year; or
label: BODY

text: c. One thousand or more people for two or more consecutive days within a calendar
label: BODY

text: year (e.g., county fair).
label: BODY

text: A common characteristic of many non-community systems is that they occupy a single parcel of
label: BODY

text: land under one ownership.  As such, the public water system includes all facilities from the source
label: BODY

text: of supply to the tap.
label: BODY

text: For non-community systems, the jurisdictions of DOH and the Local Administrative Authority
label: BODY

text: overlap. Thus, the owner of a non-community system must comply with the requirements of both
label: BODY

text: jurisdictions.  In other words, non-community systems must comply with both the drinking water
label: BODY

text: regulations (Chapter 246-290 WAC) and the Uniform Plumbing Code.  Where there is a conflict
label: BODY

text: between requirements, the system owner must comply with the more stringent of the two
label: BODY

text: requirements, or comply with both requirements.
label: BODY

text: Non-community system purveyors that are developing CCC programs should apply the drinking
label: BODY

text: water system regulations to those facilities that are normally operated by a community water
label: BODY

text: system.  In other words, the drinking water regulations should be applied to the infrastructure from
label: BODY

text: the source of supply to the service connection to the building(s).  The primary focus of the drinking
label: BODY

text: water regulations is that the source of supply and the distribution facilities (transmission mains) are
label: BODY

text: not contaminated via unprotected cross connections.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 6
label: BODY

text: Page 73
label: BODY

text: Similarly, the Uniform Plumbing Code should be applied to the fixtures within the building(s) and
label: BODY

text: any irrigation systems on the premises.  The primary focus of the Uniform Plumbing Code is to
label: BODY

text: ensure that the plumbing system (within the building or buildings) doesn’t become contaminated via
label: BODY

text: unprotected cross connections.
label: BODY

text: Depending on the number and type of buildings served, the CCC policy of a non-community system
label: BODY

text: may be to provide:
label: BODY

text: 1. Source protection, if a single building or water user is supplied (e.g., provide a DCVA at the
label: BODY

text: well house that supplies a restaurant);
label: BODY

text: 2. Area or building isolation (particularly if a Table 9 of WAC 246-290-490 premises is
label: BODY

text: served); and/or
label: BODY

text: 3. Equivalent in-building protection through installation of backflow preventers at hazardous
label: BODY

text: fixtures per the Uniform Plumbing Code.
label: BODY

text: An example of a written program plan for a non-community system is provided in Appendix B.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Page 74
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 75
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7. Implementing a Cross-Connection Control Program
label: H4

text: General Administration
label: BODY

text: The general administration tasks for a CCC program are the same for both small and larger public
label: BODY

text: water systems.  The primary difference is in the amount of administrative work associated with
label: BODY

text: implementation of the program.  For small water systems with primarily residential customers, the
label: BODY

text: administration of a CCC program should only result in a small, added workload to the system’s
label: BODY

text: existing workload.  For these systems, someone other than a DOH-certified CCS may carry out
label: BODY

text: many of the administrative tasks associated with the CCC program. .
label: BODY

text: 7.1.1 Overall Management
label: H4

text: WAC 246-290-490(3)(e) states that "personnel, including at least one person certified as a cross-
label: BODY

text: connection specialist (CCS)..." shall be provided to develop and implement the CCC program.  The
label: BODY

text: WAC also states in 246-290-490(2)(c) that the purveyor may implement the CCC program directly
label: BODY

text: or by means of a contract with another agency or party acceptable to DOH.  This language was
label: BODY

text: specifically included to give small water systems that serve primarily residential customers the
label: BODY

text: option to contract out for the services of a CCS.  Options for employing the CCS were discussed in
label: BODY

text: Section 6.2.6.
label: BODY

text: The purveyor should designate one individual, i.e., the CCC Program Manager, to provide
label: BODY

text: the overall management of the CCC program.  The purveyor should delegate to the Program
label: BODY

text: Manager the authority and responsibility to organize and implement the CCC program.  For larger
label: BODY

text: systems, the CCC Program Manager is typically the DOH-certified CCS in responsible charge of
label: BODY

text: the CCC program.
label: BODY

text: Small water system CCC Program Managers must have a general knowledge of cross-connection
label: BODY

text: control, but they do not necessarily need to be certified as CCSs.  For small systems, administration
label: BODY

text: of the CCC program typically requires only limited, periodic work for the CCS.  Thus, the services
label: BODY

text: of a full-time CCS are not likely to be needed by a small water system (nor is full-time involvement
label: BODY

text: always practical).
label: BODY

text: Small water system CCC Program Managers that are not currently certified CCSs should complete
label: BODY

text: some CCC training.  This will help them to become more knowledgeable about the public health
label: BODY

text: aspects of cross-connection control, the regulatory requirements for public water systems and basic
label: BODY

text: industry practices.  This knowledge should help uncertified Program Managers with the day-to-day
label: BODY

text: implementation of the CCC program.
label: BODY

text: Several third party training organizations offer CCC courses in Washington.  These courses range
label: BODY

text: from inexpensive one-day Basic CCC classes for Small Water Systems to more expensive,
label: BODY

text: weeklong CCS certification classes.  More information is available on training in Appendix F.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 76
label: BODY

text: Small system CCC Program Managers interested in pursuing CCS certification should note that
label: BODY

text: scholarships might be available.  The CCC Committee of the PNWS-AWWA offers CCS
label: BODY

text: scholarships for systems serving 2500 connections or less.  See Appendix F for further information.
label: BODY

text: For a small water system, the CCC Program Manager may be:
label: BODY

text: The owner of the system (private system);
label: BODY

text: An elected representative (water association or district); or
label: BODY

text: An employee, contract manager, or satellite management agency.
label: BODY

text: The Cross-Connection Control Program Manager will be responsible for the day-to-day
label: BODY

text: contact with customers, the general public, state and local government, etc., on cross-
label: BODY

text: connection control matters.  To ensure that this contact person is kept well informed, all CCC
label: BODY

text: Program administration tasks should be under their supervision.  For example:
label: BODY

text: All correspondence should be routed through the Program Manager (the Program Manager
label: BODY

text: should sign the correspondence or at least receive a copy); and
label: BODY

text: All plans, plan review reports, cross-connection hazard survey reports, assembly test reports,
label: BODY

text: etc., should be routed through the Program Manager.
label: BODY

text: When technical CCC program issues arise, small water system CCC Program Managers who are
label: BODY

text: not certified CCSs should defer to the recommendations and advice of the contract CCS.  Program
label: BODY

text: Managers who have concerns about or don’t agree with the contract CCS’s recommendations can
label: BODY

text: contact DOH for regulatory interpretation questions and/or seek the advice of another experienced
label: BODY

text: CCS.  Non-CCS Program Managers should not over-ride the recommendations of their contract
label: BODY

text: CCSs.
label: BODY

text: 7.1.2 Purveyor's Policy Statement/Ordinance
label: H4

text: Once developed, the CCC program policy (policy statement, ordinance and/or resolution) should be
label: BODY

text: incorporated into the purveyor's system Management and Operations Manual.  Purveyors can
label: BODY

text: inform their customers about the CCC program policy by:
label: BODY

text: Distributing the policy to new customers with the application for water service (e.g., as an
label: BODY

text: attachment to the service agreement); and
label: BODY

text: Including a policy summary statement in the annual Consumer Confidence Report.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 77
label: BODY

text: The annual Consumer Confidence Report can be a
label: BODY

text: cost-effective tool for public education on the
label: BODY

text: purveyor's conditions for service, including the
label: BODY

text: customer's obligation to protect the distribution
label: BODY

text: system from contamination through cross
label: BODY

text: connections.
label: BODY

text: 7.1.3 Personnel
label: HH2

text: All water system employees (staff and/or contract manager/operator) should have a general
label: BODY

text: knowledge of cross-connection control.  The CCS involved in the development and implementation
label: BODY

text: of the program will likely be the most knowledgeable about the principles and practices of cross-
label: BODY

text: connection control.  However, all other water system staff members, from time-to-time, may be
label: BODY

text: involved in CCC issues because:
label: BODY

text: Customers may ask general questions of office and/or field staff;
label: BODY

text: Office staff will process the paper work related to the CCC program (survey records,
label: BODY

text: correspondence, DOH annual summary report forms, etc.);
label: BODY

text: Field staff may encounter backflow conditions (e.g., main break causes backsiphonage
label: BODY

text: conditions, meter reader may notice meter running backwards) or may need to respond to a
label: BODY

text: backflow incident; and
label: BODY

text: Field staff may spot a new “uncontrolled” (i.e., no backflow preventer) cross connection
label: BODY

text: (e.g., customer may have installed a lawn sprinkler system without notifying the purveyor or
label: BODY

text: obtaining a plumbing permit from the Local Administrative Authority).
label: BODY

text: General CCC training for staff may be obtained through:
label: BODY

text: 1. Workshops sponsored and/or provided by DOH or technical associations, such as the Pacific
label: BODY

text: Northwest Section - American Water Works Association (PNWS-AWWA), Spokane
label: BODY

text: Region Cross-Connection Control Committee (SRC4), the Western Washington Cross-
label: BODY

text: Connection Prevention Professionals Group (The Group), and the American Backflow
label: BODY

text: Prevention Association (ABPA); and
label: BODY

text: 2. Operator training manuals, such as Small Water System Operation and Maintenance,
label: BODY

text: prepared by California State University, Sacramento.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 78
label: BODY

text: For the CCS employed by the purveyor (on staff or by contract), specialized training is
label: BODY

text: recommended and current CCS certification is required.  The initial specialized training may be
label: BODY

text: a three to five day "specialist" course.  The CCS must hold a current Cross-Connection Specialist
label: BODY

text: certification issued by DOH.  To be eligible to sit for the CCS exam, an applicant must have a high
label: BODY

text: school diploma and have six months experience (not necessarily in cross-connection control)
label: BODY

text: working for a public water system.  The Cross-Connection Control Resource Information section in
label: BODY

text: Appendix F provides information about training resources and CCS certification courses.
label: BODY

text: DOH requires contract operators to be certified CCSs and Water Distribution Managers.  To obtain
label: BODY

text: a list of contract operators check the DOH Office of Drinking Water website at:
label: BODY

text: http://www.doh.wa.gov/ehp/dw
label: BODY

text: Completion of a three to five-day CCS course and certification by DOH ensures a minimum level of
label: BODY

text: knowledge in cross-connection control.  However, CCS certification does not provide any assurance
label: BODY

text: of experience or expertise.  When employing a CCS to develop and/or implement the cross-
label: BODY

text: connection control program (either on staff, inter-agency agreement, or contract CCS),
label: BODY

text: purveyors should follow procedures normally used for selecting a contractor or consultant.
label: BODY

text: Purveyors should try to get proposals from at least two (preferably three) contract CCSs.
label: BODY

text: When soliciting proposals from contract CCSs, at a minimum, purveyors should request:
label: BODY

text: Documentation of current CCS certification, and the date of initial CCS certification;
label: BODY

text: A resume of applicable training, certification, and work experience with specific emphasis
label: BODY

text: on experience in program development and implementation to meet the most recently
label: BODY

text: published CCC regulations;
label: BODY

text: A list of public water systems the CCS is currently under contract with and/or systems they
label: BODY

text: have provided CCC program services to within the past five years and a description of the
label: BODY

text: services provided to each system;
label: BODY

text: The names of at least three public water systems the CCS has worked for within the
label: BODY

text: previous three to five years (to contact as references);
label: BODY

text: Information on the scope of services the CCS is willing to provide (the scope should include
label: BODY

text: all tasks specified in WAC 246-290-490); and
label: BODY

text: A sample of the CCS’s written work, i.e., a sample CCC program plan, Annual Summary
label: BODY

text: Report (ASR), other report, etc. (to evaluate the quality of their work).
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 79
label: BODY

text: Purveyors should carefully check references to obtain information about the quality of service
label: H4

text: provided by the contract cross-connection control specialist.  When checking references
label: BODY

text: purveyors should be sure to ask whether any problems were encountered during the contract and
label: BODY

text: whether the system would hire the CCS again.  Purveyors should avoid cross-connection control
label: BODY

text: specialists who advocate an in-premises protection only strategy, since this approach doesn’t
label: BODY

text: provide adequate public health protection and doesn’t comply with the current cross-connection
label: BODY

text: control regulations.
label: BODY

text: It is recommended that purveyors only hire CCSs who:
label: BODY

text: Are familiar with the intent of the most recently published CCC regulations and any
label: BODY

text: revisions being proposed and who work closely with DOH CCC program staff;
label: BODY

text: Develop complete written program plans (i.e., that comply with all the minimum elements in
label: BODY

text: the regulations);
label: BODY

text: Return purveyor technical assistance phone calls within a reasonable timeframe and during
label: BODY

text: business hours; and
label: BODY

text: Ensure that original CCC records are kept by the water system.
label: BODY

text: If the feedback from references is positive, purveyors may wish to request a sample contract from
label: BODY

text: the CCS.  The contract should clearly identify the specific tasks to be performed by the CCS, the
label: BODY

text: timeframe for completion of each task and include a provision for the water system to seek a
label: BODY

text: remedy for any work that is unsatisfactory to the purveyor (at no additional cost).  The contract
label: BODY

text: should also specify that the written program plan will comply with the requirements of the most
label: BODY

text: recently published CCC regulations.  In addition, the contract should specify that all work
label: BODY

text: performed by the CCS will be in accordance with the most recently published CCC regulations.
label: BODY

text: Small systems contracting out the development of a written program are advised to include
label: BODY

text: language in the contract that allows them to withhold final payment pending DOH’s review and
label: BODY

text: acceptance of the written program.  Final payment should not be made, until DOH has indicated to
label: BODY

text: the purveyor that the written CCC program meets the current regulatory requirements and is
label: BODY

text: considered acceptable.
label: BODY

text: Taking the above steps is analogous to an insurance policy for a small system and should help
label: BODY

text: prevent a small system from being taken advantage of by unscrupulous CCSs.  DOH is aware of
label: BODY

text: one small system in Washington that paid $15,000 to a contract CCS for development of a written
label: BODY

text: CCC program plan and other services.  Shortly after the system made the final payment, DOH sent
label: BODY

text: out notices that the new regulations had been adopted.  The program developed for the small system
label: BODY

text: didn’t begin to comply with the new regulations.  The contract only specified that the program
label: BODY

text: would meet the regulations currently in effect, so the system had no recourse.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 80
label: BODY

text: In this case, the CCS under contract never told the purveyor that the CCC regulations were
label: BODY

text: undergoing extensive revision.  Yet, DOH had notified all CCSs in Washington of the upcoming
label: BODY

text: changes and invited them to participate in the regulation revisions process.  The CCS also did not
label: BODY

text: inform the purveyor that the new regulations specified the minimum elements of a written program.
label: BODY

text: If, prior to making final payment, the small system purveyor had contacted DOH and asked for an
label: BODY

text: informal review of the program developed by the contract CCS, this unfortunate situation might
label: BODY

text: have been avoided.
label: BODY

text: Small water systems might want to consider contracting with a cross-connection control
label: BODY

text: specialist who also is a certified backflow assembly tester (i.e., BAT).  Although not required,
label: BODY

text: the additional certification would be advantageous to the system, since the BAT could test all
label: BODY

text: purveyor-owned assemblies.
label: BODY

text: For most small systems, a cross-connection control
label: BODY

text: specialist (CCS) is needed for a relatively small
label: BODY

text: number of hours of work.  Thus, the hourly fee
label: BODY

text: should not be a major factor in selecting a CCS.
label: BODY

text: Instead, purveyors should select a CCS based
label: BODY

text: upon training, experience, and past
label: BODY

text: performance.
label: BODY

text: WAC 246-290-490 specifies a number of program tasks that must be performed by a DOH-certified
label: BODY

text: CCS.  These tasks include:
label: BODY

text: 1. Development and implementation of the CCC program;
label: BODY

text: 2. Hazard assessments and determination of the appropriate backflow protection;
label: BODY

text: 3. Granting of exceptions to the mandatory premises isolation requirements and completion of
label: BODY

text: forms to document the reason for granting the exception;
label: BODY

text: 4. Inspection of backflow preventer installations to ensure that backflow protection provided is
label: BODY

text: commensurate with the degree of hazard;
label: BODY

text: 5. Inspection of AG installations for compliance with the AG definition; and
label: BODY

text: 6. Inspection of backflow assemblies for correct installation and approval status.
label: BODY

text: 7.1.4 Water Service Agreements
label: H4

text: The types of water service agreements and their respective benefits are discussed in Section 6.2.2.
label: BODY

text: Whatever the form of service agreement, the Program Manager and CCS should be involved in the:
label: BODY

text: Development of the water service agreement; and
label: BODY

text: Administration of the agreement (e.g., enforcement actions).
label: BODY

text: For new customers, the Program Manager should ensure that the customer signs an application for
label: BODY

text: water service (i.e., the service agreement).
label: BODY

text: For existing customers, two options are available.  The Program Manager may either:
label: BODY

text: 1. Request that the customer sign an agreement; or
label: BODY

text: 2. Reaffirm the terms of service by asking the customer to sign an agreement as a condition of
label: BODY

text: retaining his existing backflow prevention assemblies for fixture protection in lieu of
label: BODY

text: installing premises isolation assemblies.
label: BODY

text: Appendix D includes copies of standard service agreements for new and existing customers.
label: BODY

text: 7.1.5 Backflow Assembly Installation Standards
label: H4

text: Per WAC 246-290-490, all backflow prevention assemblies that protect the public water system
label: BODY

text: from contamination must be approved by DOH.  In addition, the WAC requires these assemblies to
label: BODY

text: be installed in a manner that will facilitate their proper operation, maintenance, inspection, and in-
label: BODY

text: line testing.  Assemblies must also be installed in compliance with safety regulations and all
label: BODY

text: applicable building and plumbing code regulations.
label: BODY

text: The purveyor is responsible for ensuring that backflow
label: BODY

text: preventer installations comply with safety regulations,
label: BODY

text: codes, etc., for the backflow preventers it owns.
label: BODY

text: These requirements were established, because an improper installation decreases the assembly’s
label: BODY

text: reliability of preventing backflow.  This is due to the fact that:
label: BODY

text: An unsafe or inaccessible location reduces the likelihood of an assembly being inspected,
label: BODY

text: tested and maintained;
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 84
label: BODY

text: Improper assembly orientation may prevent proper operation;
label: BODY

text: Installation in a hazardous environment may allow contaminants to enter the assembly
label: BODY

text: through test cocks, relief valve ports, or air inlets, and/or may cause corrosion damage; and
label: BODY

text: Freezing temperatures or high temperatures may damage the assembly.
label: BODY

text: Where the purveyor is also part of a Local
label: BODY

text: Administrative Authority (town or city), any installation
label: BODY

text: problem noted by the purveyor (i.e., water utility) is
label: BODY

text: deemed to be known by the plumbing inspector, whether
label: BODY

text: or not there is communication between the two
label: BODY

text: departments.
label: BODY

text: Manufacturers provide recommendations for the proper installation of their assemblies, and it is
label: BODY

text: important to consult the manufacturer's instructions prior to the installation of any assembly.
label: BODY

text: However, the water purveyor or other approval authorities may have established installation
label: BODY

text: requirements that differ from the manufacturer's recommendations.  In fact, the manufacturer's
label: BODY

text: recommendations may be in conflict with DOH and/or the purveyor's requirements.  In all cases,
label: BODY

text: the more stringent installation requirements of DOH and the water purveyor take precedence
label: BODY

text: over the manufacturer’s recommendations.
label: BODY

text: The Washington State Department of Health
label: BODY

text: Backflow Prevention Assemblies Approved for Installation
label: BODY

text: in Washington shows the approved orientation for the
label: BODY

text: installation of each approved assembly (e.g., flow upward,
label: BODY

text: horizontal, vertical, or alternate orientation) by make,
label: BODY

text: model, and size of assembly.
label: BODY

text: Systems that need to establish installation standards for their program plans can consult technical
label: BODY

text: publications, regional CCC groups and/or larger purveyors in their area for detailed assembly
label: BODY

text: installation information.  Recommended installation standards are provided in technical publications
label: BODY

text: such as the:
label: BODY

text: Manual of Cross-Connection Control, published by the University of Southern California -
label: BODY

text: Foundation for Cross-Connection Control & Hydraulic Research (USC-FCCCHR); and
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 85
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control Manual, Accepted Procedure and Practice, published by the
label: BODY

text: Pacific Northwest Section, American Water Works Association.
label: BODY

text: Most water utilities in Washington with established programs reference the PNWS-AWWA
label: BODY

text: publication.
label: BODY

text: Another source of installation information is the regional CCC groups within Washington.  The
label: BODY

text: Western Washington Group has developed brochures showing the installation requirements for each
label: BODY

text: type of assembly used for premises isolation.
label: BODY

text: The purveyor of a small water system may adopt installation standards by referencing:
label: BODY

text: The above noted manuals;
label: BODY

text: The standard plans issued by a nearby (large) utility;
label: BODY

text: The standard plans issued by a regional CCC group in Washington; or
label: BODY

text: Standard plans issued by the purveyor.
label: BODY

text: Examples of standard installation drawings are included in Appendix D.
label: BODY

text: Implementation of Program
label: BODY

text: Program implementation starts with the adoption of CCC policy (ordinance, by-law, or other legal
label: BODY

text: instrument).  This is followed by development of a written program plan to carry out the policy and
label: BODY

text: to meet the requirements of WAC 246-290-490.  The written description of the program must be
label: BODY

text: included in the purveyor's Water System Plan or Small Water System Management Program,
label: BODY

text: whichever is applicable.
label: BODY

text: WAC 246-290-490 (3)(b) sets forth the required elements of the CCC program.  The minimum
label: BODY

text: elements are summarized in section 4.3 of this manual.  The major implementation elements are
label: BODY

text: discussed in this section.
label: BODY

text: The purveyor reduces exposure to liability by
label: BODY

text: complying with the cross-connection control
label: BODY

text: regulations for Group A systems and following the
label: BODY

text: "standards" of the cross-connection control
label: BODY

text: industry.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 86
label: BODY

text: 7.2.1 Schedule of Initial Risk Assessment
label: H4

text: The purveyor must establish procedures and schedules for assessing the cross-connection
label: BODY

text: hazard (health risk) of all new and existing customers.  The procedure for hazard assessment
label: BODY

text: depends on the type of program adopted, i.e., premises isolation versus a combination program that
label: BODY

text: also relies on in-premises assemblies.  The discussion on program types was provided in Section
label: BODY

text: New Customers
label: BODY

text: The hazard assessment for all new connections should have begun in April of 1999.  This was the
label: BODY

text: effective date of the new regulations.  According to the WAC, for new customers, the hazard
label: BODY

text: assessment must be done before service is provided.  The assessment may be done by:
label: BODY

text: Category classification (medical clinic);
label: BODY

text: Customer questionnaire (fire sprinkler system); and/or
label: BODY

text: CCS plan review and field cross-connection hazard survey.
label: BODY

text: Existing Customers
label: BODY

text: For existing customers, the purveyor must prepare a schedule acceptable to DOH for:
label: BODY

text: The initial hazard assessment; and
label: BODY

text: Periodic re-assessment.
label: BODY

text: An absolute deadline has not been established by DOH for completion of the initial hazard
label: BODY

text: assessment.
label: BODY

text: The hazard assessment procedures for new and existing customers are essentially the same.
label: BODY

text: However, the hazard assessment schedules for these two categories of customers will differ.  The
label: BODY

text: hazard assessment schedule for existing customers is a key element in the purveyor's written
label: BODY

text: program.
label: BODY

text: The assessment schedules directly affect the annual administration and operation costs of the
label: BODY

text: purveyor’s CCC program.  The schedules also have a major bearing on the purveyor's exposure to
label: BODY

text: the risk of contamination and potential liability for damages from a backflow incident.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 87
label: BODY

text: Hazard assessments should be done on a priority
label: BODY

text: basis.  A higher priority should be given to high
label: BODY

text: health hazard categories of premises (e.g.,
label: BODY

text: hospitals, medical clinics, car washes, etc., of the
label: BODY

text: type listed on Table 9 of WAC 246-290-490).
label: BODY

text: Setting Priorities
label: BODY

text: All purveyors need to set priorities for hazard assessments, due to limited resources.  However,
label: BODY

text: purveyors with combination programs need to even be more careful in prioritizing their hazard
label: BODY

text: assessments.  This is because a significantly greater effort is required to survey the non-high hazard
label: BODY

text: customer’s premises to determine if backflow preventers at fixtures provide protection
label: BODY

text: commensurate with the degree of hazard and equivalent to premises isolation.
label: BODY

text: For combination programs that rely on premises isolation and in-premises protection, priority for
label: BODY

text: hazard assessments should be as follows (listed from high to low priority):
label: BODY

text: 1. High Priority:  Customers of the type listed on Table 9 of WAC 246-290-490 as a high
label: BODY

text: health hazard requiring premises isolation by an AG or RPBA (mandatory premises
label: BODY

text: isolation);
label: BODY

text: 2. Medium Priority:  Customers included in the purveyor's supplemental list for mandatory
label: BODY

text: premises isolation; and
label: BODY

text: 3. Low Priority:  The remaining customers.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Table 14 lays out a reasonable hazard assessment schedule for a small water system.  The
label: BODY

text: timeframes listed under the schedule column start from the initiation of the water system’s CCC
label: BODY

text: program.

label: BODY

text: Purveyor may use their billing records, business license information, and/or the telephone book
label: BODY

text: "Yellow Pages" to identify potential commercial, industrial, and other non-single family residential
label: BODY

text: customers.  This list can be used to make a rough appraisal of the number of connections in each
label: BODY

text: non-residential hazard category.  For small towns and cities, the local business licensing agency is
label: BODY

text: often a very good source of information for identifying non-residential customers.
label: BODY

text: Once the rough appraisal is made, the next step is to determine if a customer actually "fits" the
label: BODY

text: hazard category.  The purveyor’s CCS must make final hazard assessment decisions.
label: BODY

text: Exceptions
label: BODY

text: As mentioned previously, some customers that initially appear to fall into a high health hazard
label: BODY

text: category requiring mandatory premises isolation may actually pose only a moderate or low hazard
label: BODY

text: to the public water system.  For example, a building described as a medical clinic may contain only
label: BODY

text: psychologists, and thus, would not fall into a high health hazard category requiring premises
label: BODY

text: isolation by an RPBA.  However, if a tenant changed to a physician or veterinarian, the building
label: BODY

text: would require an RPBA for premises isolation.
label: BODY

text: Other examples of premises that initially appear to fall into the high hazard category but pose a
label: BODY

text: lower hazard are:
label: BODY

text: A “bottling plant” that only stores the finished product; and
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 89
label: BODY

text: A commercial dry cleaners or laundromat that is used only to collect or deliver clothes (i.e.,
label: BODY

text: the cleaning facility is located elsewhere).
label: BODY

text: For these type facilities, the purveyor has the policy choice to either:
label: BODY

text: 1. Require premises isolation from the start, based on the potential for a change in tenants/use;
label: BODY

text: 2. Grant an exception to premises isolation and frequently re-assess the hazard to detect a
label: BODY

text: change in tenants/use.
label: BODY

text: Purveyors don’t have to obtain DOH concurrence to grant an exception to mandatory
label: BODY

text: premises isolation for a high-hazard category of customer of the type listed in Table 9 of WAC
label: BODY

text: 246-290-490, where the customer's water use does not ”match” the high-hazard assessment.
label: BODY

text: However, the purveyor's CCS must document the justification for waiving premises isolation by
label: BODY

text: completing an Exceptions Report Form.  Purveyors must submit Exception Report Forms to DOH
label: BODY

text: with the ASR (see Section 7.6).  All exceptions granted by the purveyor to the mandatory premises
label: BODY

text: isolation list must be reported to DOH.
label: BODY

text: Customer Notification
label: BODY

text: Once the initial hazard assessment is complete, purveyors must notify their customers of the results.
label: BODY

text: The WAC states that the purveyor must notify the customer, within a reasonable timeframe, to
label: BODY

text: inform them of the assessment results and the requirements for backflow prevention to protect the
label: BODY

text: purveyor's system.  To allow for purveyor flexibility, DOH has not established an absolute
label: BODY

text: timeframe for issuing the assessment notification for backflow preventer installation.
label: BODY

text: However, to better protect public health and for risk and liability management, it is prudent for
label: BODY

text: purveyors to notify customers as soon as possible of their:
label: BODY

text: Hazard assessment results; and
label: BODY

text: Responsibility to prevent contaminants from entering their potable water systems and the
label: BODY

text: purveyor's distribution system.
label: BODY

text: Table 15 presents a schedule that can be used by a small water system for notifying customers of
label: BODY

text: hazard assessment results.  The schedule starts from the date of completion of the hazard
label: BODY

text: assessment.

text: 7.2.2 Schedule for Periodic Re-Assessment
label: HH2

text: Per the WAC, the purveyor must periodically re-assess the cross-connection hazard posed by all
label: BODY

text: connections served by the system.  However, the purveyor’s reassessment efforts can focus on
label: BODY

text: customers other than those with premises isolation AGs or RPBAs, as long as annual test
label: BODY

text: reports are satisfactory for the premises isolation backflow preventers.  Customers with
label: BODY

text: premises isolation AGs or RPBAs already have installed the maximum backflow protection.
label: BODY

text: How often should hazard reassessments be done?  The frequency of periodic hazard re-assessments
label: BODY

text: should be based on the potential risk the customer poses to the purveyor's water system.
label: BODY

text: Due to resource limitations, most systems will need to phase the scheduling of hazard re-
label: BODY

text: assessments.  Customers that pose the greatest risk to the water system (i.e., non-residential
label: BODY

text: customers) should have their hazard reassessments scheduled first.  Once the higher risk customers
label: BODY

text: have been addressed, assessments for lower risk (i.e., residential) customers can be scheduled.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 91
label: BODY

text: Priorities (listed from highest to lowest) for scheduling re-assessments should be given to:
label: BODY

text: 1. Non-residential customers:
label: BODY

text: a. Without premises isolation DCVAs, i.e., where in-premises backflow preventers protect
label: BODY

text: the public water system from contamination (e.g., industrial building that is likely to
label: BODY

text: have changes in the plumbing);
label: BODY

text: b. With premises isolation DCVAs, where changes in tenants or plumbing could raise the
label: BODY

text: risk to high hazard (e.g., strip malls where a building occupancy could change to include
label: BODY

text: a medical clinic); and
label: BODY

text: 2. Residential customers (the water use questionnaire can be used for re-assessments).
label: BODY

text: Per the WAC, a re-assessment is also required whenever there is a change in the use of the
label: BODY

text: premises.  This is because a change in use often results in a change in the hazard posed to the water
label: BODY

text: system.  Hazard assessment changes may trigger:
label: BODY

text: A requirement for a premises isolation backflow preventer, where no preventer was
label: BODY

text: previously required or where the purveyor relied on in-premises preventers; or
label: BODY

text: An upgrade to a more reliable preventer (i.e., DCVA to RPBA), where a less reliable
label: BODY

text: preventer was previously required.
label: BODY
