text: 7.2.3 Schedule for Backflow Prevention Assemblies Installation
label: H4

text: Once the initial hazard assessment is complete and the customer has been notified, the WAC states
label: BODY

text: that the purveyor shall develop and implement procedures for:
label: BODY

text: Eliminating cross connections; or
label: BODY

text: Controlling cross connections by installation of approved backflow preventers
label: BODY

text: commensurate with the degree of hazard in situations where cross connections cannot be
label: BODY

text: eliminated.
label: BODY

text: Cross connections are eliminated by removal of points of
label: BODY

text: use of water (e.g., plumbing fixtures) or removing sources
label: BODY

text: of contaminants (e.g., abandoning a private well according
label: BODY

text: to Washington State Department of Ecology
label: BODY

text: specifications).
label: BODY

text: It is not possible to eliminate all cross connections on
label: BODY

text: the customer's premises.
label: BODY

text: A hazard assessment determines if the customer's cross connections are "controlled" to the
label: BODY

text: satisfaction of the purveyor.  If control is not satisfactory, the purveyor must:
label: BODY

text: 1. Install an approved backflow preventer for premises isolation;
label: BODY

text: 2. Get the customer to install an approved backflow preventer for premises isolation; or
label: BODY

text: 3. Get the customer to install in-premises approved backflow preventers (for fixture protection
label: BODY

text: or area isolation) that provide equivalent (to premises isolation) protection for the purveyor's
label: BODY

text: system.
label: BODY

text: Whichever is the case, the purveyor must establish a schedule for the installation of the backflow
label: BODY

text: preventer(s).  To give flexibility to purveyors, DOH has not established an absolute deadline for the
label: BODY

text: installation of backflow preventers once a hazard assessment for an existing customer has been
label: BODY

text: done.  However, for public health protection and liability management reasons, backflow
label: BODY

text: preventers should be installed as soon as possible after the need for a preventer is identified.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 93
label: BODY

text: For liability management reasons, it is in the
label: BODY

text: purveyor's best interest to have assemblies installed
label: BODY

text: as soon as possible.
label: BODY

text: The installation of backflow prevention assemblies may be a significant cost to the purveyor and/or
label: BODY

text: customer.  For new customers, the cost of a backflow preventer for premises isolation or in-
label: BODY

text: premises alternatives will constitute a very small amount compared with the overall project budget
label: BODY

text: if they are required at the time of construction.  Thus, the requirement for the installation of a BPA
label: BODY

text: before service is provided is not an undue burden to the customer.
label: BODY

text: For existing customers and/or the purveyor, the cost of installing backflow preventers as a retrofit
label: BODY

text: may be significant compared with the customer's annual operating budget.  Except where an
label: BODY

text: immediate high health hazard has been identified, it is reasonable to work with the customer and to
label: BODY

text: allow them enough time to fund the installation of backflow prevention assemblies required by the
label: BODY

text: purveyor.
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: 7.2.4 Communication with Customers
label: H4

text: The CCC Program Manager should be responsible for all initial communication with customers.
label: BODY

text: The initial communication should include:
label: BODY

text: Notification of the water system’s policy (or change in policy) to establish a CCC program;
label: BODY

text: Public education materials describing the need for cross-connection control; and
label: BODY

text: Hazard assessment information, i.e., either the distribution of water use questionnaires or the
label: BODY

text: scheduling of a cross-connection hazard survey.
label: BODY

text: The purveyor's CCS may handle subsequent communication with customers regarding the CCC
label: BODY

text: program.
label: BODY

text: Sample letters, public education materials, and forms are provided in Appendix D.  Additional
label: BODY

text: resource materials may be found in the PNWS-AWWA manuals and USC Manual listed in
label: BODY

text: Appendix F.
label: BODY

text: 7.2.5 Requirements of Existing Customers
label: H4

text: Under WAC 246-290-490, purveyors must protect the public water system from the cross-
label: BODY

text: connection hazards posed by its customers.  Unless the purveyor has specific knowledge to the
label: BODY

text: contrary, for existing customers, the purveyor must assume that:
label: BODY

text: All customers were in compliance with the plumbing code in effect at the time the certificate
label: BODY

text: of occupancy was issued for their premises; and
label: BODY

text: No significant plumbing changes have occurred (i.e., that would require a new plumbing
label: BODY

text: permit) since the certificate was issued.
label: BODY

text: The Local Administrative Authority, i.e., plumbing inspector, has jurisdiction over matters of public
label: BODY

text: health and safety within the property lines of the customer’s premises.  The customer's plumbing is
label: BODY

text: considered to be "reasonably" safe, if it complies with the health-related parts of the Uniform
label: BODY

text: Plumbing Code.  However, unlike the drinking water regulations, the customer is "vested" with
label: BODY

text: respect to the Uniform Plumbing Code.
label: BODY

text: Thus, Local Administrative Authorities can’t require a change in the customer’s plumbing system to
label: BODY

text: bring the plumbing into compliance with the most recently adopted code, unless the Local
label: BODY

text: Administrative Authority has specific knowledge of a health or safety hazard.  Also, the Local
label: BODY

text: Administrative Authority doesn’t have the authority to make random plumbing inspections, once
label: BODY

text: certificates of occupancy have been issued.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 97
label: BODY

text: Despite efforts by the Local Administrative Authorities to ensure compliance with the Uniform
label: BODY

text: Plumbing Code, experience has shown that some customers make plumbing changes without the
label: BODY

text: proper permits and thus, their plumbing doesn’t comply with the plumbing code in effect at the time
label: BODY

text: of construction.   Also, the plumbing of many other existing customer premises may not comply
label: BODY

text: with the most recently adopted plumbing code.
label: BODY

text: If the purveyor requires a backflow preventer for premises isolation (i.e., purveyor installs or
label: BODY

text: requires customer to install), prior to installation:
label: BODY

text: 1. The purveyor should notify the customer:
label: BODY

text: a. Of the reason for the backflow preventer installation (e.g., general policy for a meter
label: BODY

text: check; to isolate an existing lawn irrigation system); and
label: BODY

text: b. That the backflow preventer will prevent thermal expansion from being relieved
label: BODY

text: through the distribution main, and thus, the customer should ensure that his plumbing
label: BODY

text: has adequate safety protection (e.g., pressure temperature relief valve on the hot water
label: BODY

text: tank, and an expansion tank).
label: BODY

text: 2. The purveyor should notify the Local Administrative Authority (LAA) (plumbing
label: BODY

text: inspector) of any backflow preventer and/or meter check to be installed by the purveyor,
label: BODY

text: so that the LAA may inspect the customer's premises for thermal expansion protection.
label: BODY

text: 7.2.6 Cross Connections in Purveyor's System
label: H4

text: An essential component of the purveyor's CCC program is to provide protection from cross
label: BODY

text: connections at purveyor-owned facilities.  These facilities include:
label: BODY

text: Office and maintenance buildings;
label: BODY

text: Water treatment plants; and
label: BODY

text: Water distribution mains.
label: BODY

text: Office and maintenance facilities should be evaluated using the same criteria used for assessing a
label: BODY

text: customer's premises.  For facilities constructed on parcels of land owned by the purveyor, the
label: BODY

text: purveyor must also comply with the Uniform Plumbing Code requirements enforced by the Local
label: BODY

text: Administrative Authority (plumbing inspector).
label: BODY

text: If the purveyor is an agency of a city, town, or county, municipal facilities such as water and sewage
label: BODY

text: treatment plants, parks, community centers, government buildings, and shops must also be
label: BODY

text: evaluated for cross-connection control.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 98
label: BODY

text: There are a number of common cross connections typically found in purveyor-owned facilities.
label: BODY

text: These may include cross connections in:
label: BODY

text: 1. Water treatment plant including:
label: BODY

text: a. The discharge of filter backwash and rinse water to waste;
label: BODY

text: b. Potable water connections to chemical injectors or pumps;
label: BODY

text: c. Sampling lines that connect a meter to both raw and treated (finished) water;
label: BODY

text: d. By-pass connections between raw and treated water storage;
label: BODY

text: e. Surface washers;
label: BODY

text: f. Hydraulically operated filter effluent valves;
label: BODY

text: g. Chlorinators connected to both raw and treated water; and
label: BODY

text: h. Common walls between finished and unfinished water.
label: BODY

text: 2. Distribution system including:
label: BODY

text: a. Air release and vacuum valves;
label: BODY

text: b. Temporary connections for new water main disinfection;
label: BODY

text: c. Fire hydrants, standpipes when used for:
label: BODY

text: i. Filling tanker trucks; or
label: BODY

text: ii. Flushing water mains or sewers.
label: BODY

text: The following manuals list typical distribution system hazards and the recommended backflow
label: BODY

text: prevention:
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control Manual, Accepted Procedure and Practice, published by the
label: BODY

text: Pacific Northwest Section, American Water Works Association (PNWS-AWWA); and
label: BODY

text: Manual of Cross-Connection Control, published by the University of Southern California
label: BODY

text: Foundation for Cross-Connection Control and Hydraulic Research.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 99
label: BODY

text: For liability and public relations reasons, it is
label: BODY

text: prudent for purveyors to provide cross-connection
label: BODY

text: control for all purveyor-owned facilities, before
label: BODY

text: asking customers to spend money for backflow
label: BODY

text: preventer installation and testing.
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: premises.  For ease of use, the tables are divided into residential and commercial hazards
label: BODY

text: respectively.

text: Mandatory Premises Isolation
label: BODY

text: WAC 246-290-490 lists categories of high hazard premises that require mandatory isolation.  Most
label: BODY

text: CCC technical publications also list customers requiring mandatory premises isolation.  These lists
label: BODY

text: were developed based on assessments of severe or very high degrees of hazard.  The assessments
label: BODY

text: are often confirmed by reports of well-documented backflow incidents.
label: BODY

text: Between the various technical publications and state regulations, there may be different customer
label: BODY

text: categories listed for mandatory premises isolation.  At a minimum, the purveyor must comply
label: BODY

text: with the premises isolation requirements of WAC 246-290-490(4).  It should be noted that the
label: BODY

text: WAC gives purveyors the option to require premises isolation for connections serving premises not
label: BODY

text: identified on Table 9 of WAC 246-290-490.  These include premises such as tall buildings,
label: BODY

text: premises with complex plumbing or plumbing subject to frequent changes, and premises with a
label: BODY

text: history of cross connections being established.
label: BODY

text: Some purveyors supplement Table 9 of the WAC by adding other customer categories (usually non-
label: BODY

text: residential) to their system’s mandatory premises isolation list.  Purveyors can obtain ideas for
label: BODY

text: additional categories in technical manuals, such as:
label: BODY

text: Manual of Cross-Connection Control, published by the University of Southern California -
label: BODY

text: Foundation for Cross-Connection Control & Hydraulic Research (USC-FCCCHR); and
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 102
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control Manual, Accepted Procedure and Practice, published by the
label: BODY

text: Pacific Northwest Section - American Water Works Association.
label: BODY

text: 7.3.1 Washington State Requirements for Fire Protection Systems
label: H4

text: In Washington, the Uniform Plumbing Code requires backflow prevention for all fire protection
label: BODY

text: systems, except for flow-through or combination systems for residential services.
label: BODY

text: A flow-through fire system:
label: BODY

text: Uses a different piping system from the consumer’s potable water piping;
label: BODY

text: Is constructed of approved potable water piping and materials to which sprinkler heads are
label: BODY

text: attached; and
label: BODY

text: Ends at a connection to a toilet or other plumbing fixture to prevent the water in the pipe
label: BODY

text: from becoming stagnant.
label: BODY

text: In a combination fire system, the potable water piping and materials serve both the fire sprinkler
label: BODY

text: system and the consumer’s potable water system.
label: BODY

text: WAC 246-290-490 requires the purveyor to ensure that backflow protection consistent with the
label: BODY

text: UPC is installed.  The UPC requires minimum protection as follows:
label: BODY

text: An RPBA or RPDA for fire protection systems with chemical addition or using an
label: BODY

text: unapproved auxiliary water supply; and
label: BODY

text: A DCVA or DCDA for all other fire protection systems.
label: BODY

text: Purveyors can easily meet this requirement for new services.  Purveyors can stipulate in the service
label: BODY

text: agreement (i.e., application for new service) that the customer must comply with the current
label: BODY

text: Uniform Plumbing Code before service is provided.
label: BODY

text: For existing customers, the purveyors may only request compliance from the customer, or install a
label: BODY

text: backflow preventer on the service for premises isolation.  By defining "high health cross-connection
label: BODY

text: hazard" and specifying the appropriate approved backflow preventer as an AG, RPBA or RPDA, by
label: BODY

text: default, a fire protection system requiring a DCVA or DCDA is a "low health cross-connection
label: BODY

text: hazard.”  This may undermine the purveyor's enforcement of a DCVA for public health protection
label: BODY

text: reasons.
label: BODY

text: For existing customers, purveyors can require compliance in situations where the customer has a
label: BODY

text: change in water use, remodels the premises, etc.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 103
label: BODY

text: The purveyor is not an enforcement agency for the
label: BODY

text: Uniform Plumbing Code.
label: BODY

text: An existing customer may be "vested" with respect to the
label: BODY

text: Uniform Plumbing Code.  If a backflow preventer is not
label: BODY

text: currently in place, neither the purveyor nor the Local
label: BODY

text: Administrative Authority (plumbing inspector) has
label: BODY

text: authority to require compliance with the current UPC.
label: BODY

text: However, if the customer does not install the required
label: BODY

text: backflow prevention assembly, the purveyor must
label: BODY

text: install an assembly on the service.
label: BODY

text: Table 21 provides guidance for scheduling the installation of backflow preventers on fire sprinkler
label: BODY

text: systems for existing customer connections.  The schedule starts from the purveyor’s hazard
label: BODY

text: assessment notice to the customers.
label: BODY

text: Table 21
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Connections
label: BODY

text: Fire System Hazard Category
label: BODY

text: Schedule of Backflow
label: BODY

text: Preventer Installation
label: BODY

text: High health hazard fire systems (with chemical
label: BODY

text: addition and/or auxiliary supply)
label: BODY

text: Within 2 years
label: BODY

text: All other fire systems
label: BODY

text: Within 10 years
label: BODY

text: The purveyor should notify the Local Fire Marshal
label: BODY

text: whenever a backflow preventer is installed on a
label: BODY

text: fire service or on a combined fire and domestic
label: BODY

text: service, since the added pressure loss through the
label: BODY

text: backflow assembly may affect the design of the
label: BODY

text: fire system.
label: BODY

text: 7.3.2 Purveyor's Additional Requirements
label: H4

text: WAC 246-290-490 establishes minimum requirements for CCC programs.  However, under the
label: BODY

text: WAC, water purveyors may develop more stringent program requirements than those of the state
label: BODY

text: and/or local levels of government (i.e., the county).
label: BODY

text: When adding new requirements or making more stringent requirements, it is important for
label: BODY

text: purveyors to:
label: BODY

text: Establish justification for the added requirement (i.e., show that the decision was not
label: BODY

text: arbitrary or capricious and that the added requirement can reasonably be met by the
label: BODY

text: customer); and
label: BODY

text: Maintain consistency in their application to customers served by the system.
label: BODY

text: Justification for additional requirements may be based on:
label: BODY

text: • Following good engineering and public health practice as outlined in technical
label: BODY

text: publications; and
label: BODY

text: • Adopting a policy to further limit the purveyor's risk and liability (e.g., by requiring
label: BODY

text: DCVAs on all commercial customers).
label: BODY

text: Consistency may require that the purveyor apply the more stringent requirements:
label: BODY

text: Equally to new and existing customers; and
label: BODY

text: To similar hazard categories.
label: BODY

text: Requirements for Backflow Assembly Testing
label: BODY

text: Backflow assemblies are mechanical devices subject to fouling and wear.  History has shown that
label: BODY

text: backflow preventers that are not tested periodically will not be maintained or repaired.  Backflow
label: BODY

text: preventers that are not maintained or repaired have a much higher likelihood of failure.  Similarly,
label: BODY

text: AGs that are not inspected periodically may be by-passed or re-plumbed.
label: BODY

text: Testing Frequency
label: BODY

text: Backflow assemblies and AGs used in place of assemblies relied upon by the purveyor to protect
label: BODY

text: the public water system must be inspected for proper installation and tested for proper operation.
label: BODY

text: WAC 246-290-490 (7)(b) requires inspections and/or testing:
label: BODY

text: 1. At the time of installation;
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 105
label: BODY

text: 2. Annually after installation (minimum frequency);
label: BODY

text: 3. After a backflow incident; and
label: BODY

text: 4. After an assembly is repaired, reinstalled, or relocated (or an AG is re-plumbed).
label: BODY

text: Atmospheric vacuum breakers on residential lawn irrigation systems, if relied upon by the
label: BODY

text: purveyor to protect the public water system, must also be inspected for proper installation per WAC
label: BODY

text: At the time of installation;
label: BODY

text: After a backflow incident; and
label: BODY

text: After repair, reinstallation or relocation.
label: BODY

text: Because a test procedure for the AVB has not been
label: BODY

text: established, some purveyors require a PVBA or DCVA on
label: BODY

text: all lawn irrigation systems, so that all preventers relied
label: BODY

text: upon by the purveyor are testable.
label: BODY

text: A lawn irrigation system for a residential customer poses
label: BODY

text: no less a hazard than an irrigation system for a
label: BODY

text: commercial customer.
label: BODY

text: The UPC establishes backflow protection requirements
label: BODY

text: for irrigation systems, and as amended for Washington,
label: BODY

text: allows an RPBA, PVBA, DCVA, or an AVB for
label: BODY

text: backflow protection for irrigation system without
label: BODY

text: chemical addition.
label: BODY

text: Test Procedures
label: BODY

text: WAC 246-290-490 requires backflow prevention assemblies (relied upon by the purveyor to protect
label: BODY

text: the public water system) to be tested using procedures acceptable to DOH, such as those specified in
label: BODY

text: the most recently published edition of the Manual of Cross-Connection Control, published by the
label: BODY

text: University of Southern California Foundation for Cross-Connection Control & Hydraulic Research.
label: BODY

text: Copies of the field test procedures are available from DOH on request.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 106
label: BODY

text: It should be noted that the testing requirements in the most recently published edition of the
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control Manual, Accepted Procedure and Practice, published by the Pacific
label: BODY

text: Northwest Section, American Water Works Association are more stringent (supplemental tests
label: BODY

text: required) than the test procedures specified by USC.  Therefore, it is important that the purveyor
label: BODY

text: adopts as a policy and notifies the customer if the more stringent PNWS-AWWA test
label: BODY

text: requirements are to be followed.  An example of the supplemental testing requirements of the
label: BODY

text: PNWS-AWWA Manual for RPBAs is that the RPBA relief valve tests include a check to verify
label: BODY

text: the relief valve will continue to open and discharge water.
label: BODY

text: Most small water systems specify the use of the
label: BODY

text: standard Washington State Department of Health
label: BODY

text: Approved Field Test Procedures.
label: BODY

text: As discussed in Section 6.2.7, purveyors have the option of testing the assembly (purveyor's
label: BODY

text: certified staff or purveyor-contracted certified BAT), or requiring the customer to employ a BAT to
label: BODY

text: perform the test and submit a test report to the purveyor.  The purveyor may also elect to make the
label: BODY

text: initial test of an assembly, but require the customer to arrange for all subsequent tests.
label: BODY

text: Testing Notification
label: BODY

text: Regardless whether the purveyor or assembly owner is responsible for testing, the small water
label: BODY

text: system purveyor should schedule the tests of all assemblies that protect the public water system at
label: BODY

text: the same time of the year.  This approach makes it easier for the purveyor to administer the testing
label: BODY

text: portion of the cross-connection program.  In addition, BATs will often reduce their testing fees
label: BODY

text: when they can arrange to test several assemblies in one area.
label: BODY

text: If the assembly owner is responsible for testing, purveyors should:
label: BODY

text: 1. Notify the customer in writing and allow at least one month from the date of notification for
label: BODY

text: the testing to be done and the test report to be returned;
label: BODY

text: 2. Include, in the testing notification letter, a statement affirming the understanding that service
label: BODY

text: is provided based on the customer's agreement to test, maintain, and repair the assemblies
label: BODY

text: required by the purveyor (if a written service agreement is not in place);
label: BODY

text: 3. Specify the acceptable field testing method (e.g., the DOH field test procedures);
label: BODY

text: 4. Provide a list of local testers (BATs); and
label: BODY

text: 5. Provide a test report form for each assembly owned by the customer.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 107
label: BODY

text: A public listing of the DOH-certified BATs will be available from DOH sometime in the future.
label: BODY

text: DOH does not currently require that one “standardized” test report form be used in Washington.
label: BODY

text: This approach gives purveyors the flexibility to design their test report forms for ease of data entry
label: BODY

text: into their respective CCC databases.  However, all test reports should provide the same basic
label: BODY

text: information needed by the purveyor.  It is hoped that the minimum elements of an acceptable test
label: BODY

text: report form will be addressed in future CCC-related regulation revisions.
label: BODY

text: Because the minimum elements of an acceptable test report are not currently specified in the
label: BODY

text: drinking water regulations, purveyors must identify test report contents as part of their testing
label: BODY

text: quality assurance/quality control program (Element 6 of WAC 246-290-490).  A sample test report
label: BODY

text: form is included in Appendix D.  Other sample test report forms are available:
label: BODY

text: • In technical CCC guidance manuals from PNWS-AWWA and/or USC;
label: BODY

text: • From national organizations such as the ABPA; and
label: BODY

text: • From regional CCC groups in Washington, such as SRC4 and “The Group.”
label: BODY

text: • To obtain test report forms from the above sources, see Appendix F for contact
label: BODY

text: information.
label: BODY

text: • It should be noted that the regional CCC groups in Washington are in the process of
label: BODY

text: developing a standardized test report form for voluntary use by their members.  Many
label: BODY

text: BATs support the standardized test report form concept since it eliminates the need for
label: BODY

text: BATs to keep track of and use different test report forms in different service areas (i.e., a
label: BODY

text: different form for each purveyor).
label: BODY

text: Purveyors may choose to address the requirement for a periodic hazard re-assessment at the same
label: BODY

text: time they address assembly testing.  For purveyors that conduct their own hazard re-assessments, a
label: BODY

text: water use questionnaire can be included with the testing notice for customers.  Purveyors that rely
label: BODY

text: on hazard re-assessments conducted by customer-employed CCSs may include with the assembly
label: BODY

text: testing notice:
label: BODY

text: A notification letter for the customer to employ a certified CCS to re-survey the premises
label: BODY

text: (the CCS’s re-assessment should either confirm that the existing assemblies are
label: BODY

text: commensurate with the degree of hazard or recommend additional and/or different
label: BODY

text: assemblies); and
label: BODY

text: A list of local CCSs providing contract services.
label: BODY

text: A list of contract operators who are certified CCSs is available from the DOH website.  Regional
label: BODY

text: CCC groups may also maintain lists of experienced CCSs who are willing to contract with small
label: BODY

text: water system customers for hazard surveys.  See Appendix F for resource information.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 108
label: BODY

text: It should be noted that the purveyor only has a contract relationship with the customer.  In other
label: BODY

text: words, purveyors have no contract relationship with the customer's BAT or CCS.  Thus, all
label: BODY

text: purveyor communication about testing and surveys should be with the customer, not with the
label: BODY

text: customer’s backflow assembly tester or cross-connection control specialist (third party).
label: BODY

text: Purveyors should send the notices for testing directly to their customers.  Both the BAT and the
label: BODY

text: customer should sign the completed test report form, and the customer should return the completed
label: BODY

text: form to the purveyor.  This approach accomplishes the following:
label: BODY

text: Establishes a record that the customer was made aware of any deficiencies listed in the
label: BODY

text: report form by the BAT; and
label: BODY

text: Re-affirms, by signature, the customer's agreement to test and maintain the assemblies as a
label: BODY

text: condition of service.
label: BODY

text: Copies of sample testing notification and hazard re-survey letters are included in Appendix D.
label: BODY

text: The CCC Program Manager should review test and survey forms as soon as possible after they are
label: BODY

text: submitted.  For CCC Program Managers that are not certified CCSs, the purveyor's CCS should
label: BODY

text: provide guidance on what to look for in the initial review (e.g., the test form is complete, and the
label: BODY

text: data shows that the assembly passed the test).  Based on the initial review:
label: BODY

text: If the test report form is incomplete, the CCC Program Manager should notify the customer
label: BODY

text: of the deficiency (and may, as a courtesy, choose to also notify the BAT at the same time);
label: BODY

text: If the test report form shows that the assembly failed the field test, the CCC Program
label: BODY

text: Manager should give written notice to the customer to repair or replace the assembly within
label: BODY

text: a specified timeframe (e.g., one month).  This is the start of enforcement procedures.
label: BODY

text: If the CCC Program Manager has concerns about a test report, the contract CCS should be
label: BODY

text: contacted for technical assistance.
label: BODY

text: Figure 4 shows a typical testing process for a small public water system.
label: BODY

text: If the purveyor’s cross-connection control program relies
label: BODY

text: upon third party backflow assembly tester or cross-
label: BODY

text: connection control specialist for hazard surveys, the
label: BODY

text: purveyor has a contract relationship with the owner, not
label: BODY

text: with the owner’s cross-connection control specialist or
label: BODY

text: backflow assembly tester.
label: BODY

text: All purveyor communication for surveys and tests should
label: BODY

text: only be with the building/assembly owner.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Purveyors should consider coordinating their test notices with the test notices issued by the
label: BODY

text: Local Administrative Authority (LAA).  Coordination of test notices will benefit the purveyor’s
label: BODY

text: customers.  The customer may have assemblies within his premises that are not relied upon by the
label: BODY

text: purveyor for the protection of the distribution system.  The cost for testing may be reduced, if the
label: BODY

text: customer arranges to have all assemblies on the property (premises isolation and fixture protection)
label: BODY

text: tested at one time.  Also, where purveyors rely on in-premises assemblies to protect the public water
label: BODY

text: system, the annual test reports required by the purveyor may be used to show compliance with the
label: BODY

text: Uniform Plumbing Code.
label: BODY

text: When coordinating test notices with the test notices issued by the LAA, the purveyor's testing letter
label: BODY

text: to the customer should clearly state that the:
label: BODY

text: Customer is to return test reports to the purveyor only for the assemblies specified;
label: BODY

text: Other assemblies owned by the customer should be tested to comply with the Uniform
label: BODY

text: Plumbing Code; and
label: BODY

text: If applicable, test reports submitted to the purveyor may also be used to comply with the
label: BODY

text: Uniform Plumbing Code testing requirements.
label: BODY

text: For combined programs (see Section 6.2.2), the coordination may include a provision for the
label: BODY

text: purveyor to collect test report forms for all assemblies within the property lines of the customer's
label: BODY

text: premises.
label: BODY

text: Regardless of the level of coordination with the LAA, the purveyor may receive completed test
label: BODY

text: reports for assemblies not on the purveyor's list (i.e., not relied upon by the purveyor to protect the
label: BODY

text: public water system.  For many purveyors it is preferable for the purveyor just to return the reports
label: BODY

text: to the customer, rather than take on the responsibility for forwarding them to the appropriate Local
label: BODY

text: Administrative Authority.  This is especially true for purveyors who coordinate with many LAAs.
label: BODY

text: When returning the report forms to customers, the purveyor should advise the customer of the
label: BODY

text: correct LAA to mail the form to.
label: BODY

text: Sample notification letters are provided in Appendix D.  Additional samples of letter and forms may
label: BODY

text: be found in referenced publications listed in Appendix F.
label: BODY

text: 7.4.1 Approved Backflow Assembly Testers
label: H4

text: A DOH-certified backflow assembly tester (BAT) must conduct all field tests of assemblies relied
label: BODY

text: upon by the purveyor to protect the water system.  The public listing of certified testers should be
label: BODY

text: available from the DOH Office of Drinking Water website in the future.  The website address is:
label: BODY

text: http://www.doh.wa.gov/ehp/dw
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 111
label: BODY

text: Purveyors should maintain a list of local certified assembly testers, so that the CCC Program
label: BODY

text: Manager:
label: BODY

text: Can verify the tester's certification status when checking completed test reports; and
label: BODY

text: May provide the list to customers along with the testing notice.
label: BODY

text: In addition to DOH BAT certification, purveyors may specify additional conditions that must be
label: BODY

text: met by BATs who want to provide testing in the purveyor’s service area.  These conditions may
label: BODY

text: specify that the BAT must:
label: BODY

text: Also be certified as a CCS;
label: BODY

text: Have a local business license;
label: BODY

text: Be a registered contractor (issued by Washington State Department of Labor and Industries
label: BODY

text: [L&I]); and
label: BODY

text: Use purveyor-approved testing equipment and show proof of a recent verification of test
label: BODY

text: equipment accuracy and calibration (if needed).
label: BODY

text: The Local Administrative Authority may also enforce minimum qualifications for BATs.  The
label: BODY

text: Uniform Plumbing Code amendments in Washington require assemblies to be tested by a DOH-
label: BODY

text: certified BAT (See WAC 51-46-0603.3.2).
label: BODY

text: WAC 246-290-490 and the Uniform Plumbing Code (amended for Washington) both require DOH
label: BODY

text: BAT certification.  However, purveyors need to be aware that additional certifications and/or
label: BODY

text: registrations may be required for persons providing backflow assembly installation, maintenance
label: BODY

text: and/or repair services.  As mentioned in Chapter 3, RCW 18.106 (enforced by L&I) establishes
label: BODY

text: minimum standards for persons installing, repairing, and/or replacing backflow prevention
label: BODY

text: assemblies within buildings.
label: BODY

text: Under this RCW, only licensed plumbers can install, maintain, repair, and/or replace backflow
label: BODY

text: assemblies within buildings.  BATs who also hold a specialty plumber certification from L&I may
label: BODY

text: test and repair assemblies within buildings.  In addition, RCW 18.27 establishes the requirements
label: BODY

text: for contractor registration, and some BATs may be required to also be registered contractors.  Thus,
label: BODY

text: multiple statutes/regulations may apply to persons working on assemblies in the purveyor’s service
label: BODY

text: area, depending on where the assemblies are located (within building vs. outside a building), and
label: BODY

text: whether services in addition to testing are provided.  Purveyors must check on the certification
label: BODY

text: status of BATs to comply with WAC 246-290-490.  However, L&I does not expect purveyors to
label: BODY

text: “police” or enforce contractor registration and/or plumber certification requirements.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 112
label: BODY

text: Current DOH tester certification is limited to demonstrating a minimum level of knowledge in
label: BODY

text: assembly field test procedures and installation requirements.  BAT certification doesn’t certify that
label: BODY

text: an individual can properly install and/or repair an assembly.  BATs who hold the specialty plumber
label: BODY

text: certification issued by L&I have successfully passed a written exam on assembly repair, in addition
label: BODY

text: to the BAT written and hands-on exam.
label: BODY

text: 7.4.2 Quality Assurance Program
label: H4

text: WAC 246-290-490 requires purveyors to develop a testing quality assurance/quality control
label: BODY

text: program.  This program must:
label: BODY

text: Document that test reports are submitted by DOH-certified testers;
label: BODY

text: Document the type of test kit used, serial number, and that the test kit has been verified for
label: BODY

text: accuracy within the last year and calibrated if necessary (some test kits can’t be re-
label: BODY

text: calibrated),
label: BODY

text: Specify the minimum content of test reports (to be acceptable to the purveyor) and establish
label: BODY

text: procedures for test report review; and
label: BODY

text: Establish a timeframe for completed test reports to be submitted to the purveyor (e.g., within
label: BODY

text: 10 working days from the date the test was performed).
label: BODY

text: Most large purveyors maintain much of this tester quality assurance information in their CCC
label: BODY

text: Program databases.  Program Managers that have this tester information readily available can more
label: BODY

text: effectively and efficiently administer their CCC programs.  For example, some systems enter the
label: BODY

text: certification numbers of testers into their CCC databases, so that any test reports submitted by non-
label: BODY

text: certified testers will automatically be rejected.
label: BODY

text: To comply with the quality assurance/quality control requirement, purveyors of small systems may
label: BODY

text: rely upon information provided by another nearby utility (i.e., larger) that has an established quality
label: BODY

text: assurance program.  This could include proof of test kit accuracy verification and calibration and the
label: BODY

text: list of approved testers.
label: BODY

text: Although small water system CCC Program Managers may conduct the initial reviews of test
label: BODY

text: reports for completeness, they may not have the training to assess the details in the report.  The test
label: BODY

text: report details may show that:
label: BODY

text: An assembly is wearing out and needs to be repaired or replaced; and
label: BODY

text: The BAT improperly tested the assembly or falsified the test results.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 113
label: BODY

text: The purveyor's CCS (either on staff or contract) should have the training and experience to
label: BODY

text: review test reports for quality assurance purposes.  The reviews should be made at least annually,
label: BODY

text: and preferably more often, if previous reviews show problems (e.g., questionable BAT
label: BODY

text: performance).
label: BODY

text: The purveyor's cross-connection control specialist
label: BODY

text: should report any questionable
label: BODY

text: backflow assembly tester performance
label: BODY

text: to Washington State Department of Health
label: BODY

text: Operator Certification Program.
label: BODY

text: Enforcement Procedures
label: BODY

text: When the purveyor provides good public education material on cross-connection control to
label: BODY

text: customers, 99 percent of the customers will voluntarily comply with the purveyor's requirements.
label: BODY

text: For the other one percent, from the very start of the CCC program, the purveyor should anticipate
label: BODY

text: the need to take some form of corrective or enforcement action against non-complying customers.
label: BODY

text: Purveyors should be pro-active and establish their enforcement policies before any
label: BODY

text: enforcement action is required.  The purveyor's management staff and lawyer should be involved
label: BODY

text: in establishing the enforcement policy.  The policy lays out in detail the enforcement procedures to
label: BODY

text: be followed by the CCC Program Manager.
label: BODY

text: The purveyor’s enforcement procedures should address the following:
label: BODY

text: The number of subsequent notices to be sent (after the initial notice), before the purveyor
label: BODY

text: takes an enforcement action;
label: BODY

text: The time interval between notices;
label: BODY

text: Use of registered mail for subsequent notices;
label: BODY

text: The wording of notices (e.g., polite reminder for the second notice, and an ultimatum for the
label: BODY

text: final notice);
label: BODY

text: For in-premises assemblies, when to inform the Local Administrative Authority of the
label: BODY

text: problem;
label: BODY

text: When to notify the purveyor's management, and/or lawyer;
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 114
label: BODY

text: An appeal process; and
label: BODY

text: Which enforcement procedure to take for the various assessed “degrees of hazard.”
label: BODY

text: Figure 5 shows an example enforcement procedure.  Examples of enforcement notices are included
label: BODY

text: in Appendix D.
label: BODY

text: Purveyors need to be aware that the failure of an assembly to pass the initial or annual field test
label: BODY

text: doesn’t establish for certain that the assembly will fail to prevent backflow.  Failure may only
label: BODY

text: indicate that the desired level of reliability is not present.  Thus, when laying out enforcement
label: BODY

text: procedures, purveyors should make the enforcement action appropriate for the hazard posed.  DOH
label: BODY

text: has developed guidance regarding when purveyors should shut-off water and when they should use
label: BODY

text: other enforcement tools to protect the public water supply.
label: BODY

text: Shutting off the supply of water to a customer may cause
label: BODY

text: a health hazard and/or a financial loss.
label: BODY

text: Purveyors should have enforcement tools other than
label: BODY

text: water shut-off also available, such as installing or testing
label: BODY

text: the backflow preventer and billing the customer.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: customer (i.e., shuts off
label: BODY

text: water)
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 116
label: BODY

text: Record-Keeping and Reporting Requirements
label: BODY

text: Purveyors should keep all original records (correspondence, plans, etc.) in the water system's
label: BODY

text: files.  If contractors (i.e., CCSs) are used, the contractors should give the original records to the
label: BODY

text: water system and retain photocopies of the records in their own files.
label: BODY

text: If a contract cross-connection control specialist
label: BODY

text: or manager's employment ceases,
label: BODY

text: the purveyor may have difficulty recovering files
label: BODY

text: and records that are retained at any location other
label: BODY

text: than the purveyor's office files.
label: BODY

text: Original records should always be kept in the
label: BODY

text: water system’s files.
label: BODY

text: 7.6.1 Record of Risk Assessment
label: HH2

text: For each customer, the purveyor shall maintain a record of the initial risk assessment and
label: BODY

text: subsequent re-assessments, in the form of a completed:
label: BODY

text: Water Use Questionnaire (i.e., for residential customers); and/or
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Survey Report.
label: BODY

text: Samples of each may be found in Appendix D, Sample Forms.
label: BODY

text: For risk management reasons, the purveyor should retain both the initial form, plus the latest re-
label: BODY

text: assessment, because the forms:
label: BODY

text: Document that the purveyor has complied with the DOH requirement to evaluate new and
label: BODY

text: existing customers to assess the degree of hazard;
label: BODY

text: Provide a historical perspective that may be needed by a new CCS, Program Manager, or
label: BODY

text: supervisor;
label: BODY

text: Contain a signed statement from the customer or customer's CCS about his water use, and/or
label: BODY

text: assessed degree of hazard; and
label: BODY

text: Contain information useful for investigating a backflow incident.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 117
label: BODY

text: For each connection where the purveyor requires a backflow preventer to protect the public water
label: BODY

text: system, records should be kept indicating the assessed hazard level of the connection and the
label: BODY

text: required backflow preventer.
label: BODY

text: 7.6.2 Inventory of Backflow Preventers
label: H4

text: It is critical for purveyors to keep accurate records on backflow preventers that protect the public
label: BODY

text: water system from contamination.  These may include both purveyor-owned assemblies and
label: BODY

text: customer-owned assemblies.
label: BODY

text: WAC 246-290-490 (3)(j)(ii) lists the minimum backflow preventer inventory information that
label: BODY

text: purveyors must keep on file.  For each customer where an approved BPA or AG is required by the
label: BODY

text: purveyor to protect its distribution system, and for approved backflow preventers installed at
label: BODY

text: purveyor- owned facilities, the inventory should include {per WAC 246-290-490(3), Element 9}:
label: BODY

text: Information on the exact location of the backflow preventer or AG (adequate details to find
label: BODY

text: the backflow preventers);
label: BODY

text: Description of hazard isolated (either the category of premises such as a medical clinic or
label: BODY

text: the fixture such as a boiler);
label: BODY

text: Type, size, make, model, serial number and installation date of backflow assembly, or AG
label: BODY

text: details including installation date; and
label: BODY

text: Size, make, model and installation date of AVBs used on irrigation systems.
label: BODY

text: 7.6.3 Inventory of Backflow Preventer Test/Inspection Reports
label: H4

text: For each assembly field test or AG inspection, the test report inventory information should include
label: BODY

text: at a minimum:
label: BODY

text: The name and certification number of the BAT performing each test or inspection;
label: BODY

text: Test results (pass/fail and actual readings) or inspection results; and
label: BODY

text: Repair/re-plumbing history.
label: BODY

text: Appendix D contains a sample file record form that includes the inventory of backflow preventers
label: BODY

text: and test reports.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 118
label: BODY

text: 7.6.4 Correspondence
label: H4

text: The purveyor should maintain copies of all correspondence with customers for a period of at least
label: BODY

text: five years.  The purveyor should also maintain, as a permanent record, the:
label: BODY

text: Most current service agreement with each customer; and
label: BODY

text: Notification to the customer to install a backflow preventer(s) to protect the public water
label: BODY

text: system from contamination.
label: BODY

text: All correspondence with DOH and the Local Administrative Authority should be maintained for at
label: BODY

text: least five years.
label: BODY

text: 7.6.5 Washington State Department of Health Reporting Requirements
label: H4

text: Purveyors are required to meet the reporting requirements of WAC 246-290-490.  These
label: BODY

text: requirements include completing the CCC Annual Summary Report (ASR) forms and making them
label: BODY

text: available to DOH on request.
label: BODY

text: Copies of the current forms (there are three) are available from DOH.  However, DOH will send
label: BODY

text: purveyors the forms and ask them to submit to DOH information on their CCC programs.  These
label: BODY

text: forms comprise the ASR forms.  The forms provide a means for purveyors to report on the:
label: BODY

text: Status of their written program plans;
label: BODY

text: Progress of their implementation activities; and
label: BODY

text: Exceptions they have granted and the justifications for granting of the exemptions.
label: BODY

text: An example set of ASR forms for 2002 is provided in Appendix E.
label: BODY

text: 7.6.6 Spreadsheets and Computer Database Software
label: H4

text: For the number of assemblies expected in most small water systems, the records of the inventory of
label: BODY

text: assemblies, test reports, local BATs, etc., can be kept on a spreadsheet, either manually (i.e., on
label: BODY

text: paper), or using commercially available computer software (such as Excel or Access).
label: BODY

text: Proprietary computer database software programs are also available.  These have been developed
label: BODY

text: specifically to aid purveyors in the management of their CCC programs.  A list of some of the
label: BODY

text: companies supplying computer software for managing CCC programs is provided in Appendix F.
label: BODY

text: Regardless of the type of record-keeping system used, the system must be able to provide the data to
label: BODY

text: answer the questions that appear on the CCC ASR forms.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 119
label: BODY

text: 7.6.7 Backflow Incident Reports
label: H4

text: Element 9 of WAC 246-290-490 requires purveyors to maintain CCC records and complete annual
label: BODY

text: summary reports and backflow incident reports.  Backflow incidents are to be reported on a form
label: BODY

text: acceptable to DOH.  A sample backflow incident report form developed by the PNWS-AWWA
label: BODY

text: CCC Committee is provided in Appendix D.  Additional supporting information, photos, laboratory
label: BODY

text: analyses, etc., may be attached to the report.
label: BODY

text: The PNWS-AWWA form is currently acceptable to DOH.  In the future, DOH may develop a
label: BODY

text: Backflow Incident Report Form that is designed for computer entry and future web-based
label: BODY

text: submission.
label: BODY

text: If a backflow incident occurs, check with DOH to ensure that your system has the most current form
label: BODY

text: to report the details of the incident.
label: BODY

text: Public Education
label: BODY

text: Public education is a key part of the purveyor's CCC program.  Through public education programs,
label: BODY

text: purveyors inform customers of:
label: BODY

text: The public health impacts of potential cross-connection hazards;
label: BODY

text: Their responsibility to protect the public water system from contamination;
label: BODY

text: The purveyor's requirement to comply with the DOH regulations; and
label: BODY

text: The purveyor's policies (i.e., conditions of service).
label: BODY

text: 7.7.1 Type of Effort
label: H4

text: Element 8 of WAC 246-290-490 requires purveyors to educate their customers on cross-connection
label: BODY

text: control.  For small water systems, the recommended public education methods are:
label: BODY

text: Water bill inserts (brochures);
label: BODY

text: Consumer Confidence Reports;
label: BODY

text: For new customers, information on service policy distributed with application for service;
label: BODY

text: and
label: BODY

text: Reliance on general public education materials developed by regional and national technical
label: BODY

text: groups (PNWS-AWWA CCC Committee, SRC4, The Group, and other technical
label: BODY

text: organizations) and/or by large utilities.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 120
label: BODY

text: Appendix F lists organizations that have public education brochures available for use by small water
label: BODY

text: systems.  Due to limited resources, small water systems are encouraged to use the education
label: BODY

text: materials (brochures, postcards, newsletters, etc.) already developed by other organizations and/or
label: BODY

text: systems.  There is no need for a small water system to “re-invent the wheel,” when so many
label: BODY

text: excellent public education materials on cross-connection control are readily available.
label: BODY

text: 7.7.2 Frequency
label: H4

text: The annual Consumer Confidence Report provides an excellent means for purveyors to routinely
label: BODY

text: inform their customers about the status of their CCC programs.  The purveyor’s Consumer
label: BODY

text: Confidence Report should include a brief statement about the:
label: BODY

text: Purveyor's operation of a CCC program; and
label: BODY

text: Customer's responsibility to protect his/her plumbing system and the purveyor's distribution
label: BODY

text: system from contamination via cross connections.
label: BODY

text: Education brochures should be distributed every two to three years.
label: BODY

text: Backflow Incident Response Plan
label: BODY

text: A purveyor’s failure to properly respond to a backflow incident may:
label: BODY

text: Significantly increase the number of persons exposed to a health hazard;
label: BODY

text: Increase the purveyor's effort (cost) to contain a contaminant and clean the contaminant
label: BODY

text: from the distribution system; and
label: BODY

text: Expose the purveyor to increased liability from a claim for punitive damages for negligence.
label: BODY

text: Don't wait until a backflow incident occurs to
label: BODY

text: develop an incident response plan!
label: BODY

text: Appendix C contains a sample Backflow Incident Response Plan for a small water system.
label: BODY

text: Purveyors should consult with the Local Administrative Authorities and Local Health jurisdiction
label: BODY

text: when developing the response plan to identify communication lines, responsibilities, etc.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 121
label: BODY

text: Special Requirements for Reclaimed or Greywater
label: BODY

text: Reclaimed Water
label: BODY

text: Reclaimed water systems use wastewater treatment effluent that has been adequately and reliably
label: BODY

text: treated, so that it is suitable for a direct beneficial use or a controlled use that would not otherwise
label: BODY

text: occur.  The utilization of reclaimed water is referred to as water reuse.
label: BODY

text: A dual distribution system supplies two grades of water to the same service area.  One of the
label: BODY

text: supplies is potable water (acceptable for drinking), and the other supply is non-potable (not
label: BODY

text: acceptable for drinking).  Reclaimed wastewater is typically categorized into four classes of quality
label: BODY

text: (A through D).   The classes range from the highest quality (A) for use in irrigation of open access
label: BODY

text: areas (golf courses, parks, schoolyard), non-restricted recreational impoundments, toilet flushing in
label: BODY

text: commercial and industrial buildings, and fire protection systems to the lowest quality (D) for use in
label: BODY

text: irrigation of non-food crops (e.g., tree farms) and sewer flushing.
label: BODY

text: All classes of reclaimed water shall be considered a high health hazard.  This is because the
label: BODY

text: degree of treatment of reclaimed water is far less than the minimum requirements for the production
label: BODY

text: of potable water.  Even the Class A reclaimed water criteria allow water that could contain
label: BODY

text: pathogens (disease-causing organisms).
label: BODY

text: Due to the high health hazard, Department of Ecology standards prohibit direct connections
label: BODY

text: between reclaimed water systems and potable water systems.  Further details can be found in the
label: BODY

text: Water Reclamation and Reuse Standards jointly published by the Department of Ecology and
label: BODY

text: Washington State Department of Health (Ecology publication number 97-23).
label: BODY

text: For connections where both reclaimed water and potable water are provided on the
label: BODY

text: customer's premises, per Table 9 of WAC 246-290-490, premises isolation at the water meter
label: BODY

text: by an approved AG or reduced-pressure backflow assembly is required.  The requirement is
label: BODY

text: based on the assessment of a high health hazard of the reclaimed water, and the high probability that
label: BODY

text: a connection could be made between the potable and non-potable systems (e.g., in the event of the
label: BODY

text: disruption of the reclaimed water supply).  Dual distribution systems operated by the water utility
label: BODY

text: shall adhere to the requirement for premises isolation.
label: BODY

text: Where the customer uses potable water to supplement a reclaimed water system, the water must be
label: BODY

text: supplied through an approved AG inspected by a certified BAT at least annually.
label: BODY

text: Greywater
label: BODY

text: A greywater system uses the effluent from untreated household wastewater that hasn’t come into
label: BODY

text: contact with toilet waste or food processing waste.  Greywater includes wastewater from bathtubs,
label: BODY

text: showers, bathroom sinks, clothes washing machines and laundry tubs.  Greywater excludes
label: BODY

text: wastewater from kitchen sinks and dishwashers.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 7
label: BODY

text: Page 122
label: BODY

text: A greywater system may supply water for underground landscape irrigation.  The system typically
label: BODY

text: contains one or more holding tanks, an underground distribution system connected to perforated
label: BODY

text: irrigation pipe, an overflow gravity drain to the sewer or septic system, and a pump.
label: BODY

text: All greywater systems shall be considered a high health hazard.  This is due to the potential for
label: BODY

text: the greywater to contain human pathogens, even if connections to toilets are excluded (e.g., bath
label: BODY

text: water may contain human fecal material).
label: BODY

text: Premises isolation at the water meter by an approved AG or reduced-pressure backflow assembly is
label: BODY

text: required.  The requirement is based on the:
label: BODY

text: Assessment of a high health hazard of the greywater; and
label: BODY

text: Probability that a connection could be made between the potable water system and
label: BODY

text: greywater system to supplement the greywater supply.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004

text: Washington Administrative Code 246-290-490
label: BODY

text: This section contains Washington State Department of Health drinking water regulations relating
label: BODY

text: to cross-connection control, WAC 246-290-490.  Section 490 has been extracted from WAC
label: BODY

text: 246-290, the Group A Drinking Water Regulations.  These regulations first became effective in
label: BODY

text: April 1999.  To enhance the completeness of the regulations, definitions, abbreviations and
label: BODY

text: acronyms relating to cross connections which have been extracted from WAC 246-290-010.
label: BODY

text: 8.2.1  Definitions Related to Cross-Connection Control
label: H4

text: "Approved air gap" means a physical separation between the free-flowing end of a potable
label: BODY

text: water supply pipeline and the overflow rim of an open or non-pressurized receiving vessel.  To
label: BODY

text: be an air gap approved by the department, the separation must be at least:
label: BODY

text: Twice the diameter of the supply piping measured vertically from the overflow rim of the
label: BODY

text: receiving vessel, and in no case be less than one inch, when unaffected by vertical surfaces
label: BODY

text: (sidewalls); and
label: BODY

text: • Three times the diameter of the supply piping, if the horizontal distance between the
label: BODY

text: supply pipe and a vertical surface (sidewall) is less than or equal to three times the
label: BODY

text: diameter of the supply pipe, or if the horizontal distance between the supply pipe and
label: BODY

text: intersecting vertical surfaces (sidewalls) is less than or equal to four times the diameter of
label: BODY

text: the supply pipe and in no case less than one and one-half inches.
label: BODY

text: "Approved atmospheric vacuum breaker" means an AVB of make, model, and size that is
label: BODY

text: approved by the department.  *AVBs that appear on the current approved backflow prevention
label: BODY

text: assemblies list developed by the University of Southern California Foundation for
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control and Hydraulic Research or that are listed or approved by other
label: BODY

text: nationally recognized testing agencies (such as IAPMO, ANSI, or UL) acceptable to the local
label: BODY

text: administrative authority are considered approved by the department.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 8
label: BODY

text: Page 125
label: BODY

text: "Approved backflow preventer" means an approved air gap, an approved backflow prevention
label: BODY

text: assembly, or an approved AVB.  The terms "approved backflow preventer," "approved air gap,"
label: BODY

text: or "approved backflow prevention assembly" refer only to those approved backflow preventers
label: BODY

text: relied upon by the purveyor for the protection of the public water system.  The requirements of
label: BODY

text: WAC 246-290-490 do not apply to backflow preventers installed for other purposes.
label: BODY

text: "Approved backflow prevention assembly" means an RPBA, RPDA, DCVA, DCDA, PVBA,
label: BODY

text: or SVBA of make, model, and size that is approved by the department.  Assemblies that appear
label: BODY

text: on the current approved backflow prevention assemblies list developed by the University of
label: BODY

text: Southern California Foundation for Cross-Connection Control and Hydraulic Research or other
label: BODY

text: entity acceptable to the department are considered approved by the department.
label: BODY

text: "Backflow" means the undesirable reversal of flow of water or other substances through a cross
label: BODY

text: connection into the public water system or consumer's potable water system.
label: BODY

text: "Backflow assembly tester" means a person holding a valid BAT certificate issued in
label: BODY

text: accordance with chapter 246-292 WAC.
label: BODY

text: "Backpressure" means a pressure (caused by a pump, elevated tank or piping, boiler, or other
label: BODY

text: means) on the consumer's side of the service connection that is greater than the pressure provided
label: BODY

text: by the public water system and which may cause backflow.
label: BODY

text: "Backsiphonage" means backflow due to a reduction in system pressure in the purveyor's
label: BODY

text: distribution system and/or consumer's water system.
label: BODY

text: "Combination fire protection system" means a fire sprinkler system that:
label: BODY

text: Is supplied only by the purveyor's water;
label: BODY

text: Does not have a fire department pumper connection; and
label: BODY

text: Is constructed of approved potable water piping and materials that serve both the fire
label: BODY

text: sprinkler system and the consumer's potable water system.
label: BODY

text: "Consumer" means any person receiving water from a public water system from either the
label: BODY

text: meter, or the point where the service line connects with the distribution system if no meter is
label: BODY

text: present.  For purposes of cross-connection control, "consumer" means the owner or operator of a
label: BODY

text: water system connected to a public water system through a service connection.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 8
label: BODY

text: Page 126
label: BODY

text: "Consumer's water system," as used in WAC 246-290-490, means any potable and/or
label: BODY

text: industrial water system that begins at the point of delivery from the public water system and is
label: BODY

text: located on the consumer's premises.  The consumer's water system includes all auxiliary sources
label: BODY

text: of supply, storage, treatment, and distribution facilities, piping, plumbing, and fixtures under the
label: BODY

text: control of the consumer.
label: BODY

text: "Cross connection" means any actual or potential physical connection between a public water
label: BODY

text: system or the consumer's water system and any source of nonpotable liquid, solid, or gas that
label: BODY

text: could contaminate the potable water supply by backflow.
label: BODY

text: "Cross-connection control program" means the administrative and technical procedures the
label: BODY

text: purveyor implements to protect the public water system from contamination via cross
label: BODY

text: connections as required in WAC 246-290-490.
label: BODY

text: "Cross-connection control specialist" means a person holding a valid CCS certificate issued in
label: BODY

text: accordance with chapter 246-292 WAC.
label: BODY

text: "Cross-connection control summary report" means the annual report that describes the status
label: BODY

text: of the purveyor's cross-connection control program.
label: BODY

text: "Flow-through fire protection system" means a fire sprinkler system that:
label: BODY

text: • Is supplied only by the purveyor's water;
label: BODY

text: • Does not have a fire department pumper connection;
label: BODY

text: • Is constructed of approved potable water piping and materials to which sprinkler heads
label: BODY

text: are attached; and
label: BODY

text: • Terminates at a connection to a toilet or other plumbing fixture to prevent the water from
label: BODY

text: becoming stagnant.
label: BODY

text: "High health cross-connection hazard" means a cross connection which could impair the
label: BODY

text: quality of potable water and create an actual public health hazard through poisoning or spread of
label: BODY

text: disease by sewage, industrial liquids or waste.
label: BODY

text: "In-premises protection" means a method of protecting the health of consumers served by the
label: BODY

text: consumer's potable water system, located within the property lines of the consumer's premises by
label: BODY

text: the installation of an approved air gap or backflow prevention assembly at the point of hazard,
label: BODY

text: which is generally a plumbing fixture.
label: BODY

text: "Local administrative authority" means the local official, board, department, or agency
label: BODY

text: authorized to administer and enforce the provisions of the Uniform Plumbing Code as adopted
label: BODY

text: under chapter 19.27 RCW.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 8
label: BODY

text: Page 127
label: BODY

text: "Low health cross-connection hazard" means a cross connection that could cause an
label: BODY

text: impairment of the quality of potable water to a degree that does not create a hazard to the public
label: BODY

text: health, but does adversely and unreasonably affect the aesthetic qualities of such potable waters
label: BODY

text: for domestic use.
label: BODY

text: “Premises Isolation” means a method of protecting a public water system by installation of
label: BODY

text: approved air gaps or approved backflow prevention assemblies at or near the service connection
label: BODY

text: or alternative location acceptable to the purveyor to isolate the consumer’s water system from the
label: BODY

text: purveyor’s distribution system.
label: BODY

text: "Reclaimed water" means effluent derived in any part from sewage from a wastewater
label: BODY

text: treatment system that has been adequately and reliably treated, so that as a result of that
label: BODY

text: treatment, it is suitable for beneficial use or a controlled use that would not otherwise occur, and
label: BODY

text: it is no longer considered wastewater.
label: BODY

text: "Unapproved auxiliary water supply" means a water supply (other than the purveyor's water
label: BODY

text: supply) on or available to the consumer's premises that is either not approved for human
label: BODY

text: consumption by the health agency having jurisdiction or is not otherwise acceptable to the
label: BODY

text: purveyor.
label: BODY

text: "Uniform Plumbing Code" means the code adopted under RCW 19.27.031(4) and amended
label: BODY

text: under chapter 51-46 WAC.  This code establishes statewide minimum plumbing standards
label: BODY

text: applicable within the property lines of the consumer's premises.
label: BODY

text: "Used water" means water which has left the control of the purveyor.
