text: 8.2.2 WAC 246-290-490  Cross-Connection Control.
label: H4

text: (1) Applicability, purpose, and responsibility.
label: BODY

text: (a) All community water systems shall comply with the cross-connection control
label: BODY

text: requirements specified in this section.
label: BODY

text: (b) All non-community water systems shall apply the principles and provisions of this
label: BODY

text: section, including subsection (4)(b) of this section, as applicable to protect the public
label: BODY

text: water system from contamination via cross connections.  Non-community systems that
label: BODY

text: comply with subsection (4)(b) of this section and the provisions of WAC 51-46-0603 of
label: BODY

text: the UPC (which addresses the installation of backflow preventers at points of water use
label: BODY

text: within the potable water system) shall be considered in compliance with the
label: BODY

text: requirements of this section.
label: BODY

text: (c) The purpose of the purveyor's cross-connection control program shall be to protect the
label: BODY

text: public water system, as defined in WAC 246-290-010, from contamination via cross
label: BODY

text: connections.
label: BODY

text: (d) The purveyor's responsibility for cross-connection control shall begin at the water supply
label: BODY

text: source, include all the public water treatment, storage, and distribution facilities, and end
label: BODY

text: at the point of delivery to the consumer's water system, which begins at the downstream
label: BODY

text: end of the service connection or water meter located on the public right-of-way or
label: BODY

text: utility-held easement.
label: BODY

text: (e) Under the provisions of this section, purveyors are not responsible for eliminating or
label: BODY

text: controlling cross connections within the consumer's water system.  Under chapter 19.27
label: BODY

text: RCW, the responsibility for cross-connection control within the consumer's water
label: BODY

text: system, i.e., within the property lines of the consumer's premises, falls under the
label: BODY

text: jurisdiction of the local administrative authority.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 8
label: BODY

text: Page 129
label: BODY

text: (2) General program requirements.
label: BODY

text: (a) The purveyor shall develop and implement a cross-connection control program that
label: BODY

text: meets the requirements of this section, but may establish a more stringent program
label: BODY

text: through local ordinances, resolutions, codes, bylaws, or operating rules.
label: BODY

text: (b) Purveyors shall ensure that good engineering and public health protection practices are
label: BODY

text: used in the development and implementation of cross-connection control programs.
label: BODY

text: Department publications and the most recently published editions of references, such as,
label: BODY

text: but not limited to, those listed below, may be used as guidance for cross-connection
label: BODY

text: program development and implementation:
label: BODY

text: (i) Manual of Cross-Connection Control published by the Foundation for
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control and Hydraulic Research, University of Southern California
label: BODY

text: (USC Manual); or
label: BODY

text: (ii) Cross-Connection Control Manual, Accepted Procedure and Practice published by
label: BODY

text: the Pacific Northwest Section of the American Water Works Association
label: BODY

text: (PNWS-AWWA Manual).
label: BODY

text: (c) The purveyor may implement the cross-connection control program, or any portion
label: BODY

text: thereof, directly or by means of a contract with another agency or party acceptable to the
label: BODY

text: department.
label: BODY

text: (d) The purveyor shall coordinate with the local administrative authority in all matters
label: BODY

text: concerning cross-connection control.  The purveyor shall document and describe such
label: BODY

text: coordination, including delineation of responsibilities, in the written cross-connection
label: BODY

text: control program required in (e) of this subsection.
label: BODY

text: (e) The purveyor shall include a written description of the cross-connection control program
label: BODY

text: in the water system plan required under WAC 246-290-100 or the small water system
label: BODY

text: management program required under WAC 246-290-105.  The cross-connection control
label: BODY

text: program shall include the minimum program elements described in subsection (3) of this
label: BODY

text: section.
label: BODY

text: (f) The purveyor shall ensure that cross connections between the distribution system and a
label: BODY

text: consumer's water system are eliminated or controlled by the installation of an approved
label: BODY

text: backflow preventer commensurate with the degree of hazard.  This can be accomplished
label: BODY

text: by implementation of a cross-connection program that relies on:
label: BODY

text: (i) Premises isolation as defined in WAC 246-290-010; or
label: BODY

text: (ii) Premises isolation and in-premises protection as defined in WAC 246-290-010.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 8
label: BODY

text: Page 130
label: BODY

text: (g) Purveyors with cross-connection control programs that rely both on premises isolation
label: BODY

text: and in-premises protection:
label: BODY

text: (i) Shall comply with the premises isolation requirements specified in subsection (4)(b)
label: BODY

text: of this section; and
label: BODY

text: (ii) May reduce premises isolation requirements and rely on in-premises protection for
label: BODY

text: premises other than the type not addressed in subsection (4)(b) of this section, if the
label: BODY

text: conditions in (h) of this subsection are met.
label: BODY

text: (h) Purveyors may rely on in-premises protection only when the following conditions are
label: BODY

text: met:
label: BODY

text: (i) The in-premises backflow preventers provide a level of protection commensurate
label: BODY

text: with the purveyor's assessed degree of hazard;
label: BODY

text: (ii) Backflow preventers which provide the in-premises backflow protection meet the
label: BODY

text: definition of approved backflow preventers as described in WAC 246-290-010;
label: BODY

text: (iii)The approved backflow preventers are installed, inspected, tested (if applicable),
label: BODY

text: maintained, and repaired in accordance with subsections (6) and (7) of this section;
label: BODY

text: (iv) Records of such backflow preventers are maintained in accordance with subsections
label: BODY

text: (3)(j) and (8) of this section; and
label: BODY

text: (v) The purveyor has reasonable access to the consumer's premises to conduct an initial
label: BODY

text: hazard evaluation and periodic reevaluations to determine whether the in-premises
label: BODY

text: protection is adequate to protect the purveyor's distribution system.
label: BODY

text: (i) The purveyor shall take appropriate corrective action within its authority if:
label: BODY

text: (i) A cross connection exists that is not controlled commensurate to the degree of hazard
label: BODY

text: assessed by the purveyor; or
label: BODY

text: (ii) A consumer fails to comply with the purveyor's requirements regarding the
label: BODY

text: installation, inspection, testing, maintenance or repair of approved backflow
label: BODY

text: preventers required by this chapter.
label: BODY

text: (j) The purveyor's corrective action may include, but is not limited to:
label: BODY

text: (i) Denying or discontinuing water service to a consumer's premises until the
label: BODY

text: cross-connection hazard is eliminated or controlled to the satisfaction of the purveyor;
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 8
label: BODY

text: Page 131
label: BODY

text: (ii) Requiring the consumer to install an approved backflow preventer for premises
label: BODY

text: isolation commensurate with the degree of hazard; or
label: BODY

text: (iii)The purveyor installing an approved backflow preventer for premises isolation
label: BODY

text: commensurate with the degree of hazard.
label: BODY

text: (k) Purveyors denying or discontinuing water service to a consumer's premises for one or
label: BODY

text: more of the reasons listed in (i) of this subsection shall notify the local administrative
label: BODY

text: authority prior to taking such action except in the event of an emergency.
label: BODY

text: (l) The purveyor shall prohibit the intentional return of used water to the purveyor's
label: BODY

text: distribution system.  Such water would include, but is not limited to, water used for
label: BODY

text: heating, cooling, or other purposes within the consumer's water system.
label: BODY

text: (3) Minimum elements of a cross-connection control program.
label: BODY

text: (a) To be acceptable to the department, the purveyor's cross-connection control program
label: BODY

text: shall include the minimum elements identified in this subsection.
label: BODY

text: (b) Element 1:  The purveyor shall adopt a local ordinance, resolution, code, bylaw, or other
label: BODY

text: written legal instrument that:
label: BODY

text: (i) Establishes the purveyor's legal authority to implement a cross-connection control
label: BODY

text: program;
label: BODY

text: (ii) Describes the operating policies and technical provisions of the purveyor's
label: BODY

text: cross-connection control program; and
label: BODY

text: (iii)Describes the corrective actions used to ensure that consumers comply with the
label: BODY

text: purveyor's cross-connection control requirements.
label: BODY

text: (c) Element 2:  The purveyor shall develop and implement procedures and schedules for
label: BODY

text: evaluating new and existing service connections to assess the degree of hazard posed by
label: BODY

text: the consumer's premises to the purveyor's distribution system and notifying the
label: BODY

text: consumer within a reasonable time frame of the hazard evaluation results.  At a
label: BODY

text: minimum, the program shall meet the following:
label: BODY

text: (i) For new connections made on or after the effective date of these regulations,
label: BODY

text: procedures shall ensure that an initial evaluation is conducted before service is
label: BODY

text: provided;
label: BODY

text: (ii) For existing connections made prior to the effective date of these regulations,
label: BODY

text: procedures shall ensure that an initial evaluation is conducted in accordance with a
label: BODY

text: schedule acceptable to the department; and
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 8
label: BODY

text: Page 132
label: BODY

text: (iii)For all service connections, once an initial evaluation has been conducted, procedures
label: BODY

text: shall ensure that periodic reevaluations are conducted in accordance with a schedule
label: BODY

text: acceptable to the department and whenever there is a change in the use of the
label: BODY

text: premises.
label: BODY

text: (d) Element 3:  The purveyor shall develop and implement procedures and schedules for
label: BODY

text: ensuring that:
label: BODY

text: (i) Cross connections are eliminated whenever possible;
label: BODY

text: (ii) When cross connections cannot be eliminated, they are controlled by installation of
label: BODY

text: approved backflow preventers commensurate with the degree of hazard; and
label: BODY

text: (iii)Approved backflow preventers are installed in accordance with the requirements of
label: BODY

text: subsection (6) of this section.
label: BODY

text: (e) Element 4:  The purveyor shall ensure that personnel, including at least one person
label: BODY

text: certified as a CCS, are provided to develop and implement the cross-connection control
label: BODY

text: program.
label: BODY

text: (f) Element 5:  The purveyor shall develop and implement procedures to ensure that
label: BODY

text: approved backflow preventers are inspected and/or tested (as applicable) in accordance
label: BODY

text: with subsection (7) of this section.
label: BODY

text: (g) Element 6:  The purveyor shall develop and implement a backflow prevention assembly
label: BODY

text: testing quality control assurance program, including, but not limited to, documentation
label: BODY

text: of tester certification and test kit calibration, test report contents, and  time frames for
label: BODY

text: submitting completed test reports.
label: BODY

text: (h) Element 7:  The purveyor shall develop and implement (when appropriate) procedures
label: BODY

text: for responding to backflow incidents.
label: BODY

text: (i) Element 8:  The purveyor shall include information on cross-connection control in the
label: BODY

text: purveyor's existing program for educating consumers about water system operation.
label: BODY

text: Such a program may include periodic bill inserts, public service announcements,
label: BODY

text: pamphlet distribution, notification of new consumers and consumer confidence reports.
label: BODY

text: Element 9:  The purveyor shall develop and maintain cross-connection control records including,
label: BODY

text: but not limited to, the following:
label: BODY

text: (i) A master list of service connections and/or consumer's premises where the purveyor
label: BODY

text: relies upon approved backflow preventers to protect the public water system from
label: BODY

text: contamination, the assessed hazard level of each, and the required backflow
label: BODY

text: preventer(s);
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 8
label: BODY

text: Page 133
label: BODY

text: (ii) Inventory information on:
label: BODY

text: (A) Approved air gaps installed in lieu of approved assemblies including exact air gap
label: BODY

text: location, assessed degree of hazard, installation date, history of inspections,
label: BODY

text: inspection results, and person conducting inspections;
label: BODY

text: (B) Approved backflow assemblies including exact assembly location, assembly
label: BODY

text: description (type, manufacturer, model, size, and serial number), assessed degree
label: BODY

text: of hazard, installation date, history of inspections, tests and repairs, test results,
label: BODY

text: and person performing tests; and
label: BODY

text: (C) Approved AVBs used for irrigation system applications including location,
label: BODY

text: description (manufacturer, model, and size), installation date, history of
label: BODY

text: inspection(s), and person performing inspection(s).
label: BODY

text: (iii)Cross-connection program summary reports and backflow incident reports required
label: BODY

text: under subsection (8) of this section.
label: BODY

text: (k) Element 10:  Purveyors who distribute and/or have facilities that receive reclaimed water
label: BODY

text: within their water service area shall meet any additional cross-connection control
label: BODY

text: requirements imposed by the department under a permit issued in accordance with
label: BODY

text: chapter 90.46 RCW.

text: (c) Backflow protection for single-family residences.

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: (D) Boilers.
label: BODY

text: For example, the purveyor may accept an approved AVB on a residential irrigation

text: system, if the AVB is properly installed in accordance with the UPC.

text: (d) Backflow protection for fire protection systems.
label: BODY

text: (i) Backflow protection is not required for residential flow-through or combination fire
label: BODY

text: protection systems constructed of potable water piping and materials.
label: BODY

text: (ii) For service connections with fire protection systems other than flow-through or
label: BODY

text: combination systems, the purveyor shall ensure that backflow protection consistent
label: BODY

text: with WAC 51-46-0603 of the UPC is installed.  The UPC requires minimum
label: BODY

text: protection as follows:
label: BODY

text: (A) An RPBA or RPDA for fire protection systems with chemical addition or using
label: BODY

text: unapproved auxiliary water supply; and
label: BODY

text: (B) A DCVA or DCDA for all other fire protection systems.
label: BODY

text: (iii)For new connections made on or after the effective date of these regulations, the
label: BODY

text: purveyor shall ensure that backflow protection is installed before water service is
label: BODY

text: provided.

text: (ii) A repeated history of cross connections being established or reestablished; or
label: BODY

text: (iii)Cross-connection hazards are unavoidable or not correctable, such as, but not limited
label: BODY

text: to, tall buildings.
label: BODY

text: (5) Approved backflow preventers.
label: BODY

text: (a) The purveyor shall ensure that all backflow prevention assemblies relied upon by the
label: BODY

text: purveyor are models included on the current list of backflow prevention assemblies
label: BODY

text: approved for use in Washington state.  The current approved assemblies list is available
label: BODY

text: from the department upon request.
label: BODY

text: (b) The purveyor may rely on testable backflow prevention assemblies that are not currently
label: BODY

text: approved by the department, if the assemblies:
label: BODY

text: (i) Were included on the department and/or USC list of approved backflow prevention
label: BODY

text: assemblies at the time of installation;
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 8
label: BODY

text: Page 138
label: BODY

text: (ii) Have been properly maintained;
label: BODY

text: (iii)Are commensurate with the purveyor's assessed degree of hazard; and
label: BODY

text: (iv) Have been inspected and tested at least annually and have successfully passed the
label: BODY

text: annual tests.
label: BODY

text: (c) The purveyor shall ensure that an unlisted backflow prevention assembly is replaced by
label: BODY

text: an approved assembly commensurate with the degree of hazard, when the unlisted
label: BODY

text: assembly:
label: BODY

text: (i) Does not meet the conditions specified in (b)(i) through (iv) of this subsection;
label: BODY

text: (ii) Is moved; or
label: BODY

text: (iii)Cannot be repaired using spare parts from the original manufacturer.
label: BODY

text: (d) The purveyor shall ensure that AVBs meet the definition of approved atmospheric
label: BODY

text: vacuum breakers as described in WAC 246-290-010.
label: BODY

text: (6) Approved backflow preventer installation.
label: BODY

text: (a) The purveyor shall ensure that approved backflow preventers are installed in the
label: BODY

text: orientation for which they are approved (if applicable).
label: BODY

text: (b) The purveyor shall ensure that approved backflow preventers are installed in a manner
label: BODY

text: that:
label: BODY

text: (i) Facilitates their proper operation, maintenance, inspection, and/or in-line testing (as
label: BODY

text: applicable) using standard installation procedures acceptable to the department such
label: BODY

text: as those in the USC Manual or PNWS-AWWA Manual;
label: BODY

text: (ii) Ensures that the assembly will not become submerged due to weather-related
label: BODY

text: conditions such as flooding; and
label: BODY

text: (iii)Ensures compliance with all applicable safety regulations.
label: BODY

text: (c) The purveyor shall ensure that approved backflow assemblies for premises isolation are
label: BODY

text: installed at a location adjacent to the meter or property line or an alternate location
label: BODY

text: acceptable to the purveyor.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 8
label: BODY

text: Page 139
label: BODY

text: (d) When premises isolation assemblies are installed at an alternate location acceptable to
label: BODY

text: the purveyor, the purveyor shall ensure that there are no connections between the point
label: BODY

text: of delivery from the public water system and the approved backflow assembly, unless
label: BODY

text: the installation of such a connection meets the purveyor's cross-connection control
label: BODY

text: requirements and is specifically approved by the purveyor.
label: BODY

text: (e) The purveyor shall ensure that approved backflow preventers are installed in accordance
label: BODY

text: with the following time frames:
label: BODY

text: (i) For new connections made on or after the effective date of these regulations, the
label: BODY

text: following conditions shall be met before service is provided:
label: BODY

text: (A) The provisions of subsection (3)(d)(ii) of this section; and
label: BODY

text: (B) Satisfactory completion of a test by a BAT in accordance with subsection (7) of
label: BODY

text: this section.
label: BODY

text: (ii) For existing connections where the purveyor identifies a high health cross-connection
label: BODY

text: hazard, the provisions of (3)(d)(ii) of this section shall be met:
label: BODY

text: (A) Within ninety days of the purveyor notifying the consumer of the high health
label: BODY

text: cross-connection hazard; or
label: BODY

text: (B) In accordance with an alternate schedule acceptable to the purveyor.
label: BODY

text: (iii)For existing connections where the purveyor identifies a low health cross-connection
label: BODY

text: hazard, the provisions of subsection (3)(d)(ii) of this section shall be met in
label: BODY

text: accordance with a schedule acceptable to the purveyor.
label: BODY

text: (f) The purveyor shall ensure that bypass piping installed around any approved backflow
label: BODY

text: preventer is equipped with an approved backflow preventer that:
label: BODY

text: (i) Affords at least the same level of protection as the approved backflow preventer that
label: BODY

text: is being bypassed; and
label: BODY

text: (ii) Complies with all applicable requirements of this section.
label: BODY

text: (7) Approved backflow preventer inspection and testing.
label: BODY

text: (a) The purveyor shall ensure that:
label: BODY

text: (i) A CCS inspects backflow preventer installations to ensure that protection is provided
label: BODY

text: commensurate with the assessed degree of hazard;
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 8
label: BODY

text: Page 140
label: BODY

text: (ii) Either a BAT or CCS inspects:
label: BODY

text: (A) Air gaps installed in lieu of approved backflow prevention assemblies for
label: BODY

text: compliance with the approved air gap definition; and
label: BODY

text: (B) Backflow prevention assemblies for correct installation and approval status.
label: BODY

text: (iii)A BAT tests approved backflow prevention assemblies for proper operation.
label: BODY

text: (b) The purveyor shall ensure that inspections and/or tests of approved air gaps and
label: BODY

text: approved backflow assemblies are conducted:
label: BODY

text: (i) At the time of installation;
label: BODY

text: (ii) Annually after installation, or more frequently, if required by the purveyor for
label: BODY

text: connections serving premises or systems that pose a high health cross-connection
label: BODY

text: hazard or for assemblies that repeatedly fail;
label: BODY

text: (iii)After a backflow incident; and
label: BODY

text: (iv) After an assembly is repaired, reinstalled, or relocated or an air gap is replumbed.
label: BODY

text: (c) The purveyor shall ensure that inspections of AVBs installed on irrigation systems are
label: BODY

text: conducted:
label: BODY

text: (i) At the time of installation;
label: BODY

text: (ii) After a backflow incident; and
label: BODY

text: (iii)After repair, reinstallation, or relocation.
label: BODY

text: (d) The purveyor shall ensure that approved backflow prevention assemblies are tested using
label: BODY

text: procedures acceptable to the department, such as those specified in the most recently
label: BODY

text: published edition of the USC Manual.  When circumstances, such as, but not limited to,
label: BODY

text: configuration or location of the assembly, preclude the use of USC test procedures, the
label: BODY

text: purveyor may allow, on a case-by-case basis, the use of alternate (non-USC) test
label: BODY

text: procedures acceptable to the department.
label: BODY

text: (e) The purveyor shall ensure that results of backflow prevention assembly inspections and
label: BODY

text: tests are documented and reported in a manner acceptable to the purveyor.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004

text: Chapter 8
label: BODY

text: Page 141
label: BODY

text: (f) The purveyor shall ensure that an approved backflow prevention assembly or AVB,
label: BODY

text: whenever found to be improperly installed, defective, not commensurate with the degree
label: BODY

text: of hazard, or failing a test (if applicable) is properly reinstalled, repaired, overhauled, or
label: BODY

text: replaced.
label: BODY

text: (g) The purveyor shall ensure that an approved air gap, whenever found to be altered or
label: BODY

text: improperly installed, is properly replumbed or, if commensurate with the degree of
label: BODY

text: hazard, is replaced by an approved RPBA.

text: (8) Recordkeeping and reporting.
label: BODY

text: (a) Purveyors shall keep cross-connection control records for the following time frames:
label: BODY

text: (i) Records pertaining to the master list of service connections and/or consumer's
label: BODY

text: premises required in subsection (3)(j)(i) of this section shall be kept as long as the
label: BODY

text: premises pose a cross-connection hazard to the purveyor's distribution system;
label: BODY

text: (ii) Records regarding inventory information required in subsection (3)(j)(ii) of this
label: BODY

text: section shall be kept for five years or for the life of the approved backflow preventer
label: BODY

text: whichever is shorter; and
label: BODY

text: (iii)Records regarding backflow incidents and annual summary reports required in

text: subsection (3)(j)(iii) of this section shall be kept for five years.
label: BODY

text: (b) Purveyors may maintain cross-connection control records in original form or transfer
label: BODY

text: data to tabular summaries.
label: BODY

text: (c) Purveyors may maintain records or data in any media, such as paper, film, or electronic
label: BODY

text: format.

text: (d) The purveyor shall complete the cross-connection control program summary report
label: BODY

text: annually.  Report forms and guidance on completing the report are available from the

text: department.

text: (e) The purveyor shall make all records and reports required in subsection (3)(j) of this

text: section available to the department or its representative upon request.

text: (f) The purveyor shall notify the department, local administrative authority, and local health
label: BODY

text: jurisdiction as soon as possible, but no later than the end of the next business day, when

text: a backflow incident is known by the purveyor to have:
label: BODY

text: (i) Contaminated the public water system; or
label: BODY

text: (ii) Occurred within the premises of a consumer served by the purveyor.

text: (g) The purveyor shall:

text: (i) Document details of backflow incidents on a form acceptable to the department such

text: Frequently Asked Regulatory Interpretation Questions and Answers
label: BODY

text: Section 1
label: H4

text: Applicability, Purpose, and Responsibility
label: BODY

text: Do all non-community systems have to develop and implement Cross-Connection
label: BODY

text: Control (CCC) Programs?
label: BODY

text: Yes.  The intent is to provide the same level of public health protection for non-community
label: BODY

text: water systems as small Group A community systems.  Non-community systems can use this
label: BODY

text: manual as guidance for development and implementation of their CCC programs.
label: BODY

text: How do the minimum elements in Section 3 of Washington Administrative Code
label: BODY

text: (WAC) 246-290-490 apply to non-community systems, especially single-purpose
label: BODY

text: systems, where the purveyor and customer are essentially the same?
label: BODY

text: The elements of Section 3 apply to all Group A systems.  However, the effort needed to
label: BODY

text: comply may be minimal for some non-community systems.  For a single-purpose system, it
label: BODY

text: may only be necessary to confirm in a hazard assessment that protection of the source of
label: BODY

text: supply is adequate.  Depending on the nature of the system, source protection could be
label: BODY

text: achieved through installation of a backflow preventer to directly protect the source and/or
label: BODY

text: through installation of backflow preventers at the points of hazard (i.e., fixtures) per the
label: BODY

text: Uniform Plumbing Code (UPC).  A sample written CCC program for a non-community
label: BODY

text: system is provided in Appendix B of this manual.  The sample program contains the
label: BODY

text: minimum elements listed in WAC 246-290-490(3).
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 8
label: BODY

text: Page 143
label: BODY

text: Was the intent for large non-community systems to "just" comply with the Uniform
label: BODY

text: Plumbing Code (UPC)?  Would premises isolation ever be appropriate for a large non-
label: BODY

text: community system?
label: BODY

text: No, it was not the intent for large non-community systems to merely comply with the UPC.
label: BODY

text: For most non-community systems, Washington State Department of Health (DOH) and the
label: BODY

text: Local Administrative Authority (LAA) have overlapping jurisdictions.  Thus, non-community
label: BODY

text: systems must comply with both WAC 246-290-490 and the UPC.  Regarding the UPC, the
label: BODY

text: non-community system must comply with the plumbing code in effect at the time the
label: BODY

text: plumbing permit was issued (i.e., at time of construction).
label: BODY

text: Regarding WAC 246-290-490, premises isolation may be appropriate, and in some cases
label: BODY

text: required, for large non-community systems, depending on the types of hazards posed to the
label: BODY

text: distribution system.  The CCC requirements of WAC 246-290-490 are, in some cases, more
label: BODY

text: stringent than the UPC, specifically in the area of mandatory premises isolation.  So merely
label: BODY

text: complying with the UPC would not provide the protection required by the drinking water
label: BODY

text: regulations.  For a non-community system, area, building, and/or source isolation may be
label: BODY

text: needed to protect the distribution system and source of supply from contamination via cross-
label: BODY

text: connections (i.e., from being a conduit for the spread of contaminants between buildings or
label: BODY

text: areas of concentration of population).
label: BODY

text: Section 2
label: H4

text: General Program Requirements
label: BODY

text: Do alternate references have to be acceptable to Washington State Department of
label: H4

text: Health (DOH)?  What criteria does DOH use to accept alternate references?
label: BODY

text: The purveyor’s CCC program must be acceptable to DOH.  The DOH regional engineer
label: BODY

text: reviewing a CCC program will accept the two publications listed as guidance in WAC 246-
label: BODY

text: 290-490.  Alternate guidance manuals may be acceptable, if certain criteria are met.  The
label: BODY

text: criteria DOH uses to accept alternate references are:  1) The manual reflects current
label: BODY

text: industry practices and standards; 2). The manual has been produced by a nationally
label: BODY

text: recognized organization with expertise in cross-connection control, such as American
label: BODY

text: Water Works Association (AWWA), University of Southern California Foundation for Cross
label: BODY

text: Connection Control and Hydraulic Research (USCFCCCHR), American Backflow
label: BODY

text: Prevention Association (ABPA), or United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA);
label: BODY

text: and 3). The manual has undergone association and/or peer review by AWWA,
label: BODY

text: USCFCCCHR, ABPA, federal and/or state public health officials and professional
label: BODY

text: engineers.
label: BODY

text: Will the department develop a "public listing" of Washington State Department of
label: BODY

text: Health (DOH) certified Cross-Connection Control Specialists (CCSs) willing to act as
label: BODY

text: consultants to small water systems?  What are the guidelines for hiring a CCS?
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 8
label: BODY

text: Page 144
label: BODY

text: DOH has developed a contract operators public listing.  All contract operators must be
label: BODY

text: DOH-certified CCSs.  The contract operators list is available on the Office of Drinking
label: BODY

text: Water’s website:  http://www.doh.wa.gov/
label: BODY

text: DOH does not have a brochure developed that provides specific guidelines for hiring a
label: BODY

text: contract CCS.  However, this issue is discussed in detail in Chapter 7.  Before hiring a CCS
label: BODY

text: on contract, at a minimum, purveyors are strongly encouraged to carefully check the
label: BODY

text: CCS’s:
label: BODY

text: Familiarity with the most recently published version of WAC 246-290-490;
label: BODY

text: Relevant experience with other similar water systems;
label: BODY

text: Extent of coordination with DOH headquarters and regional office CCC staff;
label: BODY

text: Participation in the DOH CCC-related committees;
label: BODY

text: Participation in regional and national CCC groups; and
label: BODY

text: Public water system (PWS) references (at least 3).
label: BODY

text: Sample CCC written programs developed by the CCS should also be available for the
label: BODY

text: purveyor to review.  It is recommended that proposals be obtained from at least three CCSs.
label: BODY

text: Some contract operators may have minimal experience in the development and
label: BODY

text: implementation of CCC programs.  Thus, in addition to the DOH Contract Operators list,
label: BODY

text: purveyors are encouraged to network with their regional CCC groups for a list of more
label: BODY

text: experienced consultant CCSs.
label: BODY

text: Note:  High prices do not necessarily indicate quality work.  Contracts should specify that
label: BODY

text: the written CCC program plan produced must comply with the current WAC 246-290-490.
label: BODY

text: Availability for technical consultation on an as-needed basis is an item to also consider
label: BODY

text: including in the contract.  Another suggestion is to include language in the contract that
label: BODY

text: final payment will not be made by the purveyor, until the written program plan has been
label: BODY

text: reviewed and accepted by DOH.
label: BODY

text: What does “coordination” with Local Administrative Authority (LAA) mean?
label: BODY

text: Coordination is explained in detail in Chapter 6.  Coordination may range from a minimal
label: BODY

text: effort, i.e., an exchange of information with the LAA, to an extensive level of coordination,
label: BODY

text: i.e., implementation of a joint program.  The advantages and disadvantages of the range of
label: BODY

text: levels of coordination are discussed in Chapter 6.  Purveyors must describe the level of
label: BODY

text: coordination in their written CCC program plans.  When a joint program is selected as the
label: BODY

text: preferred option, although not required, DOH recommends that a written agreement be
label: BODY

text: developed between the purveyor and the LAA.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 8
label: BODY

text: Page 145
label: BODY

text: Note:   Efforts are currently underway in Snohomish County to develop standardized
label: BODY

text: language to use when developing written coordination agreements between
label: BODY

text: purveyors and LAAs in Washington.  Purveyors are encouraged to stay informed
label: BODY

text: about this effort through their regional CCC groups.  Once developed, DOH hopes
label: BODY

text: to incorporate the sample agreement language into a future update of this manual.
label: BODY

text: Must a Cross-Connection Control program be submitted to Washington State
label: BODY

text: Department of Health (DOH) for review?
label: BODY

text: Yes, per WAC246-290-490(2)(e), it was DOH’s intent for written program plans to be
label: BODY

text: included in the purveyor’s Water System Plan (WSP) or Small Water System Management
label: BODY

text: Program (SWSMP) that are submitted to DOH for review and approval.  However, not all
label: BODY

text: Group A systems must submit WSPs or SWSMPs.  For example, small, non-expanding water
label: BODY

text: systems are not required to submit planning documents, unless specifically requested to do
label: BODY

text: so by DOH due to system operational problems.  DOH also intended to be able to request
label: BODY

text: submission of the purveyor’s written CCC program plan as a stand-alone document or to
label: BODY

text: request that the plan be made available for review as part of the sanitary survey process.
label: BODY

text: Can a purveyor rely solely upon a premises isolation program or rely solely upon an
label: BODY

text: in-premises program to protect the public water system (PWS) from contamination?
label: BODY

text: Purveyors may rely solely upon premises isolation programs to protect their systems from
label: BODY

text: contamination.  However, the opposite is not true.  Thus, purveyors can’t rely solely upon
label: BODY

text: in-premises programs to protect the PWS from contamination.  An in-premises type of
label: BODY

text: program is unacceptable, because the CCC regulations require all purveyors to ensure that
label: BODY

text: premises isolation is provided for high health hazard categories of premises of the type
label: BODY

text: listed in Table 9 of WAC 246-290-490.
label: BODY

text: Systems do have the option of implementing a combination program that relies on premises
label: BODY

text: isolation for high-hazard premises and relies on in-premises protection for non-high hazard
label: BODY

text: premises.  When the purveyor chooses this combination program option, all conditions in
label: BODY

text: WAC 246-290-490(2)(h) must be met.
label: BODY

text: Are purveyors required to shut-off or deny water service to customers that fail to
label: BODY

text: comply with the purveyor's cross-connection control requirements?
label: BODY

text: No, water shut-off is only one of the enforcement tools available to purveyors.  The
label: BODY

text: responsibility of the purveyor is to protect the PWS from contamination.  Water shut-off may
label: BODY

text: be appropriate under emergency conditions (e.g., backflow incident occurring, cross
label: BODY

text: connection with sewage).  However, in lieu of water shutoff, the purveyor may choose to
label: BODY

text: install the necessary backflow preventer, if the customer fails to comply with the request to
label: BODY

text: install a backflow preventer.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 8
label: BODY

text: Page 146
label: BODY

text: Shutting off water service may cause a public health hazard.  In addition, shutting off water
label: BODY

text: service without reasonable cause or adequate legal authority may expose the purveyor to a
label: BODY

text: claim for damages.  DOH is in the process of developing guidance to purveyors regarding
label: BODY

text: water shutoff.  Once finalized, DOH plans to include the guidance material in this manual.
label: BODY

text: Why is it necessary to notify the Local Administrative Authority (LAA), before I shut
label: BODY

text: off a customer’s water?
label: BODY

text: This requirement is in the regulations, because the purveyor’s actions may affect the public
label: BODY

text: health and safety of occupants and/or users of the customer's premises.  For example, the
label: BODY

text: shut off of potable water service affects building occupancy, adding a double-check valve
label: BODY

text: assembly (DCVA) on the service affects thermal expansion, and the shutoff of a fire line
label: BODY

text: affects public safety.  For liability management, the purveyor should not take any action
label: BODY

text: known to affect public health or safety without notifying the LAA having jurisdiction.
label: BODY

text: Why is it necessary to prevent the intentional return of water to the distribution
label: BODY

text: system (e.g., from heat exchangers)?
label: BODY

text: In a PWS, the normal flow of water is from the source of supply to the customer’s tap.
label: BODY

text: Thus, many contaminants introduced into the customer’s plumbing system by the
label: BODY

text: customer (through backflow incidents, inadequate disinfection of repair work, etc.) will
label: BODY

text: likely remain in the customer's system, until the customer’s normal use flushes the
label: BODY

text: contaminants from a tap.
label: BODY

text: However, a return system circumvents this natural protection for the PWS. More
label: BODY

text: importantly, the purveyor has no control over the quality of water that has left the
label: BODY

text: purveyor's distribution system.  Even when the returned water is supposedly potable, a
label: BODY

text: change in temperature may adversely affect the purveyor's system (e.g., increased water
label: BODY

text: temperature may enhance bacteria re-growth in the distribution system).  Prohibiting the
label: BODY

text: intentional return of used water to the purveyor’s distribution system protects the quality
label: BODY

text: of water served to consumers.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 8
label: BODY

text: Page 147
label: BODY

text: Section 3
label: H4

text: Minimum Elements of a Cross-Connection Control (CCC) Program
label: BODY

text: Do the regulations specify when purveyors need to complete their initial hazard
label: BODY

text: assessments?
label: BODY

text: The regulations do not specify an absolute time frame for completing initial hazard
label: BODY

text: assessments.  Chapter 7 of this manual includes general schedule guidelines.
label: BODY

text: The revised CCC regulations became effective in April 1999.  As of the publication date of
label: BODY

text: this manual, all Group A systems should have at least initiated their CCC programs.  At a
label: BODY

text: minimum, DOH will review the purveyor’s written program plan when a system submits a
label: BODY

text: WSP or SWSMP.  The written program plan must include procedures and reasonable
label: BODY

text: schedules for ensuring completion of initial hazard assessments for existing and new
label: BODY

text: customers.
label: BODY

text: For example, a plan may indicate for existing customers that the initial hazard evaluations
label: BODY

text: will be completed within one year of program startup.  For new connections, the purveyor
label: BODY

text: should now be making initial hazard evaluations prior to service being provided.  As a
label: BODY

text: practical matter, the purveyor will need to first establish a CCC policy, retain the services of
label: BODY

text: a CCS, etc. before assessing hazards.
label: BODY

text: Purveyors will show DOH their system’s implementation progress through submission of
label: BODY

text: the Annual Summary Report (ASR) forms, and/or through sanitary surveys.
label: BODY

text: When must the purveyor start installing backflow prevention assemblies?
label: BODY

text: The CCC regulations do not establish an absolute time frame.  However, Chapter 7 of this
label: BODY

text: manual includes general guidelines.  The purveyor's written program plan must establish
label: BODY

text: procedures and schedules for backflow preventer installation.  The time allowed should be
label: BODY

text: based on the degree of hazard posed to the PWS.  For example, a plan may specify that all
label: BODY

text: customers of the type listed on Table 9 of WAC 246-290-490 will have backflow prevention
label: BODY

text: installed within two years of notification and that all low-hazard fire lines will have
label: BODY

text: backflow prevention installed when the building is renovated or enlarged.
label: BODY

text: What is an acceptable time frame for submission of a test report?
label: BODY

text: A reasonable time frame for a backflow assembly tester (BAT) to provide the customer with
label: BODY

text: a test report is within ten business days of performing the test.  In general, for the annual
label: BODY

text: backflow assembly test report, most purveyors allow customers 30 to 45 days to submit the
label: BODY

text: paperwork from the anniversary date.  In rural areas, where only a few BATs are available,
label: BODY

text: purveyors may need to allow a longer period (e.g., 45-60 days).  Purveyors need to make
label: BODY

text: sure their customer’s receive notice for the test long before the anniversary date.  Purveyors
label: BODY

text: should not send out the testing notices at the last minute and expect their customers to rush
label: BODY

text: to comply.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 8
label: BODY

text: Page 148
label: BODY

text: Note:  The annual test doesn’t need to be completed on the precise anniversary date of the
label: BODY

text: last test.  Most purveyors consider a timeframe within thirty days of the anniversary date
label: BODY

text: reasonable for the annual test to be performed.
label: BODY

text: What is the purpose of the quality assurance/quality control (QA/QC) program?
label: BODY

text: The purpose of the QA/QC program is to ensure consistency and reliability in the testing of
label: BODY

text: assemblies that protect the PWS.  Although not fail-proof, the quality assurance program
label: BODY

text: should help prevent and/or reduce some of the problems purveyors have encountered in the
label: BODY

text: past with BAT performance.  These problems have included submission of incomplete or
label: BODY

text: false test reports, use of incorrect test procedures, and testing errors made due to
label: BODY

text: improperly calibrated test equipment.  Also, the additional hands-on training time in BAT
label: BODY

text: courses and tightening of the DOH BAT certification exam process should help improve
label: BODY

text: BAT performance statewide.
label: BODY

text: Section 4
label: H4

text: Approved Backflow Preventer Selection
label: BODY

text: Are purveyors limited to the categories in Table 9 of Washington Administrative Code
label: BODY

text: (WAC) 246-290-490 for mandatory premises isolation?
label: BODY

text: No.  Table 9 of WAC 246-290-490 is not all-inclusive, and in fact, only identifies typical
label: BODY

text: high-hazard categories of premises served by most large PWSs in Washington.  Table 9
label: BODY

text: of WAC 246-290-490 is essentially the minimum list of categories that require premises
label: BODY

text: isolation.  Other states and technical references may include additional categories in their
label: BODY

text: mandatory premises isolation lists.
label: BODY

text: Purveyors must ensure that all premises of the type listed on Table 9 of WAC 246-290-490
label: BODY

text: meet the mandatory premises isolation requirements.  Although purveyors may not delete a
label: BODY

text: mandatory isolation category from Table 9 of WAC 246-290-490, they may add to the Table
label: BODY

text: 9 of WAC 246-290-490 list.
label: BODY

text: Additions may be based on industry guidance and the purveyor’s policy for risk and liability
label: BODY

text: management.  For example, airline manufacturing plants are not specifically listed on Table
label: BODY

text: 9 of WAC 246-290-490, but must be considered as high hazard premises for the few PWSs
label: BODY

text: in Washington that provide water service to them.  As another example, for risk and liability
label: BODY

text: management, a purveyor may choose to require premises isolation DCVAs on all malls,
label: BODY

text: because of the complexity of their piping systems and high probability of changes in tenants
label: BODY

text: (i.e., water use).
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 8
label: BODY

text: Page 149
label: BODY

text: Some of the categories on Table 9 of Washington Administrative Code (WAC) 246-
label: BODY

text: 290-490 are confusing.  For example, are gas stations included in the Petroleum
label: BODY

text: Storage and Processing category?  Are restaurants included in the Food Processing
label: BODY

text: Plant category?
label: BODY

text: The intent of Table 9 of WAC 246-290-490 is to identify typical categories of facilities that
label: BODY

text: pose a high health hazard to the PWS.  This rating is due to one or more of the following:
label: BODY

text: the complexity of their plumbing and industrial piping systems, frequency of plumbing and
label: BODY

text: piping changes, scale of operations (large, commercial), the presence of hazardous
label: BODY

text: materials, and/or hazardous processes/activities occurring on-site.
label: BODY

text: DOH intended for the category Petroleum Storage and Processing facilities to address bulk
label: BODY

text: storage facilities (i.e., tank farms) and refineries; DOH did not intend for this category to
label: BODY

text: include neighborhood gas stations.  Similarly, DOH intended for the Food Processing Plant
label: BODY

text: category to address canneries, beef packing houses, potato processors, fruit processors,
label: BODY

text: etc., and in general did not intend for the category to include local restaurants.
label: BODY

text: Which irrigation systems require premises isolation?
label: BODY

text: The UPC establishes backflow protection requirements for irrigation systems in
label: BODY

text: Washington.  However, the UPC does not cover dedicated irrigation systems supplied
label: BODY

text: directly from the purveyor’s distribution main (i.e., not supplied through customer’s
label: BODY

text: domestic service line).  Under Table 9 of WAC 246-290-490, irrigation systems with
label: BODY

text: chemical addition that are supplied through a dedicated line (i.e., separate from the
label: BODY

text: domestic service line) require premises isolation with a reduced-pressure backflow
label: BODY

text: assembly (RPBA).  Dedicated irrigation lines are typically found at parks, playgrounds,
label: BODY

text: golf courses, cemeteries, and estates.
label: BODY

text: The UPC requires an RPBA on other irrigation systems with chemical addition.  For
label: BODY

text: irrigation systems without chemical addition, the UPC requires a DCVA, pressure vacuum
label: BODY

text: breaker assembly (PVBA) or atmospheric vacuum breaker (AVB).  The purveyor’s written
label: BODY

text: program plan should address irrigation systems and indicate whether:
label: BODY

text: AVBs will be accepted to protect the PWS; or
label: BODY

text: An approved assembly (e.g., a testable DCVA) will be required.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 8
label: BODY

text: Page 150
label: BODY

text: Is there a provision in the Washington Administrative Code (WAC) for the purveyor
label: BODY

text: to grant an exception to the mandatory premises isolation requirements for premises
label: BODY

text: of the type listed on Table 9 of WAC 246-290-490?
label: BODY

text: Yes, the WAC does contain such a provision.  The exception provision is to be used in those
label: BODY

text: rare instances where the customer's water use and hazard posed to the purveyor’s system
label: BODY

text: don’t “match” the water use and high health hazard typically associated with the specific
label: BODY

text: category of premises.  For example, a “beverage bottling plant” used only as a storage
label: BODY

text: warehouse doesn’t pose the same degree of hazard as a plant where beverage bottling
label: BODY

text: processes are taking place.  The purveyor's CCS must assess the degree of hazard and
label: BODY

text: determine whether the granting of an exception is appropriate.  CCSs can use the "good
label: BODY

text: engineering practices” described in the technical publications referenced in WAC 246-290-
label: BODY

text: 490(2) to aid in exception determinations.
label: BODY

text: When exceptions to mandatory premises isolation are granted, the CCS must document the
label: BODY

text: reasons, i.e., provide justification for granting the exception.  DOH has developed an
label: BODY

text: Exception Form for documenting the justification for granting an exception.  An Exception
label: BODY

text: Form must be completed for each exception granted by the purveyor.  After the initial ASR
label: BODY

text: is completed and submitted to DOH, Exception Forms must be submitted to DOH with the
label: BODY

text: ASR for the reporting year in which the exception was granted.
label: BODY

text: As an "alternate location acceptable to the purveyor,” how far downstream of the
label: BODY

text: meter may a premises isolation assembly be located?
label: BODY

text: There is no general rule in terms of distance.  However, for risk management reasons, it is
label: BODY

text: preferable that the assembly be located as close to the meter (property line) as possible and
label: BODY

text: that no connections are made between the meter and the RPBA.
label: BODY

text: For freeze protection, many purveyors allow the RPBA to be installed in the mechanical
label: BODY

text: room of the building or at the point where the service line just enters the building.  Because
label: BODY

text: the RPBA must isolate the customer’s plumbing from the PWS, there can be no connections
label: BODY

text: made between the RPBA and the meter, unless they are specifically approved by the
label: BODY

text: purveyor and have the appropriate backflow protection.
label: BODY

text: Must backflow protection for all existing fire sprinkler systems with chemical addition
label: BODY

text: be upgraded to a reduced-pressure backflow assembly (RPBA) within 90 days of
label: BODY

text: notifying the customer of the high health cross-connection hazard?
label: BODY

text: No.  The WAC allows an alternate schedule acceptable to the purveyor to be adopted.  The
label: BODY

text: 90 days indicates the high health hazard assessment of fire sprinkler systems with chemical
label: BODY

text: addition and the need to give priority to the installation of an RPBA.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 8
label: BODY

text: Page 151
label: BODY

text: The purveyor should work with the customer to establish a reasonable schedule for
label: BODY

text: installation of the backflow preventer.  However, for risk management reasons, the earliest
label: BODY

text: possible installation date provides the most benefit to the purveyor.  When working with
label: BODY

text: customers to establish a mutually agreeable schedule, purveyors should consider the
label: BODY

text: practical aspects of retrofitting an existing sprinkler system with the appropriate backflow
label: BODY

text: protection (e.g., cost, obtaining permits, impacts on sprinkler performance, possible
label: BODY

text: redesign of fire system, space limitations and scheduling a contractor).  In some situations,
label: BODY

text: the customer may need as long as two years to get the backflow preventer installed (e.g.,
label: BODY

text: hospital).
label: BODY

text: Note:  The RPBA requirement for high-hazard fire sprinkler systems should be imposed
label: BODY

text: when the customer remodels or expands the building.
label: BODY

text: How can the customer obtain water to test plumbing, before backflow preventers are
label: BODY

text: installed and tested?
label: BODY

text: Normal practice is to provide a construction service with a water meter and an RPBA
label: BODY

text: (DCVA minimum).  A construction site often poses a greater cross-connection hazard to the
label: BODY

text: PWS than the completed facility.
label: BODY

text: Section 5
label: H4

text: Approved Backflow Preventers
label: BODY

text: Where do I obtain a current list of Washington State Department of Health (DOH)
label: BODY

text: approved assemblies?
label: BODY

text: Purveyors may obtain hard copies of the list from DOH Office of Drinking Water upon
label: BODY

text: request.  The Training and Outreach Section handles such requests.  Purveyors without
label: BODY

text: Internet access can request the list by e-mail or by phone (see Appendix F for DOH contact
label: BODY

text: information).  Purveyors with Internet access can request a list via the Drinking Water
label: BODY

text: website: http://www.doh.wa.gov/ehp/dw
label: BODY

text: Due to our agreement with USC (the organization that develops the list), DOH is not
label: BODY

text: allowed to post the list on the Drinking Water website.  DOH publishes the list annually (at
label: BODY

text: the beginning of each calendar year) and issues at least one update during the year.  DOH
label: BODY

text: automatically sends updates to those systems, CCSs, BATs, etc., on file with DOH as having
label: BODY

text: requested a list at the beginning of the calendar year.
label: BODY

text: The purveyor’s CCS should have a copy of the most recently published DOH-Approved
label: BODY

text: Assemblies List and understand how to use the information on the list.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 8
label: BODY

text: Page 152
label: BODY

text: Section 6
label: H4

text: Approved Backflow Preventer Installation
label: BODY

text: What are the requirements for installation?
label: BODY

text: The standard installation procedures acceptable to DOH are provided in the technical
label: BODY

text: publications such as the USC Manual or Pacific Northwest Section – American Water
label: BODY

text: Works Association (PNWS-AWWA) Manual.  Large utilities and/or the regional cross-
label: BODY

text: connection groups may also have standard installation plans available that meet the
label: BODY

text: technical specifications in the CCC manuals and can be used by small water systems.
label: BODY

text: Can a double-check valve assembly (DCVA) be installed in a below-ground pit?  What
label: BODY

text: about the requirement that the purveyor ensure that an assembly is not flooded?
label: BODY

text: Yes, a DCVA can be installed below grade (e.g., in a meter box).  The intent of the language
label: BODY

text: regarding flooding was to prevent backflow assemblies from creating cross-connection
label: BODY

text: hazards themselves.  To meet the intent of the WAC, with a below-grade type of installation,
label: BODY

text: the purveyor must ensure that the assembly will not create a cross connection with ground
label: BODY

text: water.  This can be accomplished by requiring test cock plugs to be installed with all below-
label: BODY

text: grade assemblies.
label: BODY

text: Section 7
label: H4

text: Approved Backflow Preventer Inspection and Testing
label: BODY

text: Must a cross-connection control specialist (CCS) inspect an atmospheric vacuum
label: BODY

text: breaker (AVB) on a residential lawn sprinkler system?
label: BODY

text: Yes.  All AVBs relied upon by the purveyor must inspected by a CCS at the time of
label: BODY

text: installation, after a backflow incident and after repair, re-installation and re-inspection.
label: BODY

text: The purpose of the inspection is to make sure the AVB is installed correctly and is operable,
label: BODY

text: etc. The USC foundation recommends that AVBs be checked annually.
label: BODY

text: Annual assembly testing is a Washington State Department of Health (DOH)
label: BODY

text: minimum requirement.  When would it be appropriate for a purveyor to require more
label: BODY

text: testing?
label: BODY

text: More frequent testing is appropriate when an assembly shows (from the historical test
label: BODY

text: reports) signs of impending failure, but the assembly has not been replaced.  For example, if
label: BODY

text: there is a question about the reliability of the assembly, the purveyor should require another
label: BODY

text: test in six months.  In addition, some purveyors require more frequent testing for premises
label: BODY

text: isolation assemblies installed at severe and high-hazard facilities such as nuclear facilities,
label: BODY

text: sewage treatment plants, and hospitals.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 8
label: BODY

text: Page 153
label: BODY

text: Section 8
label: H4

text: Recordkeeping and Reporting
label: BODY

text: What documentation must be kept?
label: BODY

text: For each connection served, the purveyor must keep:
label: BODY

text: Information on the initial and subsequent hazard assessments (e.g., questionnaire
label: BODY

text: and survey); and
label: BODY

text: Detailed assembly inventory information for all assemblies relied upon by the
label: BODY

text: purveyor to protect the PWS.  Actual test report readings should be recorded and
label: BODY

text: kept as part of the required assembly test report information.
label: BODY

text: For connections with both a premises isolation assembly and one or more in-premises
label: BODY

text: assemblies, the purveyor is only required to track information on the premises isolation
label: BODY

text: assembly.  All assemblies other than the premises isolation assembly fall under the
label: BODY

text: jurisdiction of the Local Administrative Authority.
label: BODY

text: When should records of test reports be kept in electronic format (i.e., other than
label: BODY

text: manually)?
label: BODY

text: The WAC allows records to be kept manually on paper or in electronic format, so the
label: BODY

text: decision is left to the purveyor.  Most systems find that manual tracking becomes too
label: BODY

text: difficult, when the number of assemblies that protect the PWS reaches 100 or more.
label: BODY

text: Because they will have so few assemblies to track, many small water systems may be able to
label: BODY

text: keep adequate records manually.  However, where a personal computer is used for word
label: BODY

text: processing, it is a relatively easy task to establish a computer spreadsheet to track test
label: BODY

text: reports.  Most small systems will not need to purchase more expensive, proprietary
label: BODY

text: computer database software specifically designed for CCC program management.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Chapter 8
label: BODY

text: Page 154
label: BODY

text: Must all backflow incidents be reported to DOH?
label: BODY

text: Yes.  Purveyors must notify DOH, the local administrative authority, and the local health
label: BODY

text: jurisdiction as soon as possible and no later than the next business day of any backflow
label: BODY

text: incident that contaminates the PWS or customer’s plumbing.  Purveyors can consult the
label: BODY

text: PNWS-AWWA Backflow Incident Investigation Manual for information on how to proceed
label: BODY

text: with investigation and clean up.
label: BODY

text: The purveyor must document (on a form acceptable to DOH) the details of any incidents
label: BODY

text: that contaminated the PWS.  However, for risk management purposes, it is prudent for
label: BODY

text: purveyors to report all known backflow incidents to DOH, including incidents where the
label: BODY

text: contaminant was contained within the customer’s premises.  This additional information
label: BODY

text: can be helpful when DOH is coordinating with the State Building Code Council on UPC
label: BODY

text: issues and for demonstrating the effectiveness of premises isolation for protection of the
label: BODY

text: PWS.
label: BODY

text: Appendix A
label: BODY

text: Example Cross-Connection Control Program and
label: BODY

text: Legal Instrument for a Community System
label: BODY

text: Contents
label: BODY

text: This appendix contains an example written cross-connection control (CCC) program plan and an
label: BODY

text: example legal instrument for a community system.  The legal instrument establishes the authority
label: BODY

text: of a public water system (PWS) to adopt and implement a CCC program.
label: BODY

text: The primary type of program that these documents address is a premises isolation type of pro-
label: BODY

text: gram.  However, alternate wording or passages are included for combination or joint types of
label: BODY

text: programs.  Other commonly used alternate approaches and optional additional requirements are
label: BODY

text: also included where appropriate.
label: BODY

text: How to Use Appendix A
label: HH3

text: The example program and legal instrument in Appendix A have been designed for use by com-
label: BODY

text: munity systems where the majority of the service connections are residences or premises owned
label: BODY

text: or occupied by private or public entities separate from the purveyor.
label: BODY

text: The documents in this appendix have been arranged and formatted for ease of review by the
label: BODY

text: Washington State Department of Health (DOH) when it evaluates the program with respect to
label: BODY

text: the regulations.  Therefore, DOH recommends that purveyors follow the format (i.e., use the ex-
label: BODY

text: ample program as a template) whenever possible.  However, PWSs are not required to use the
label: BODY

text: example program and legal instrument.  DOH recognizes that some PWSs may have a particular
label: BODY

text: approach or institutional requirements that may dictate a different format or wording in the writ-
label: BODY

text: ten program plan.
label: BODY

text: Instructions
label: BODY

text: To use the example program plan, water systems are encouraged to:
label: BODY

text: 1. Download the example program file (in Microsoft Word format) from the web site or ob-
label: BODY

text: tain from DOH electronically;
label: BODY

text: 2. Retain the basic formatting and text of the example program and fill in the blanks, deci-
label: BODY

text: sion table, and check boxes where indicated to “customize” the example program;
label: BODY

text: 3. Include or delete optional and/or additional language shown in the example program to
label: BODY

text: reflect system-specific decisions; and
label: BODY

text: 4. Insert the completed written CCC program plan in the Small Water System Management
label: BODY

text: Program (SWSMP) or Water System Plan (WSP).
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Appendix A Page 158
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control Program Plan
label: BODY

text: for _________________ Water System
label: BODY

text: Requirement for Program
label: BODY

text: {Insert public water system name}, {insert public water system identification number},
label: BODY

text: hereinafter referred to as “the Purveyor”, has the responsibility to protect the public water system
label: BODY

text: from contamination due to cross connections.  A cross connection may be defined as “any actual or
label: BODY

text: potential physical connection between a potable water line and any pipe, vessel, or machine that
label: BODY

text: contains or has a probability of containing a non-potable gas or liquid, such that it is possible for a
label: BODY

text: non-potable gas or liquid to enter the potable water system by backflow.”
label: BODY

text: All public water systems are required to develop and implement cross-connection control (CCC)
label: BODY

text: programs.  The CCC requirements are contained in Washington Administrative Code (WAC) 246-
label: BODY

text: 290-490 of the Group A Drinking Water Regulations.  The minimum required elements of a CCC
label: BODY

text: program are:
label: BODY

text: 1. Establishment of legal authority and program policies;
label: BODY

text: 2. Evaluation of premises for cross-connection hazards;
label: BODY

text: 3. Elimination and/or control of cross connections;
label: BODY

text: 4. Provision of qualified personnel;
label: BODY

text: 5. Inspection and testing of backflow preventers;
label: BODY

text: 6. Quality control of testing process;
label: BODY

text: 7. Response to backflow incidents;
label: BODY

text: 8. Public education for consumers;
label: BODY

text: 9. Record keeping for CCC program; and
label: BODY

text: 10. Special requirements for reclaimed water use.
label: BODY

text: Other CCC program requirements include:
label: BODY

text: 1. Coordination with the Local Administrative Authority (LAA), i.e., the local building or
label: BODY

text: plumbing official regarding CCC activities;
label: BODY

text: 2. Prohibition of the return of used water into the public water system (PWS) distribution
label: BODY

text: system; and
label: BODY

text: 3. Inclusion of a written CCC program in a Water System Plan (WSP) or a Small Water
label: BODY

text: System Management Program (SWSMP).
label: BODY

text: Note:  Throughout the example CCC program plan the term customer is used.  Customer as used
label: BODY

text: herein means the property owner and/or occupant of the premises served by the PWS (i.e.,
label: BODY

text: whoever interfaces with the PWS regarding water service).  Also, unless otherwise defined, all
label: BODY

text: CCC-related terms used in this example program have the same definitions as those contained in
label: BODY

text: WAC 246-290-010 of the Washington State Drinking Water Regulations.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Appendix A Page 159
label: BODY

text: Program Objectives
label: BODY

text: The objectives of the CCC program are to:
label: BODY

text: 1. Reasonably reduce the risk of contamination of the public water distribution system; and
label: BODY

text: 2. Reasonably reduce the Purveyor's exposure to legal liability arising from the backflow of
label: BODY

text: any contaminant originating from the customer's plumbing system and then supplied to
label: BODY

text: other customers; and
label: BODY

text: 3. [Add for Joint Program: “Cooperate with the LAA by joint operation of program
label: BODY

text: administrative tasks.”]
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: PWS name} water system.  The items in the table represent CCC program areas that have more
label: BODY

text: than one acceptable approach or option.  (The PWS should mark the appropriate boxes under
label: BODY

text: “Decision” in the following table.)

label: BODY

text: 3.  Relationship with Customer [Element 1]

text: 5.  Assessment and Re-assessment of Hazard [Element 2]
label: H4

text: Required Elements of Program
label: BODY

text: The drinking water regulations for Group A public water systems in Washington, WAC 246-290,
label: BODY

text: require CCC programs to include certain minimum elements.  The elements are listed in WAC 246-
label: BODY

text: 290-490(3).  This section describes how the water system intends to comply with each of the
label: BODY

text: required program elements.  Elements are numbered the same as they appear in the WAC.
label: BODY

text: Element 1: Adoption of a written legal instrument authorizing the establishment and
label: BODY

text: implementation of a CCC program.
label: BODY

text: The {Insert PWS name} water system has adopted a resolution (Resolution No. _________),
label: BODY

text: reproduced as Exhibit _____, which authorizes the Purveyor to implement a CCC program.  The
label: BODY

text: resolution also authorizes the system to terminate water service to consumers who do not comply
label: BODY

text: with the resolution.  However, the primary method for protection of the distribution system will be
label: BODY

text: the installation of a backflow preventer by the customer, at the customer’s expense.  [Optional
label: BODY

text: approach: “by the water system, and the cost thereof to be billed to the customer.” (see Decision
label: BODY

text: Table Items 6 and 9)]  (The Purveyor can substitute appropriate wording to reflect alternate
label: BODY

text: decisions made by the PWS.)
label: BODY

text: The attached service contract referred to in the resolution shall be the primary enforcement authority
label: BODY

text: for all new customers.
label: BODY

text: For customers supplied prior to the adoption of the attached resolution, an implied service contract
label: BODY

text: allows the Purveyor to protect the distribution system from contamination through a Purveyor-
label: BODY

text: installed backflow preventer on a customer's service.
label: BODY

text: The written and implied contract terms are discussed further under Element 3.
label: BODY

text: (The Purveyor should complete and include the following schedule for adoption of a legal
label: BODY

text: instrument, if not already adopted:
label: BODY

text: Legal Instrument Status
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Preparation of proposed legal instrument
label: BODY

text: Introduction of the legal instrument to governing body
label: BODY

text: Adoption of legal instrument
label: BODY

text: Legal instrument becomes effective
label: BODY

text: Schedules may vary depending on governing body procedures.)
