text: Element 2:
label: BODY

text: Development and implementation of procedures and schedules for evaluating new
label: BODY

text: and existing service connections to assess the degree of hazard.
label: BODY

text: Initial Cross-Connection Hazard Surveys
label: BODY

text: The procedures for evaluating the backflow prevention requirements for new and existing customers
label: BODY

text: are as follows:
label: BODY

text: 1. For all new non-residential services, the Purveyor will require that the customer submit
label: BODY

text: with the application for water service an evaluation (performed at customer’s expense) by a
label: BODY

text: DOH-certified cross-connection control specialist (CCS) of the hazard posed by the
label: BODY

text: proposed plumbing system, with recommendations for the installation at the meter of either
label: BODY

text: a double-check valve assembly (DCVA) or a reduced-pressure principle backflow assembly
label: BODY

text: (RPBA).  [Combination or Joint Program Alternative: “or commensurate in-premises
label: BODY

text: backflow protection.”]  The Purveyor may accept the recommendations or submit the
label: BODY

text: recommendations to a CCS employed by the PWS for peer review and concurrence, before
label: BODY

text: acceptance.
label: BODY

text: As an alternative to the above requirement for a survey by a CCS, the customer may agree
label: BODY

text: to install an approved air gap (AG) or RPBA for premises isolation as a condition of service.
label: BODY

text: 2. For all new residential services, the Purveyor will require that the customer submit with the
label: BODY

text: application for water service a completed “Water Use Questionnaire” (copy shown on page
label: BODY

text: {PWS insert page number here}).  If the customer's questionnaire indicates special
label: BODY

text: plumbing, such as a lawn sprinkler system, or hazardous water use on the premises, the
label: BODY

text: customer shall submit to the Purveyor an evaluation by a DOH-certified CCS of the hazard
label: BODY

text: posed by the proposed special plumbing system, with recommendations for the installation
label: BODY

text: at the meter of either a DCVA or an RPBA.  [Combination or Joint Program Alternative:
label: BODY

text: “or commensurate in-premises protection.”]
label: BODY

text: As an alternative to the above requirement for a survey by a DOH-certified CCS, the
label: BODY

text: Purveyor, at his/her discretion, may specify the backflow preventer required to be installed
label: BODY

text: as a condition of service.
label: BODY

text: 3. For all existing non-residential services, the Purveyor will require the customer to submit to
label: BODY

text: the Purveyor, within nine months of notification, an evaluation by a DOH-certified CCS, of
label: BODY

text: the hazard posed by the plumbing system, with recommendations for the installation at the
label: BODY

text: meter of either a DCVA or an RPBA.  [Combination or Joint Program Alternative: “or
label: BODY

text: commensurate in-premises backflow preventers.”]  The Purveyor may accept the
label: BODY

text: recommendations or submit the recommendations to a CCS employed by the Purveyor for
label: BODY

text: peer review and concurrence, before acceptance.
label: BODY

text: As an alternative to the above requirement for a survey by a DOH-certified CCS, the
label: BODY

text: customer may agree to install an AG or RPBA for premises isolation within 90 days of
label: BODY

text: notification by the Purveyor or an alternate time period acceptable to the Purveyor.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Appendix A Page 163
label: BODY

text: 4. For all existing residential services, the Purveyor will require the customer to submit to the
label: BODY

text: Purveyor, within four months of notification, a completed “Water Use Questionnaire.”  If
label: BODY

text: the customer's reply indicates special plumbing or water use on the premises, the customer
label: BODY

text: shall submit an evaluation by a DOH-certified CCS of the hazard posed to the water system
label: BODY

text: by the customer’s plumbing system, with recommendations for the installation at the meter
label: BODY

text: of either a DCVA or an RPBA.  [Combination or Joint Program Alternative:  “or
label: BODY

text: commensurate in-premises backflow preventers”.]
label: BODY

text: As an alternative to the above requirement for a survey by a CCS, the Purveyor may specify
label: BODY

text: the backflow preventer required to be installed as a condition of service.  The Purveyor’s
label: BODY

text: CCS will provide guidance on the type of backflow preventer to be installed.
label: BODY

text: 5. For all existing services, should the customer fail to supply the required information for a
label: BODY

text: hazard assessment or fail to submit a completed “Water Use Questionnaire,” the Purveyor
label: BODY

text: may have the assessment made by a CCS employed by the Purveyor, require the installation
label: BODY

text: of an RPBA for premises isolation, or take other such actions consistent with the previously
label: BODY

text: stated policies and bill the customer for the associated costs.
label: BODY

text: Element 3:
label: BODY

text: Development and implementation of procedures and schedules for elimination
label: BODY

text: and/or control of cross-connections.
label: BODY

text: Backflow Preventer Requirements
label: BODY

text: The following service policy shall apply to all new and existing customers:
label: BODY

text: 1. The Purveyor will require that water service to all non-residential customers be isolated at
label: BODY

text: the meter by a DOH-approved DCVA or RPBA acceptable to the Purveyor.  All high-
label: BODY

text: hazard connections of the type described in Table 9 of WAC 246-290-490 shall be isolated
label: BODY

text: with an RPBA.  [Recommended Option: “All other non-residential customers shall be
label: BODY

text: isolated with a DCVA.”]
label: BODY

text: [Optional Combination or Joint Program Alternative: “In lieu of isolation with a DCVA,
label: BODY

text: other non-residential customers, with the concurrence of the Purveyor’s CCS, may install
label: BODY

text: in-premises protection commensurate with the degree of hazard, as determined by the
label: BODY

text: Purveyor’s CCS.”]
label: BODY

text: 2. The Purveyor will require all residential customers with facilities of the type described in
label: BODY

text: Table 9 of WAC 246-290-490 to be isolated with an RPBA.  All other residential customers
label: BODY

text: with special plumbing or water use on the premises will be isolated with a DCVA.  “Special
label: BODY

text: plumbing” includes, but is not limited to, the following:
label: BODY

text: a. A lawn irrigation system;
label: BODY

text: b. A solar heating system;
label: BODY

text: c. An auxiliary source of supply, e.g., a well or creek;
label: BODY

text: d. Piping for livestock watering, hobby farming, etc.;
label: BODY

text: e. Residential fire sprinkler system; and
label: BODY

text: f. Property containing a small boat moorage.
label: BODY

text: 3. [Optional addition: “Additional premises requiring premises isolation.  The Purveyor has
label: BODY

text: chosen to supplement Table 9 of WAC 246-290-490(4) by identifying additional premises or
label: BODY

text: premises types for which premises isolation is mandated.  Such premises will include
label: BODY

text: aircraft and automotive manufacturers, pulp and paper mills, military bases, tall buildings,
label: BODY

text: premises with complex plumbing, premises with plumbing subject to frequent changes,
label: BODY

text: plumbing with a repeat history of cross-connections being established or reestablished,
label: BODY

text: premises with public swimming pools, and {Purveyor should add other premises or
label: BODY

text: premises types}.”]
label: BODY

text: 4. [Optional addition: “All remaining residential customers will be isolated at the meter by a
label: BODY

text: purveyor-installed meter check valve (single or dual).”] [Combination or Joint Program
label: BODY

text: Alternative:  “Residential customers not required to be isolated with an RPBA may install
label: BODY

text: in-premises protection in accordance with the Uniform Plumbing Code (UPC) in lieu of
label: BODY

text: isolation with a DCVA.”]
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Appendix A Page 166
label: BODY

text: 5. For all customers that have a written service contract with the Purveyor, the required
label: BODY

text: premises isolation DCVA or RPBA shall be:
label: BODY

text: Purchased and installed by the customer (at the customer's expense) immediately
label: BODY

text: downstream of the water meter in accordance with the Purveyor's standards described
label: BODY

text: hereinafter; and
label: BODY

text: Maintained, tested, and inspected in accordance with the Purveyor's standards described
label: BODY

text: hereinafter.
label: BODY

text: For new customers, the Purveyor will not turn on water (except for testing purposes) at the
label: BODY

text: meter until the customer complies with the above requirements.
label: BODY

text: The failure of the customer to comply with the Purveyor’s installation and maintenance
label: BODY

text: requirements shall constitute a breach of contract by the customer.  The Purveyor may then
label: BODY

text: proceed with corrective action provisions stipulated in the contract.
label: BODY

text: 6. Customers without written contracts are considered to have an implied contract that
label: BODY

text: requires the customer to bear all reasonable costs of service.  The Purveyor will install the
label: BODY

text: required DCVA or RPBA on the service, upstream of the meter, and charge the customer
label: BODY

text: for the cost of the initial installation, and all future maintenance, testing, and repair, as set
label: BODY

text: forth in the Purveyor's schedule of rates and charges.  The failure of the customer to pay
label: BODY

text: these costs shall constitute a breach of contract by the customer, and the Purveyor will
label: BODY

text: proceed with the established delinquency of payment procedures.  As an alternative, the
label: BODY

text: customer may sign a service contract and install the required backflow preventer
label: BODY

text: downstream of the meter in accordance with the Purveyor’s installation standards
label: BODY

text: described hereinafter.
label: BODY

text: 7. Approved Backflow Preventers and Installation
label: BODY

text: All backflow preventers relied upon by the Purveyor to protect the public water system shall
label: BODY

text: meet the definition of “approved backflow preventer” as contained in WAC 246-290-010.
label: BODY

text: The Purveyor will obtain and maintain a current list of assemblies approved for installation
label: BODY

text: in Washington State from the DOH Office of Drinking Water.
label: BODY

text: All backflow preventers will be installed in:
label: BODY

text: The orientation for which they are approved;
label: BODY

text: A manner and location that facilitates their proper operation, maintenance, and testing or
label: BODY

text: inspection;
label: BODY

text: A manner that will protect them from weather-related conditions such as flooding and
label: BODY

text: freezing; and
label: BODY

text: Compliance with applicable safety regulations.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Appendix A Page 167
label: BODY

text: Installation standards contained in the most recently published edition of the Pacific
label: BODY

text: Northwest Section, American Water Works Association (PNWS-AWWA) CCC Manual or
label: BODY

text: the University of Southern California Foundation for Cross-Connection Control and
label: BODY

text: Hydraulic Research (USCFCCCHR) CCC Manual shall be followed unless the
label: BODY

text: manufacturer’s requirements are more stringent.  [Optional Alternative: “Installation shall
label: BODY

text: conform to standard construction drawings and specifications of the Purveyor.”]
label: BODY

text: The Purveyor has no regulatory responsibility or authority over the installation and
label: BODY

text: operation of the customer's plumbing system.  The customer is solely responsible for
label: BODY

text: compliance with all applicable regulations and for prevention of contamination of his
label: BODY

text: plumbing system from sources within his/her premises.  Any action taken by the Purveyor
label: BODY

text: to survey plumbing, inspect or test backflow prevention assemblies, or to require premises
label: BODY

text: isolation (installation of DCVA or RPBA on service) is solely for the purposes of reducing
label: BODY

text: the risk of contamination of the Purveyor's distribution system.
label: BODY

text: The Purveyor will inform the customer that any action taken by the Purveyor shall not be
label: BODY

text: construed by the customer as guidance on the safety or reliability of the customer’s
label: BODY

text: plumbing system.  The Purveyor will not provide advice to the customer on the design and
label: BODY

text: installation of plumbing other than through the general public education program discussed
label: BODY

text: in Element 8.
label: BODY

text: Except for easements containing the Purveyor's distribution system, the Purveyor will not
label: BODY

text: undertake work on the customer's premises.
label: BODY

text: Element 4:
label: BODY

text: Provision of qualified personnel, including at least one person certified as a CCS, to

text: develop and implement the CCC program.

text: 1. Program Administration: The responsibility for administration of the CCC Program rests
label: BODY

text: with the Purveyor.  General policy direction and risk management decisions are established
label: BODY

text: by the {insert name of governing body such as the board of directors, commissioners,
label: BODY

text: town council, etc.}.  [Add for Joint Program: “By an inter-agency agreement, the Local
label: BODY

text: Administrative Authority (LAA) may undertake certain administrative tasks, and the
label: BODY

text: Purveyor may undertake additional tasks to assist the LAA.”]
label: BODY

text: 2. The Purveyor will employ or have on staff at least one person certified by DOH as a CCS to
label: BODY

text: develop and implement the CCC program.  As an alternative, or when no staff or employees
label: BODY

text: are properly qualified, the Purveyor may retain a DOH-certified CCS on contract to provide
label: BODY

text: the necessary expertise and services.
label: BODY

text: 3. The following cross-connection related tasks will be performed by or under the direction of
label: BODY

text: the Purveyor’s certified CCS (on staff or under contract):
label: BODY

text: Preparation of and recommendations regarding changes to the CCC program;
label: BODY

text: Performance of and/or reviews of CCC hazard evaluations;
label: BODY

text: Recommendations on the type of backflow preventer to be installed;
label: BODY

text: Recommendations on schedules for retrofitting of backflow preventers;
label: BODY

text: Inspections of backflow preventers for proper application and installation;
label: BODY

text: Reviews of backflow preventer inspection and test reports;
label: BODY

text: Reviews of backflow testing quality control information;
label: BODY

text: Recommendations and/or the granting of exceptions to mandatory premises isolation;
label: BODY

text: Participation in or cooperation with other water utility staff in the investigation of
label: BODY

text: backflow incidents and other water quality problems;
label: BODY

text: Completion of Backflow Incident Reports; and
label: BODY

text: Completion of CCC Activity and Program Summary Reports.
label: BODY

text: 4. The Purveyor may delegate other CCC program activities to other personnel who are not
label: BODY

text: certified CCSs, including clerical support staff.  These activities include:

text: Mailing of assembly testing notices;

text: Receiving and screening of assembly testing reports;

text: CCC program database administration and record keeping;

text: Dissemination of public education material; and
label: BODY

text: Assisting tasks associated with coordination with the LAA.

text: 1. Inspection and Testing of Backflow Preventers

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: degree of hazard).
label: BODY

text: Either a DOH-certified CCS or backflow assembly tester (BAT) will perform
label: BODY

text: inspections of backflow preventers for correct installation.
label: BODY

text: A DOH-certified backflow assembly tester will test all assemblies relied upon by the
label: BODY

text: Purveyor to protect the public water system.
label: BODY

text: 2. Frequency of Inspection and Testing
label: H4

text: Inspection and testing of backflow preventers will be conducted:
label: BODY

text: • At the time of installation;
label: BODY

text: • Annually after installation;
label: BODY

text: After a backflow incident; and
label: BODY

text: After repair, reinstallation, relocation, or re-plumbing.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Appendix A Page 170
label: BODY

text: The Purveyor may require a backflow preventer to be inspected and/or tested more
label: BODY

text: frequently than once a year, when it protects against a high-health hazard or when it
label: BODY

text: repeatedly fails tests or inspections.
label: BODY

text: 3. Responsibility for Inspection and Testing
label: H4

text: The Purveyor will be responsible for inspection and testing of all purveyor-owned backflow
label: BODY

text: preventers.
label: BODY

text: The Purveyor will require the customer to be responsible for inspection and testing of
label: BODY

text: backflow preventers owned by the customer.  The customer shall employ, at customer
label: BODY

text: expense, a DOH-certified BAT [Recommended Optional Alternative: “pre-approved by the
label: BODY

text: Purveyor”] to conduct the inspection and test within the time period specified in the testing
label: BODY

text: notice sent by the Purveyor.  The test report shall be completed and signed by the BAT, then
label: BODY

text: countersigned and returned by the customer to the Purveyor, before the due date specified
label: BODY

text: by the Purveyor.  The customer may request an extension of the due date for returning a test
label: BODY

text: report by submitting a written request to the Purveyor.  The Purveyor may grant one
label: BODY

text: extension up to 90 days.
label: BODY

text: 4. Approved Test Procedures
label: H4

text: The Purveyor will require that all assemblies relied upon to protect the public water system
label: BODY

text: be tested in accordance with DOH-approved test procedures as specified in WAC 246-290-
label: BODY

text: 490(7)(d).  Any proposal to use alternate test procedures must be approved by the
label: BODY

text: Purveyor’s CCS.
label: BODY

text: [Optional: “The Purveyor will require all assembly tests to be reported on the form shown
label: BODY

text: in Appendix {PWS insert letter here} and returned as specified above.”]
label: BODY

text: 5. Notification of Inspection and/or Testing
label: H4

text: The Purveyor will notify in writing all customers who own backflow preventers that are
label: BODY

text: relied upon to protect the public water system to have their backflow preventer(s) inspected
label: BODY

text: and/or tested.  Notices will be sent out not less than 30 days before the due date of the
label: BODY

text: inspection and/or test.  The notice will also specify the date (up to 30 days after the due date
label: BODY

text: of the inspection and/or test date) by which the inspection/test report must be received by the
label: BODY

text: Purveyor.
label: BODY

text: 6. Enforcement
label: H4

text: When a customer fails to send in the inspection/test report within 15 days after the due date
label: BODY

text: specified, and the Purveyor has not approved an extension to the due date, the Purveyor will
label: BODY

text: take the following enforcement action:
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Appendix A Page 171
label: BODY

text: The Purveyor will send a second notice giving the customer an additional 15 days to
label: BODY

text: send in the inspection/test report.
label: BODY

text: If the customer has not sent in the inspection/test report within 10 days of the due date
label: BODY

text: given in the second notice, the Purveyor will send a third notice, by certified mail,
label: BODY

text: [Optional: “or by hand delivery,”] giving the customer an additional 15 days to send in
label: BODY

text: the report.  The notice will also inform the customer that failure to satisfactorily respond
label: BODY

text: to this notice will result in water service shut-off.
label: BODY

text: The Purveyor will send copies of the third notice to the owner and occupants of the
label: BODY

text: premises (if different from the customer) and to the LAA.
label: BODY

text: If the owner and/or occupants have not responded satisfactorily to the Purveyor within
label: BODY

text: 10 days of the due date specified in the third notice, the Purveyor will implement water
label: BODY

text: service shut-off procedures.
label: BODY

text: [Optional Procedure Prior to Shut-Off: “The Purveyor will offer to arrange for the
label: BODY

text: inspection and/or testing of the customer-owned backflow preventers by a certified BAT
label: BODY

text: and will bill the customer the actual or typical cost of inspection and/or testing in the
label: BODY

text: service area plus reasonable administrative costs.  Collection and enforcement
label: BODY

text: procedures for such charges will be the same as for other water utility charges.”]

text: Element 7:
label: BODY

text: Development and implementation (when appropriate) of procedures for responding
label: BODY

text: to backflow incidents.
label: BODY

text: 1. Backflow Incident Response Plan
label: H4

text: The Purveyor's CCS will participate in developing a backflow incident response plan that
label: BODY

text: will be part of the water system’s emergency response program as required by WAC 246-
label: BODY

text: 290-415(2).  The incident response plan will include, but will not be limited to:
label: BODY

text: Notification of affected population;
label: BODY

text: Notification and coordination with other agencies, such as DOH, the LAA, and the local
label: BODY

text: health jurisdiction;
label: BODY

text: Identification of the source of contamination;
label: BODY

text: Isolation of the source of contamination and the affected area(s);
label: BODY

text: Cleaning, flushing, and other measures to mitigate and correct the problem; and
label: BODY

text: Apply corrective action to prevent future backflow occurrences.

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004

text: Appendix A Page 173

label: BODY

text: Development and implementation of a cross-connection control public education
label: BODY

text: program.

text: 1. Customer Education
label: H4

text: The Purveyor will distribute with water bills or some other means, at regular intervals,
label: BODY

text: public education brochures to system customers.  For residential customers, such brochures
label: BODY

text: will describe the cross-connection hazards in homes and the recommended assemblies or
label: BODY

text: devices that should be installed by the homeowner to reduce the hazard to the public water
label: BODY

text: system.  The education program will emphasize the responsibility of the customer in
label: BODY

text: preventing the contamination of the public water supply.  The Purveyor’s staff will produce
label: BODY

text: the public education brochures or the Purveyor will obtain brochures from:
label: BODY

text: PNWS-AWWA;
label: BODY

text: Spokane Regional Cross-Connection Control Committee (SRC4);
label: BODY

text: Western Washington Cross-Connection Prevention Professionals Group (The Group);
label: BODY

text: USC FCCCHR;
label: BODY

text: Other national backflow prevention associations, such as the American Backflow
label: BODY

text: Prevention Association (ABPA); and/or
label: BODY

text: Other water utilities.
label: BODY

text: The information distributed by the Purveyor will include, but not be limited to, the following
label: BODY

text: subjects:
label: BODY

text: Cross-connection hazards in general;
label: BODY

text: Irrigation system hazards and corrective actions;
label: BODY

text: Fire sprinkler cross-connection hazards;
label: BODY

text: Importance of annual inspection and/or testing of backflow preventers; and
label: BODY

text: Thermal expansion in hot water systems when backflow preventers are installed for
label: BODY

text: premises isolation.
label: BODY

text: The Purveyor will distribute information brochures to all customers every two to three years,
label: BODY

text: and to every new customer at the time the service agreement is signed.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: • Backflow incident known by the Purveyor to have contaminated the public water
label: BODY

text: system or a customer’s plumbing system.

text: 4. Prohibition of Return of Used Water.  The PWS must prohibit the intentional return of used
label: H4

label: BODY

text: system from customers with multiple connections.

text: potential return of used water, to install a backflow preventer (DCVA or RPBA)

text: Relationship to Other Planning and Operations Program Requirements
label: BODY

text: The Purveyor will consider the requirements and consequences of the CCC program on the utility’s
label: BODY

text: planning and operations requirements.  Such considerations include, but are not limited to ensuring:

text: • And promoting adequate communication between CCC program personnel and other wa-
label: BODY

text: ter utility staff;

label: BODY

text: trol problems;

text: program.

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems

text: March 2004

text: Appendix A Page 179
label: BODY

text: Resolution No. ________
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control Policy
label: BODY

text: Finding of Fact
label: BODY

text: Whereas it is the responsibility of a water purveyor to provide water to the customer at the meter
label: BODY

text: that meets Washington state water quality standards;
label: BODY

text: Whereas it is the water purveyor's responsibility to prevent the contamination of the public water
label: BODY

text: system from the source of supply (i.e., to the customer's connection to the service pipe or meter);
label: BODY

text: Whereas it is a requirement of the Washington State Department of Health (DOH) for the Purveyor
label: BODY

text: to establish a cross connection-control program satisfactory to DOH;
label: BODY

text: Whereas cross-connections within the customer's plumbing system pose a potential source for the
label: BODY

text: contamination of the public water supply system;
label: BODY

text: Now be it resolved that the {Insert PWS name}, hereinafter referred to as the Purveyor, establishes
label: BODY

text: the following service policy to protect the purveyor-owned water system from the risk of
label: BODY

text: contamination.  For public health and safety, this policy shall apply equally to all new and existing
label: BODY

text: customers.
label: BODY

text: Definitions
label: BODY

text: Unless otherwise defined, all terms used in this resolution pertaining to cross-connection control
label: BODY

text: have the same definitions as those contained in WAC 246-290-010 of the Washington State
label: BODY

text: Drinking Water Regulations.
label: BODY

text: Prevention of Contamination
label: BODY

text: The customer's plumbing system, starting from the termination of the Purveyor's water service pipe,
label: BODY

text: shall be considered a potential high-health hazard requiring the isolation of the customer's premises
label: BODY

text: by a DOH-approved, customer-installed and maintained reduced-pressure principle backflow
label: BODY

text: assembly (RPBA) or reduced-pressure detector assembly (RPDA).  The RPBA or RPDA shall be
label: BODY

text: located at the end of the Purveyor's water service pipe (i.e., immediately downstream of the meter).
label: BODY

text: Water shall only be supplied to the customer through a DOH-approved, customer-installed and
label: BODY

text: maintained RPBA or RPDA.
label: BODY

text: Notwithstanding the aforesaid, the Purveyor, upon an assessment of the risk of contamination posed
label: BODY

text: by the customer's plumbing system and use of water, may allow:
label: BODY

text: A single-family or duplex residential customer to connect directly to the water service pipe,
label: BODY

text: i.e., without a purveyor-approved DCVA or RPBA.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Appendix A Page 180
label: BODY

text: Any customer other than a single-family or duplex residential customer, as a minimum, to
label: BODY

text: be supplied through a DOH-approved, customer-installed and maintained double-check
label: BODY

text: valve assembly (DCVA) or double-check detector assembly (DCDA).
label: BODY

text: [Add for Combination or Joint Program: “Any customer, other than a single-family or
label: BODY

text: duplex residential customer to connect directly to the water service pipe (i.e., without a

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Conditions for Providing Service
label: BODY

text: Water service is provided based on the following terms and limitations:
label: BODY

text: 1. The customer agrees to take all measures necessary to prevent the contamination of the
label: BODY

text: plumbing system within his/her premises and the Purveyor's distribution system that may
label: BODY

text: occur from backflow through a cross connection.  These measures shall include the
label: BODY

text: prevention of backflow under any backpressure or backsiphonage condition, including the
label: BODY

text: disruption of the water supply from the Purveyor's system that may occur during routine
label: BODY

text: system maintenance or during emergency conditions, such as a water main break.
label: BODY

text: 2. The customer agrees to install, operate, and maintain at all times his plumbing system in
label: BODY

text: compliance with the current edition of the Uniform Plumbing Code having jurisdiction as it
label: BODY

text: pertains to the prevention of contamination and protection from thermal expansion, due to a
label: BODY

text: closed system that could occur with the present or future installation of backflow preventers
label: BODY

text: on the customer's service and/or at plumbing fixtures.
label: BODY

text: 3. For cross-connection control or other public health-related surveys, the customer agrees to
label: BODY

text: provide for the Purveyor’s employees or agents free access to all parts of the premises
label: BODY

text: during reasonable working hours of the day for routine surveys and at all times during
label: BODY

text: emergencies.
label: BODY

text: Where agreement for free access for the Purveyor's survey is denied, the Purveyor may
label: BODY

text: supply water service provided that premises isolation is provided through a DOH- approved
label: BODY

text: reduced-pressure principle backflow assembly (RPBA).
label: BODY

text: 4. The customer agrees to install all backflow prevention assemblies requested by the Purveyor
label: BODY

text: and to maintain those assemblies in good working order.  The assemblies shall be of a type,
label: BODY

text: size, and make approved by DOH and acceptable to the Purveyor.  The assemblies shall be
label: BODY

text: installed in accordance with the recommendations given in the most recently published
label: BODY

text: edition of the Cross Connection Control Manual, Accepted Procedures and Practice,
label: BODY

text: published by the Pacific Northwest Section, American Water Works Association, or latest
label: BODY

text: edition thereof. [Optional Wording: “The assemblies shall be installed in accordance with
label: BODY

text: the Purveyor’s construction standards and specifications.”]
label: BODY

text: 5. The customer agrees to:
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Appendix A Page 181
label: BODY

text: Have all assemblies (e.g., RPBAs and/or DCVAs) that the Purveyor relies upon to
label: BODY

text: protect the public water distribution system tested upon installation, annually
label: BODY

text: thereafter and/or more frequently if requested by the Purveyor, after repair, and after
label: BODY

text: relocation;
label: BODY

text: Have all testing done by a purveyor-approved and currently DOH-certified Backflow
label: BODY

text: Assembly Tester (BAT);
label: BODY

text: Have the RPBA or DCVA tested in accordance with DOH-approved test procedures;
label: BODY

text: and
label: BODY

text: Submit to the Purveyor the results of the test(s) on Purveyor-supplied test report forms
label: BODY

text: within the time period specified by the Purveyor.
label: BODY

text: 6. The customer agrees to bear all costs for the aforementioned installation, testing, repair,
label: BODY

text: maintenance and replacement of the RPBA, RPDA, DCVA or DCDA installed to protect
label: BODY

text: the Purveyor's distribution system.
label: BODY

text: 7. At the time of application for service, if required by the Purveyor, the customer agrees to
label: BODY

text: submit to the Purveyor plumbing plans and/or a cross-connection control survey of the
label: BODY

text: premises conducted by a purveyor-approved and DOH-certified Cross-Connection Con-
label: BODY

text: trol Specialist (CCS).
label: BODY

text: The cross-connection control survey shall assess the cross-connection hazards and list the
label: BODY

text: backflow preventers provided within the premises.  The results of the survey shall be
label: BODY

text: submitted prior to the Purveyor turning on water service to a new customer.  The cost of
label: BODY

text: the survey shall be borne by the customer.
label: BODY

text: 8. For classes of customers other than single-family residential, when required by the
label: BODY

text: Purveyor, the customer agrees to periodically submit a cross-connection control re-survey of
label: BODY

text: the premises by a DOH-certified CCS acceptable to the Purveyor.  The Purveyor may
label: BODY

text: require the re-survey to be performed in response to changes in the customer's plumbing or
label: BODY

text: water use, or performed periodically (annually or less frequently) where the Purveyor
label: BODY

text: considers the customer's plumbing system to be complex or subject to frequent changes in
label: BODY

text: water use.  The cost of the re-survey shall be borne by the customer.
label: BODY

text: 9. Within 30 days of a request by the Purveyor, a residential customer shall agree to complete
label: BODY

text: and submit to the Purveyor a "Water Use Questionnaire" for the purpose of surveying the
label: BODY

text: health hazard posed by the customer's plumbing system on the Purveyor's distribution
label: BODY

text: system.  Further, the residential customer agrees to provide within 30 days of a request by
label: BODY

text: the Purveyor a cross-connection control survey of the premises by a DOH-certified CCS
label: BODY

text: acceptable to the Purveyor.
label: BODY

text: 10. The customer agrees to obtain the prior approval from the Purveyor for all changes in water
label: BODY

text: use, and alterations and additions to the plumbing system, and shall comply with any
label: BODY

text: additional requirements imposed by the Purveyor for cross-connection control.
label: BODY

text: 11. The customer agrees to immediately notify the Purveyor and the local health jurisdiction of
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Appendix A Page 182
label: BODY

text: any backflow incident occurring within the customer’s premises (i.e., entry of any
label: BODY

text: contaminant/pollutant into the drinking water) and shall cooperate fully with the Purveyor to
label: BODY

text: determine the reason for the backflow incident.
label: BODY

text: 12. The customer acknowledges the right of the Purveyor to discontinue the water supply within
label: BODY

text: 72 hours of giving notice to the customer, or a lesser period of time if required to protect
label: BODY

text: public health, if the customer fails to cooperate with the Purveyor in the survey of premises,
label: BODY

text: in the installation, maintenance, repair, inspection, or testing of backflow prevention
label: BODY

text: assemblies or air gaps required by the Purveyor, or in the Purveyor's effort to contain a
label: BODY

text: contaminant or pollutant that is detected in the customer's system.
label: BODY

text: Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, in lieu of discontinuing water service, the
label: BODY

text: Purveyor may install an RPBA on the service pipe to provide premises isolation, and
label: BODY

text: recover all costs for the installation and subsequent maintenance and repair of the assembly,
label: BODY

text: appurtenances, and enclosure from the customer as fees and charges for water.  The failure
label: BODY

text: of the customer to pay these fees and charges may result in termination of water service in
label: BODY

text: accordance with the Purveyor's water billing policies.
label: BODY

text: 13. [Add for Combination or Joint Program: “The Purveyor will require premises isolation for
label: BODY

text: a customer that is of the high-hazard type or category requiring "Mandatory Premises
label: BODY

text: Isolation" established by the DOH regulations (Table 9, WAC 246-290-490).”]
label: BODY

text: 14. Where the Purveyor imposes mandatory premises isolation in compliance with DOH
label: BODY

text: regulations, or agrees to the customer's voluntary premises isolation through the installation
label: BODY

text: of a RPBA immediately downstream of the Purveyor's water meter, the customer
label: BODY

text: acknowledges his obligation to comply with the other cross-connection control regulations
label: BODY

text: having jurisdiction (i.e., Uniform Plumbing Code).  Although the Purveyor's requirements
label: BODY

text: for installation, testing, and repair of backflow assemblies may be limited to the RPBAs
label: BODY

text: used for premises isolation, the customer agrees to the other terms herein as a condition of
label: BODY

text: allowing a direct connection to the Purveyor's service pipe.
label: BODY

text: 15. The customer agrees to indemnify and hold harmless the Purveyor for all contamination of
label: BODY

text: the customer's plumbing system or the Purveyor's distribution system that results from an
label: BODY

text: unprotected or inadequately protected cross connection within the customer’s premises.
label: BODY

text: This indemnification shall pertain to all backflow conditions that may arise from the
label: BODY

text: Purveyor's suspension of water supply or reduction of water pressure, recognizing that the
label: BODY

text: air gap separation otherwise required would require the customer to provide adequate
label: BODY

text: facilities to collect, store, and pump water for his/her premises.
label: BODY

text: 16. The customer agrees that, in the event legal action is required and commenced between the
label: BODY

text: Purveyor and the customer to enforce the terms and conditions herein, the substantially
label: BODY

text: prevailing party shall be entitled to reimbursement of all incurred costs and expenses
label: BODY

text: including, but not limited to, reasonable attorney's fees as determined by the Court.
label: BODY

text: 17. The customer acknowledges that the Purveyor's survey of a customer's premises is for the
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Appendix A Page 183
label: BODY

text: sole purpose of establishing the Purveyor's minimum requirements for the protection of the
label: BODY

text: public water supply system, commensurate with the Purveyor's assessment of the degree of
label: BODY

text: hazard.
label: BODY

text: It shall not be assumed by the customer or any regulatory agency that the Purveyor's survey,
label: BODY

text: requirements for the installation of backflow prevention assemblies, lack of requirements for
label: BODY

text: the installation of backflow prevention assemblies, or other actions by the Purveyor’s
label: BODY

text: personnel constitute an approval of the customer's plumbing system or an assurance to the
label: BODY

text: customer of the absence of cross connections therein.
label: BODY

text: 18. The customer acknowledges the right of the Purveyor, in keeping with changes to
label: BODY

text: Washington State regulations, industry standards, or the Purveyor's risk management
label: BODY

text: policies, to impose retroactive requirements for additional cross-connection control
label: BODY

text: measures.
label: BODY

text: Appendix B

text: Example Cross-Connection Control Program
label: BODY

text: for a Non-Community System
label: BODY

text: Contents
label: BODY

text: Appendix B contains an example written cross-connection control (CCC) program plan and an
label: BODY

text: example legal instrument for a non-community system.
label: BODY

text: How to Use Appendix B
label: HH3

text: The documents in Appendix B have been arranged and formatted for ease of review by the
label: BODY

text: Washington State Department of Health (DOH) when it evaluates the CCC program with respect
label: BODY

text: to the regulations.  Therefore, DOH recommends that purveyors follow the format (i.e., use as a
label: BODY

text: template) whenever possible.  However, public water systems are not required to use the exam-
label: BODY

text: ple program and legal instrument.  DOH recognizes that some PWSs may have a particular ap-
label: BODY

text: proach or institutional requirements that may dictate a different format or wording in the written
label: BODY

text: program.
label: BODY

text: Description of Typical Non-Community Systems
label: BODY

text: The majority of non-community water systems, in addition to the definitions in the Drinking Water
label: BODY

text: Regulations, Chapter 246-290 WAC, have the following characteristics:
label: BODY

text: The water system owner (purveyor) serves his/her own facilities; and
label: BODY

text: The consumers are the occupants or users (employees, students, patrons, visitors, etc.) of the
label: BODY

text: facilities.
label: BODY

text: Examples of Non-Community Water Systems
label: BODY

text: Non-community water systems of this type include, but are not limited to:
label: BODY

text: Schools, colleges, day care centers, and similar institutions;
label: BODY

text: Clinics, hospitals, public parks, golf courses, fairgrounds, and playgrounds;
label: BODY

text: Hotels, motels, resorts, campgrounds, RV parks and highway rest areas;
label: BODY

text: Businesses such as stores, nurseries, service stations, restaurants and laundromats; and
label: BODY

text: Industrial plants, food processing facilities, shellfish processors, and temporary farm worker
label: BODY

text: housing.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Appendix B
label: BODY

text: Page 186
label: BODY

text: Community Systems with Non-Community System Characteristics
label: BODY

text: Some community water systems have characteristics similar to non-community systems, i.e., the
label: BODY

text: water system owner (purveyor) serves his/her own facilities, and the consumers are the occupants or
label: BODY

text: users of the facilities.
label: BODY

text: Examples of such community systems are those that serve long-term occupants such as:
label: BODY

text: Educational institutions with dormitories or student and staff residences;
label: BODY

text: Nursing homes, retirement centers and mental institutions;
label: BODY

text: Correctional institutions such as prisons;
label: BODY

text: Mobile home parks and apartment complexes; and
label: BODY

text: Military bases with barracks or other personnel housing.
label: BODY

text: For CCC program purposes, community systems with non-community system characteristics, such
label: BODY

text: as the examples listed above, should develop and implement a program similar to the example CCC
label: BODY

text: program for non-community water systems provided in this Appendix.
label: BODY

text: Non-Community Systems with Community System Characteristics
label: BODY

text: Some non-community water systems may have both non-community and community systems
label: BODY

text: characteristics.  For example, some non-community systems serve developments where there is a
label: BODY

text: mix of recreational and residential connections.  In this example, the Purveyor owns the recreational
label: BODY

text: facilities, but the residential connections are privately owned.
label: BODY

text: Non-community systems with characteristics of community and non-community systems should
label: BODY

text: base their written programs primarily on Appendix B.  However, the relevant elements of Appendix
label: BODY

text: A (or the DOH Very Small Water System CCC Guidance) should be incorporated into the
label: BODY

text: Appendix B program plan where applicable (to address CCC issues for the non-purveyor owned
label: BODY

text: connections).
label: BODY

text: Instructions
label: BODY

text: To use the example program plan, non-community water systems are encouraged to:
label: BODY

text: 1. Copy the example program file into Word (download from the web-site or obtain from
label: BODY

text: DOH electronically);
label: BODY

text: 2. Retain the basic formatting and text of the example program and fill in the blanks, deci-
label: BODY

text: sion table and check boxes where indicated to “customize” the example program;
label: BODY

text: 3. Include or delete optional and/or additional language shown in the example program to
label: BODY

text: reflect system-specific decisions; and
label: BODY

text: 4. Insert the completed written CCC program in the Small Water System Management Pro-
label: BODY

text: gram (SWSMP) or Water System Plan (WSP).
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control Program
label: BODY

text: Requirement for Program
label: BODY

text: The {Insert PWS name and ID number} hereinafter referred to as “the Purveyor”, has the
label: BODY

text: responsibility to protect the public water systems from contamination due to cross connections.  A
label: BODY

text: cross connection may be defined as "Any actual or potential physical connection between a potable
label: BODY

text: water line and any pipe, vessel, or machine that contains or has a probability of containing a non-
label: BODY

text: potable gas or liquid, such that it is possible for a non-potable gas or liquid to enter the potable
label: BODY

text: water system by backflow.”
label: BODY

text: All public water systems are required to develop and implement cross-connection control (CCC)
label: BODY

text: programs.  The CCC requirements are contained in WAC 246-290-490 of the Group A Drinking
label: BODY

text: Water Regulations.  The minimum required elements of a CCC program are as follows:
label: BODY

text: 1. Establishment of legal authority and program policies;
label: BODY

text: 2. Evaluation of premises for cross-connection hazards;
label: BODY

text: 3. Elimination and/or control of cross connections;
label: BODY

text: 4. Provision of qualified personnel;
label: BODY

text: 5. Inspection and testing of backflow preventers;
label: BODY

text: 6. Quality control of testing process;
label: BODY

text: 7. Response to backflow incidents;
label: BODY

text: 8. Public education for consumers;
label: BODY

text: 9. Record keeping for CCC program; and
label: BODY

text: 10. Special requirements for reclaimed water use.
label: BODY

text: Other requirements of a CCC program include:
label: BODY

text: 1. Coordination with the Local Administrative Authority (LAA), i.e. the local building or
label: BODY

text: plumbing official, regarding CCC activities;
label: BODY

text: 2. Inclusion of a written CCC program in a WSP or SWSMP; and
label: BODY

text: 3. Prohibition of the intentional return of used water.
label: BODY

text: Program Objectives
label: BODY

text: The objectives of the CCC program are to:
label: BODY

text: Reasonably reduce the risk of contamination of the source of supply and water distribution
label: BODY

text: system; and
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Appendix B
label: BODY

text: Page 188
label: BODY

text: Comply with the applicable plumbing code and other regulations pertaining to the
label: BODY

text: construction and operation of the Purveyor’s facilities.

label: BODY

text: Authority - The Purveyor is the owner and operator of all facilities on the premises.  By stated
label: BODY

text: policy [Alternate Wording if Applicable: “ resolution by the {Insert name of governing
label: BODY

text: body}”], the Purveyor is authorized and mandated to protect the water system from
label: BODY

text: of this CCC program.

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Hazard Assessments
label: BODY

text: 1. Initial Hazard Assessment
label: BODY

text: a. Existing Facilities/Systems - The Purveyor will ensure that a DOH certified cross-
label: BODY

text: connection control specialist (CCS) conducts an initial cross-connection hazard
label: BODY

text: evaluation of the {Insert PWS name} Water System within six months after adoption of
label: BODY

text: this CCC program.
label: BODY

text: Program Adoption Date:____________ Initial Hazard Survey Date:_____________
label: BODY

text: b. New Facilities/Systems – The Purveyor will ensure that a DOH-certified CCS conducts
label: BODY

text: an initial cross-connection hazard evaluation, before water service is provided to any
label: BODY

text: new facilities, irrigation systems etc. served by the water system.
label: BODY

text: 2. Periodic Resurveys – The Purveyor will ensure that a DOH-certified CCS periodically
label: BODY

text: resurveys for cross-connection hazards the {Insert PWS name} Water System.  Resurveys
label: BODY

text: will be conducted:
label: BODY

text: a. Every 2 years after the initial hazard survey {insert alternate frequency if appropriate};
label: BODY

text: and
label: BODY

text: b. Upon any changes in use of the premises, plumbing or distribution facilities.

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004

text: Appendix B

text: Page 190

text: Element 3:
label: BODY

text: Development and implementation of procedures and schedules for elimination
label: BODY

text: and/or control of cross connections.
label: BODY

text: Policy - The following procedures apply to all new and existing buildings or areas of water use in
label: BODY

text: the {Insert PWS name} Water System:
label: BODY

text: 1. Mandatory Premises Isolation for High-hazard Buildings, Facilities or Systems – The
label: BODY

text: Purveyor will ensure that water services to all buildings, facilities or systems of the type
label: BODY

text: described in Table 9 of WAC 246-290-490 (i.e., high hazard) are isolated by a DOH-
label: BODY

text: approved reduced pressure backflow assembly (RPBA).
label: BODY

text: 2. Compliance with Uniform Plumbing Code/Additional Premises Isolation Requirements –
label: BODY

text: The Purveyor will ensure that all buildings or areas of water use:
label: BODY

text: a. Comply with the current plumbing code (amended for Washington) adopted by the State
label: BODY

text: Building Code Council; and
label: BODY

text: b. [Purveyor’s Optional Additional Language “Be isolated with an approved double
label: BODY

text: check valve assembly (DCVA), where the CCS believes the plumbing code does not
label: BODY

text: provide protection commensurate with the assessed degree of hazard.”]
label: BODY

text: 3. Plumbing/Water System Design – The Purveyor will ensure that the design of the plumbing
label: BODY

text: and/or water system incorporates DOH-approved backflow prevention assemblies
label: BODY

text: appropriate for the degree of hazard assessed by the Purveyor’s CCS.  Initial
label: BODY

text: plumbing/water system design and subsequent design modifications will be subject to
label: BODY

text: review by a DOH-certified CCS for cross-connection hazards.
label: BODY

text: 4. Approved Backflow Assemblies - The Purveyor will ensure that DOH-approved backflow
label: BODY

text: prevention assemblies protect the public water system from contamination.  DOH-approved
label: BODY

text: assemblies are assemblies that appear on DOH's published list of Backflow Prevention
label: BODY

text: Assemblies Approved for Installation in Washington State.  The Purveyor will keep on file
label: BODY

text: documentation regarding the approval status of all backflow assemblies installed to protect
label: BODY

text: the public water system.
label: BODY

text: 5. Installation Standards – The Purveyor will ensure that all approved backflow preventers are
label: BODY

text: installed in:
label: BODY

text: • The orientation for which they are approved;
label: BODY

text: • A manner and location that facilitates their proper operation, maintenance, and testing
label: BODY

text: or inspection, and in compliance with safety regulations;
label: BODY

text: • A manner and location that protects them from flooding and freezing; and
label: BODY

text: • Accordance with the installation standards outlined in the most recently published
label: BODY

text: editions of the PNWS-AWWA Cross-Connection Control Manual, or the USC-
label: BODY

text: FCCCHR Manual Of Cross-Connection Control, unless the manufacturer’s require-
label: BODY

text: ments are more stringent.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Appendix B
label: BODY

text: Page 191
label: BODY

text: Element 4:
label: BODY

text: Provision of qualified personnel, including at least one person certified as a CCS, to
label: BODY

text: develop and implement the cross-connection control program.
label: BODY

text: 1. Program Administration - The Purveyor or his authorized agent is responsible for
label: BODY

text: administration of the CCC program.
label: BODY

text: 2. DOH-Certified CCS – The Purveyor will employ, or have available on staff, at least one
label: BODY

text: person certified by DOH as a CCS to develop and implement the CCC program.  When no
label: BODY

text: staff or employees are qualified, the Purveyor will retain a DOH-certified CCS on contract
label: BODY

text: to provide the necessary expertise and services.
label: BODY

text: 3. CCS Duties – The Purveyor will ensure that a DOH-certified CCS does the following:
label: BODY

text: Performs CCC hazard evaluations;
label: BODY

text: Determines the type of backflow preventer to be installed;
label: BODY

text: Inspects backflow preventers (to ensure protection is provided commensurate for the
label: BODY

text: degree of hazard, for correct installation and for approval status);
label: BODY

text: Reviews assembly test reports;
label: BODY

text: Reports and investigates backflow incidents; and
label: BODY

text: Completes reports (Annual Activities, Program Summary and Exception Reports)
label: BODY

text: required by WAC 246-290-490 and submits them upon request to DOH.
label: BODY

text: 4. Current CCS Information – The following table(s) shows information related to the CCS(s)
label: BODY

text: currently responsible for development, implementation and oversight of the Purveyor’s
label: BODY

text: CCC program:
label: BODY

text: Name of CCS
label: BODY

text: Address
label: BODY

text: City, State, Zip
label: BODY

text: Telephone Number
label: BODY

text: CCS Certification Number
label: BODY

text: {Insert or attach additional tables, if the Purveyor has more than one CCS that is involved
label: BODY

text: with CCC program implementation.}
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems

text: March 2004

text: Page 192

text: Element 5:
label: BODY

text: Development and implementation of procedures to ensure that approved backflow
label: BODY

text: preventers are inspected and/or tested (as applicable).
label: BODY

text: 1. Backflow Preventer Inspection and Testing – The Purveyor will ensure that all backflow
label: BODY

text: preventers in the {Insert PWS name} Water System are inspected and tested in accordance
label: BODY

text: with WAC 246-290-490.  The Purveyor will arrange to have all backflow preventers
label: BODY

text: inspected and tested (if applicable):
label: BODY

text: At the time of installation;
label: BODY

text: Annually after installation (minimum frequency) or more frequently;
label: BODY

text: After a backflow incident; and
label: BODY

text: After an assembly is repaired, reinstalled or relocated (or air gap re-plumbed).
label: BODY

text: 2. DOH-Approved Test Procedures - Per WAC 246-290-490 (7)(d), the Purveyor will ensure
label: BODY

text: that all assemblies protecting the public water system from contamination are tested in
label: BODY

text: accordance with DOH-approved field test procedures.
label: BODY

text: Element 6:
label: BODY

text: Development and implementation of a backflow prevention assembly testing quality
label: BODY

text: control assurance program.
label: BODY

text: 1. DOH-Certified Backflow Assembly Tester (BAT) Required - The Purveyor will ensure that
label: BODY

text: a DOH-certified BAT tests all backflow assemblies that protect the public water system
label: BODY

text: from contamination.
label: BODY

text: 2. BAT Documentation Requirements - Prior to engaging a BAT to test assemblies within the
label: BODY

text: water system, the Purveyor will require the tester to document that he/she:
label: BODY

text: a. Is currently certified by DOH as a BAT;
label: BODY

text: b. Has appropriate assembly testing equipment (make, model and serial number); and
label: BODY

text: c. Has had the testing equipment verified for accuracy and/or calibrated within the past 12
label: BODY

text: months.
label: BODY

text: 3. Alternate BAT Approach - In lieu of the above documentation, the Purveyor will engage a
label: BODY

text: BAT who is currently on an “Approved” list developed by a public water system of 1000
label: BODY

text: connections or more having a BAT quality assurance program acceptable to DOH (i.e., that
label: BODY

text: as a minimum meets the BAT documentation requirements stated above).  {If this option is
label: BODY

text: chosen, identify the name of the public water system whose list is used.}
label: BODY

text: [Optional Alternative Language: “The Purveyor will employ one or more DOH-certified
label: BODY

text: BATs.  The Purveyor will ensure that the BATs are currently certified, maintain their
label: BODY

text: certifications in good standing, and that all testing equipment is of the appropriate type and
label: BODY

text: is verified for accuracy and calibrated, if needed, at least once annually.”]
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Appendix B
label: BODY

text: Page 193
label: BODY

text: 4. Quality Assurance – The Purveyor’s CCS will review within 30 days of receipt
label: BODY

text: inspection/test report forms submitted by the BAT and follow-up on any reports that are
label: BODY

text: found to be deficient in any way.
label: BODY

text: Element 7:
label: BODY

text: Development and implementation (when appropriate) of procedures for responding
label: BODY

text: to backflow incidents.
label: BODY

text: 1. Backflow Incident Response Plan - The Purveyor will develop a Backflow Incident
label: BODY

text: Response Plan in consultation with the Purveyor’s CCS.  It will be included:
label: BODY

text: a. In the {Insert PWS name} Water System’s overall emergency plan.
label: BODY

text: b. {Optional language: “In the CCC plan”}.
label: BODY

text: The incident response plan will include, but not be limited to:
label: BODY

text: Notification of affected users (employees, occupants, etc.);
label: BODY

text: Notification and cooperation with other agencies, such as DOH, the Local
label: BODY

text: Administrative Authority, and the local health jurisdiction;
label: BODY

text: Identification of the source of contamination;
label: BODY

text: Isolation of the source of contamination and the affected area(s);
label: BODY

text: Provision of alternate supplies of drinking water;
label: BODY

text: Cleaning, flushing and other mitigation measures; and
label: BODY

text: Corrective action to prevent future occurrences.
label: BODY

text: [Optional Alternative:  The Purveyor has developed a Backflow Incident Response Plan and it
label: BODY

text: is included here or in the water system’s overall emergency plan {select whichever is
label: BODY

text: applicable}.]
label: BODY

text: 2. Technical Resources - The Purveyor will use {Optional Alternative: “has used”} the
label: BODY

text: manual, Backflow Incident Investigation Procedures, First Edition, 1996, published by the
label: BODY

text: PNWS-AWWA as a technical resource and/or supplement to the Backflow Incident
label: BODY

text: Response Plan.
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: special cross-connection classes for) staff and other water users as appropriate.  The
label: BODY

text: education program will emphasize the responsibility of the water users in preventing
label: BODY

text: contamination of the water supply.  Information distributed will include, the following
label: BODY

text: subjects (as applicable):

text: 2. Prohibition of Return of Used Water: The water system must prohibit the intentional return
label: BODY

text: of used water to the Purveyor’s distribution system per WAC 246-290-490 (2)(d).
label: BODY

text: a. Definition - Used water is defined as water that has left the control of the Purveyor.
label: BODY

text: b. Used Water Policies - Since the Purveyor owns both the water supply facilities and the
label: BODY

text: plumbing systems, the water has not, technically, left the control of the Purveyor.
label: BODY

text: However, for protection of the drinking water quality and the health of the
label: BODY

text: employees/building occupants, the Purveyor will institute the following policies:
label: BODY

text: Plumbing design or changes will not allow water that has been used for such
label: BODY

text: purposes as heating or cooling to be returned to the drinking water system; and
label: BODY

text: Buildings and facilities with two or more water service connections that are
label: BODY

text: internally connected such as to provide a flow–through condition will have each
label: BODY

text: service isolated by either an RPBA or DCVA, depending upon the level of hazard
label: BODY

text: assessed by the Purveyor’s CCS.
label: BODY

text: Relationship to Other Planning and Program Operations
label: BODY

text: The Purveyor will consider the impacts of the CCC program upon the planning and operations
label: BODY

text: requirements of the {Insert PWS name} Water System.  Such considerations include, but are not
label: BODY

text: limited to, ensuring that:
label: BODY

text: 1. The design of the water distribution system (and plumbing system) provides for expected
label: BODY

text: head losses resulting from installation of backflow assemblies;
label: BODY

text: 2. CCC program personnel are consulted in the design of water and wastewater treatment
label: BODY

text: facilities and when proposals are made to receive or distribute reclaimed water;
label: BODY

text: 3. Operations under normal and abnormal conditions do not result in excessive pressure
label: BODY

text: losses;
label: BODY

text: 4. Cross-connection issues are considered in water quality investigations; and
label: BODY

text: 5. Adequate financial and administrative resources are provided to carry out the CCC pro-
label: BODY

text: gram.

label: BODY

text: Legal Instrument for a Non-community Water System CCC Program
label: BODY

text: Background
label: H4

text: Where the Purveyor owns both the public water system and the facilities served by the water sys-
label: BODY

text: tem (i.e., the plumbing systems up to the free-flowing tap), the Purveyor may already have the
label: BODY

text: legal authority to establish a CCC program.  Proprietors of restaurants or small businesses that
label: BODY

text: have their own water systems are examples where the legal authority already exists.  In such
label: BODY

text: cases, the Purveyor may not require a formal legal instrument, but only a declaration of owner-
label: BODY

text: ship of the system and facilities served and the intent to establish and implement a CCC program
label: BODY

text: consistent with WAC 246-290-490.
label: BODY

text: In other cases, such as school districts, it may be necessary for the governing body (such as the
label: BODY

text: School Board) to adopt a resolution or similar document to establish the authority and intent to
label: BODY

text: adopt and implement a CCC program.  For this reason, a sample resolution for a non-community
label: BODY

text: water system is presented below.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Appendix B
label: BODY

text: Page 199
label: BODY

text: Resolution No. ________
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control Policy
label: BODY

text: Finding of Fact:
label: BODY

text: Whereas it is the responsibility of a water purveyor to provide water that meets Washington State
label: BODY

text: water quality standards to all consumers occupying or visiting the Purveyor’s premises;
label: BODY

text: Whereas it is the water purveyor's responsibility to prevent the contamination of the public water
label: BODY

text: system from the source of supply (i.e., to the customer's connection to the service pipe or meter);
label: BODY

text: Whereas the Purveyor also owns the facilities and the plumbing systems that deliver the water to the
label: BODY

text: consumers;
label: BODY

text: Whereas it is a requirement of the Washington State Department of Health for the Purveyor to
label: BODY

text: establish a cross-connection control program satisfactory to DOH;
label: BODY

text: Now be it resolved that the {Insert PWS name}, hereinafter referred to as “the Purveyor”,
label: BODY

text: establishes the following policy to protect the Purveyor-owned water system and plumbing facilities
label: BODY

text: from the risk of contamination.  For public health and safety, this policy shall apply equally to all
label: BODY

text: new and existing facilities.
label: BODY

text: A.  Definitions
label: HH2

text: Unless otherwise defined, all terms used in this resolution pertaining to cross-connection control
label: BODY

text: have the same definitions as those contained in WAC 246-290-010 of the Washington State
label: BODY

text: Drinking Water Regulations and Chapter 2 of the Uniform Plumbing Code as amended for
label: BODY

text: Washington State (Chapter 51-56 WAC).
label: BODY

text: B.  Administrative Provisions
label: HH3

text: 1. The Purveyor shall engage the services of a Department of Health (DOH) certified cross-
label: BODY

text: connection control specialist (CCS), by employment or by contract, to develop, implement,
label: BODY

text: and be in responsible charge of the {{Insert PWS name} Water System’s CCC program.
label: BODY

text: 2. The Purveyor, under the direction of the CCS as provided for in B-1, shall prepare a written
label: BODY

text: CCC program plan to implement the requirements of this resolution.  The written CCC
label: BODY

text: program plan will be consistent with this resolution and shall comply with the requirements
label: BODY

text: of Chapter 246-290 WAC (Group A Drinking Water Regulations) and with Chapter 51-56
label: BODY

text: WAC (Uniform Plumbing Code as amended for Washington).
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Appendix B
label: BODY

text: Page 200
label: BODY

text: 3. The Purveyor will use the most recently published editions of the following publications as
label: BODY

text: references and technical aids:
label: BODY

text: a. Manual of Cross-Connection Control, published by the Foundation for Cross-
label: BODY

text: Connection Control and Hydraulic Research, University of Southern California, or latest
label: BODY

text: edition thereof.
label: BODY

text: b. Cross Connection Control Manual, Accepted Procedures and Practice, published by the
label: BODY

text: Pacific Northwest Section, American Water Works Association, or latest edition thereof.
label: BODY

text: c. Cross-Connection Control Guidance Manual for Small Water Systems, published by the
label: BODY

text: Washington State Department of Health, Office of Drinking Water.
label: BODY

text: 4. The Purveyor shall incorporate the written program plan into the Water System Plan or
label: BODY

text: Small Water System Management Program as applicable and shall submit the program to
label: BODY

text: DOH for approval when requested.
label: BODY

text: C.  Technical Provisions
label: HH3

text: 1. The Purveyor’s CCS shall perform hazard assessments of all water system and water-using
label: BODY

text: facilities owned by the Purveyor according to a reasonable schedule.
label: BODY

text: 2. The Purveyor shall eliminate all cross-connections that are discovered by the CCS.  Where it
label: BODY

text: is impossible or impractical to eliminate the cross-connections, they shall be protected
label: BODY

text: against by installation of a backflow preventer.  The type, location and schedule of
label: BODY

text: installation of the backflow preventer shall be as recommended by the Purveyor’s CCS.
label: BODY

text: 3. When a facility or building owned or served by the Purveyor is of a type included on Table
label: BODY

text: 9 of WAC 246-290-490(4), the building or facility plumbing system shall be isolated from
label: BODY

text: the rest of the water system by installation of a reduced pressure principle backflow
label: BODY

text: assembly (RPBA) or air gap (AG).  The premises isolation backflow preventer will be
label: BODY

text: installed at a location recommended by the CCS.
label: BODY

text: 4. Cross-connection hazards found within buildings owned by the Purveyor will be protected
label: BODY

text: against as according to the Uniform Plumbing Code (UPC) as amended for Washington.
label: BODY

text: For cross-connection hazards and/or specific plumbing fixtures that are not address in the
label: BODY

text: UPC, the Purveyor will provide protection in accordance with the fixture protection tables
label: BODY

text: found in the most recently published edition of the PNWS-AWWA Cross Connection
label: BODY

text: Control Manual.
label: BODY

text: 5. All backflow preventers owned by the Purveyor shall be inspected and/or tested in
label: BODY

text: accordance with WAC 246-290-490 (i.e. at the time of installation, after repair,
label: BODY

text: reinstallation or relocation and after a backflow incident).  After the initial test, the Purveyor
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Appendix B
label: BODY

text: Page 201
label: BODY

text: will ensure that Purveyor-owned backflow preventers are tested at least once annually.  The
label: BODY

text: Purveyor will ensure that a purveyor-approved, DOH-certified backflow assembly tester
label: BODY

text: (BAT) tests all assemblies.  The Purveyor will reinstall, repair or replace as soon as feasible
label: BODY

text: any backflow preventers that fail an inspection and/or a test.
label: BODY

text: 6. The Purveyor shall maintain records of hazard assessments, backflow preventers, and
label: BODY

text: backflow preventer tests and inspections.  The Purveyor shall make all data concerning the
label: BODY

text: CCC program available to DOH when requested.
label: BODY

text: 7. The Purveyor shall allocate resources as necessary to implement the provisions of this
label: BODY

text: resolution and the CCC program adopted.
label: BODY

text: D.  Other Provisions
label: HH3

text: If any provisions in this resolution, or in the written CCC program plan adopted by the Purveyor,
label: BODY

text: are found to be less stringent than or inconsistent with the Drinking Water Regulations (Chapter
label: BODY

text: 246-290 WAC), the Uniform Plumbing Code (Chapter 51-56 WAC), or any other Washington State
label: BODY

text: statutes or rules, the more stringent statute, rule, or regulations shall apply.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: March 2004
