text: Page 202
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Appendix C
label: BODY

text: Page 203
label: BODY

text: Appendix C
label: BODY

text: Backflow Incident Response Plan
label: BODY

text: for a Small Water System
label: BODY

text: General
label: BODY

text: This Backflow Incident Response Plan should be considered a supplement to the Purveyor’s
label: BODY

text: Emergency Plan.
label: BODY

text: Purveyors should immediately begin a backflow incident investigation whenever the initial
label: BODY

text: evaluation of a water quality complaint indicates that:
label: BODY

text: 1. A backflow incident has occurred (i.e., drinking water supply has been contaminated) or
label: BODY

text: may have occurred; or
label: BODY

text: 2. The complaint can’t be explained as a "normal" aesthetic problem.
label: BODY

text: Also, whenever a water main break (or power outage for pumped systems) causes a widespread loss
label: BODY

text: of water pressure in the system (creating backsiphonage conditions), purveyors should initiate a
label: BODY

text: check of distribution system water quality as a precursor to the need for a backflow incident
label: BODY

text: investigation.
label: BODY

text: WAC 246-290-490 requires purveyors to notify DOH, the Local Administrative Authority and local
label: BODY

text: health jurisdiction as soon as possible, but no later than the end of the next business day when a
label: BODY

text: backflow incident contaminates the potable water supply (in the distribution system and/or in the
label: BODY

text: customer's plumbing system).  Purveyors should include a list of emergency contact telephone
label: BODY

text: numbers at the beginning of the water system’s O & M Manual, so that the information is readily
label: BODY

text: available when an incident occurs.
label: BODY

text: A backflow incident investigation is often a team effort.  The investigation should be made by or
label: BODY

text: initially led by the DOH-certified Cross-Connection Control Specialist employed by the Purveyor.
label: BODY

text: The investigation team may include state health (regional) staff, local health personnel and/or local
label: BODY

text: plumbing inspectors.
label: BODY

text: Purveyors can get more detailed guidance on how to respond to a backflow incident from the
label: BODY

text: manual, Backflow Incident Investigation Procedures, published by the Pacific Northwest Section,
label: BODY

text: American Water Works Association (PNWS-AWWA).  Contact information for the PNWS-
label: BODY

text: AWWA is provided in Appendix F.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Appendix C
label: BODY

text: Page 204
label: BODY

text: Short List of Tasks
label: BODY

text: Small water system purveyors can use the following short list of tasks as initial guidance for dealing
label: BODY

text: with backflow incidents.  Purveyors should consult the most recently published edition of the
label: BODY

text: PNWS-AWWA Backflow Incident Investigation Procedures Manual referenced above for greater
label: BODY

text: detail as soon as possible after learning of a possible or confirmed backflow incident.  Note: the
label: BODY

text: water system is referred to as the Purveyor in the short task list.
label: BODY

text: 1. Customer Notification
label: H4

text: a. As soon as possible, the Purveyor will notify customers not to consume or use water.
label: BODY

text: b. The Purveyor will start the notification with the customers nearest in location to the
label: BODY

text: assumed source of contamination (usually the customer(s) making the water quality
label: BODY

text: complaint).
label: BODY

text: c. The Purveyor will inform the customer about the reason for the backflow incident
label: BODY

text: investigation and the Purveyor's efforts to restore water quality as soon as possible. The
label: BODY

text: Purveyor will let the customer know that customers will be informed when they may use
label: BODY

text: water, the need to boil water used for consumption until a satisfactory bacteriological
label: BODY

text: test result is obtained from the lab, etc.
label: BODY

text: d. Where a customer cannot be contacted immediately, the Purveyor will place a written
label: BODY

text: notice on the front door handle, and a follow-up visit will be made to confirm that the
label: BODY

text: customer received notice about the possible contamination of the water supply.
label: BODY

text: e. When dealing with a backflow incident, the Purveyor will let customers know that it
label: BODY

text: could take several days to identify the source and type of contaminant(s) and to clean
label: BODY

text: and disinfect the distribution system.
label: BODY

text: 2. Identification of Source of Contamination
label: H4

text: a. The Purveyor will give consideration to the distribution system as a potential source of
label: BODY

text: the contaminant (e.g., air valve inlet below ground).
label: BODY

text: b. The Purveyor will not start flushing the distribution system until the source of
label: BODY

text: contamination is identified (flushing may aggravate the backflow situation, and will
label: BODY

text: likely remove the contaminant before a water sample can be collected to fully identify
label: BODY

text: the contaminant).
label: BODY

text: c. The Purveyor will conduct a house-to-house survey to search for the source of
label: BODY

text: contamination and the extent that the contaminant has spread through the distribution
label: BODY

text: system.  Note: a check of water meters may show a return of water (meter running
label: BODY

text: backward) to the distribution system.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Appendix C
label: BODY

text: Page 205
label: BODY

text: d. When the cross connection responsible for the system contamination is located, the
label: BODY

text: Purveyor should discontinue water service to that customer, until the customer
label: BODY

text: completes the corrective action ordered by the Purveyor.
label: BODY

text: 3. Isolation of Contaminated Portion of System
label: H4

text: a. The Purveyor will isolate the portions of the system that are suspected of being
label: BODY

text: contaminated by closing isolating valves; leave one valve open to ensure that positive
label: BODY

text: water pressure is maintained throughout the isolated system.
label: BODY

text: b. The Purveyor will be sure to notify all affected customers in the isolated area first and
label: BODY

text: then notify other customers served by the system.
label: BODY

text: 4. Public Health Impacts
label: H4

text: a. The Purveyor will seek immediate input from and work with state and local health
label: BODY

text: agencies to accurately communicate and properly mitigate potential health effects
label: BODY

text: resulting from the backflow incident.
label: BODY

text: b. If appropriate, the Purveyor will refer customers that may have consumed the
label: BODY

text: contaminant or had their household (or commercial) plumbing systems contaminated to
label: BODY

text: public health personnel and Local Administrative Authorities (plumbing inspectors).
label: BODY

text: 5. Cleaning/Disinfecting the Distribution System
label: H4

text: a. The Purveyor will develop and implement a program for cleaning the contaminated
label: BODY

text: distribution system consistent with the contaminant(s) identified.
label: BODY

text: b. Where both chemical and bacteriological contamination has occurred, the Purveyor will
label: BODY

text: disinfect the system after the removal of the chemical contaminant.
label: BODY

text: c. Where any bacteriological contamination is suspected, the Purveyor will provide field
label: BODY

text: disinfection.
label: BODY

text: C.  Additional Information on Cleaning/Disinfecting the Distribution System
label: HH3

text: Most chemical or physical contaminants can be flushed from the water distribution system or
label: BODY

text: customer's plumbing system with adequate flushing velocity.  However, this may not be the case in
label: BODY

text: systems where scale and corrosion deposits (e.g., tuberculation on old cast iron mains) provide a
label: BODY

text: restriction to obtaining adequate flushing velocity, or where chemical deposits or bacteriological
label: BODY

text: slimes (biofilm) are present (on which the chemical contaminant may adhere).
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Appendix C
label: BODY

text: Page 206
label: BODY

text: To remove a chemical or physical contaminant from the distribution system, purveyors may need
label: BODY

text: to:
label: BODY

text: 1.  Physically clean the affected area using foam swabs (pigs); and/or
label: BODY

text: 2. Alter the form of the chemical contaminant (e.g., through oxidation using chlorination or
label: BODY

text: addition of detergents).
label: BODY

text: When adding any chemical (including chlorine) to remove a contaminant from the distribution
label: BODY

text: system, it is essential that the Purveyor fully understand the chemistry of the contaminant.  Adding
label: BODY

text: the wrong chemical could make the contaminant more toxic to customers and/or more
label: BODY

text: difficult to remove from the distribution system.
label: BODY

text: To disinfect water mains using the "slug" or "continuous flow" method, a field unit should be used
label: BODY

text: for chlorine injection, such as a chemical feed - metering or proportioning pump for sodium
label: BODY

text: hypochlorite.  Purveyors should contact the appropriate DOH regional office to discuss proposed
label: BODY

text: approaches to contaminant removal and disinfection prior to taking corrective action.
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Program Administration Documents
label: BODY

text: Appendix D contains sample forms, letters and standard installation drawings.  Purveyors may use any or
label: BODY

text: all of these documents as they administer their cross-connection control programs.  The content of these
label: BODY

text: forms and letters may be adjusted where appropriate to meet system-specific needs or program require-
label: BODY

text: ments.
label: BODY

text: Sample Forms
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: • Backflow Assembly Test/AG Inspection Report;
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: • Preliminary Hazard Assessment Form – Non-Residential Customers;
label: BODY

text: • Cross-Connection Control Survey Report – Non-Residential Customers;
label: BODY

text: • Water Use Questionnaire - Residential Customers; and
label: BODY

text: Backflow Incident Report Form.
label: BODY

text: Sample Letters
label: BODY

text: The second section of Appendix D contains sample letters from the Purveyor to the customer relating to the
label: BODY

text: administration of a cross-connection control program.  These letters include:
label: BODY

text: • Request to Complete Water Use Questionnaire;
label: BODY

text: • Notice of Survey of Premises;
label: BODY

text: • Request to Install Backflow Prevention Assembly;
label: BODY

text: • Request to Submit Test of Backflow Prevention Assembly; and
label: BODY

text: Second Notice to Test Backflow Prevention Assembly.
label: BODY

text: Sample Standard Installation Drawings
label: BODY

text: The last section of Appendix D contains the following sample installation drawings:
label: BODY

text: • Standard Details - Single Family Residential Service Connection Options; and
label: BODY

text: • Backflow Prevention Assemblies - Recommended Premises Isolation Installations.

text: Application for Water Service (Service Agreement)
label: BODY

text: 1. The undersigned applicant hereby applies for a water connection to the above-described property.
label: BODY

text: 2. The applicant is the owner of the described property or the authorized agent of the owner.
label: BODY

text: 3. As a condition of the {Insert PWS Name}, hereinafter referred to as the Purveyor, providing and continuing
label: BODY

text: service to the above described property, the property owner, by signing this application, agrees to comply with:
label: BODY

text: a. All provisions of the attached current Ordinance, Resolution and/or By-laws of the Purveyor, or latest revision
label: BODY

text: thereof; and
label: BODY

text: b. Other such current (attached) and future rules and regulations that govern the Purveyor's water system.
label: BODY

text: 4. The property owner specifically agrees:
label: BODY

text: a. To install and maintain at all times his plumbing system in compliance with the most current edition of the
label: BODY

text: {PWS to insert applicable code, i.e. city, county and/or state} Plumbing Code as it pertains to the
label: BODY

text: prevention of potable water system contamination and prevention of pressure surges and thermal expansion in
label: BODY

text: his water piping (for thermal expansion, it shall be assumed that a check valve is installed by the Purveyor on
label: BODY

text: the water service pipe);
label: BODY

text: b. Within 30 days of the Purveyor's request (or alternate schedule acceptable to the Purveyor):
label: BODY

text: To install, maintain, test and repair in accordance with the Purveyor’s cross-connection control standards
label: BODY

text: all premises isolation backflow prevention assemblies required by the Purveyor to be installed to protect
label: BODY

text: the public water system from contamination; and
label: BODY

text: ii) To report to the Purveyor the results of all assembly tests and/or repairs to the premises isolation backflow
label: BODY

text: prevention assemblies.
label: BODY

text: c. As a condition of the Purveyor waiving the requirement for premises isolation by a reduced pressure backflow
label: BODY

text: assembly on the property owner’s service pipe:
label: BODY

text: To authorize the Purveyor to make periodic water use surveys of the premises;
label: BODY

text: ii) Within 30 days of the Purveyor's request, to install, test, maintain, and repair in accordance with the
label: BODY

text: Purveyor's cross connection control standards (copy received with this application) all in-premises
label: BODY

text: backflow prevention assemblies that provide equivalent protection for the Purveyor's distribution system;
label: BODY

text: iii) To report to the Purveyor within 30 days of obtaining the results of all tests and repairs to the
label: BODY

text: aforementioned backflow prevention assemblies; and
label: BODY

text: Cross-Connection Control for Small Water Systems
label: BODY

text: March 2004
label: BODY

text: Appendix D
label: BODY

text: Page 209
label: BODY

text: iv) To report to the Purveyor any change to the plumbing system.
label: BODY

text: d. Not to make a claim against the Purveyor or its agents or employees for damages and/or loss of production,
label: BODY

text: sales or service, in case of water pressure variations, or the disruption of the water supply for water system
label: BODY

text: repair, routine maintenance, power outages, and other conditions normally expected in the operation of a water
label: BODY

text: system.
label: BODY

text: e. To pay his water bill within 30 days from the date of billing.
label: BODY

text: After 30 days of the Purveyor mailing a written notice to the property owner of his breach of this agreement, the
label: BODY

text: Purveyor may terminate water service.
label: BODY

text: In the event legal action is required and commenced between the parties to this agreement to enforce the terms and
label: BODY

text: conditions herein, the substantially prevailing party shall be entitled to reimbursement of all its costs and expenses
label: BODY

text: including but not limited to reasonable attorney's fees as determined by the Court.
label: BODY

text: The following table lists Backflow Assembly Testers (BATs) that are pre-approved to test backflow
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: requested to work in this area or who previously submitted properly completed test reports to our system.

text: {Optional language: An asterisk (*) denotes BATs that are also DOH-certified Cross-Connection Control
label: BODY

text: Specialists (CCSs).}  Note: listing does not constitute an endorsement of these BATs by our system or a
label: BODY

text: certification of the quality of services they provide.
label: BODY

text: To appear on our pre-approved BAT list, the tester must:
label: BODY

text: Show proof of current BAT certification from DOH;
label: BODY

text: Submit documentation that his/her assembly test equipment has been verified for accuracy within the last 12
label: BODY

text: months and calibrated if needed; and
label: BODY

text: {Optional language: Meet other criteria established by our system including____________________ {insert
label: BODY

text: additional requirements here such as business licenses, etc.}
label: BODY

text: As an alternative to the above, pre-approved testers must document that they appear on the approved BAT list of
label: BODY

text: another nearby water system that has a testing QA/QC program acceptable to our system.
label: BODY

text: WAC 246-290-490 requires a DOH-certified BAT to test all assemblies (RPBA, RPDA, DCVA, etc.) that protect the
label: BODY

text: distribution system.  Assemblies that protect the public water system must be tested in accordance with DOH-
label: BODY

text: approved field test procedures:
label: BODY

text: Upon installation, and annually thereafter;
label: BODY

text: After repair, reinstallation, or relocation; and
label: BODY

text: After a backflow incident.

label: BODY

text: categories, plumbing licenses, contractor registration, etc.  Other licenses, certifications and/or registrations may be
label: BODY

text: Dear ________ Water System Customer:
label: BODY

text: Washington State drinking water regulations, WAC 246-290-490, require public water systems to develop and
label: BODY

text: implement cross-connection control programs.  Cross-connection control programs help protect public health by
label: BODY

text: preventing contamination of the drinking water as it is delivered to water system customers.  The attached brochure
label: BODY

text: explains what a cross connection is, describes typical household cross connections and what you can do to help
label: BODY

text: protect your drinking water.
label: BODY

text: As part of our efforts to keep your drinking water safe, we are conducting a cross-connection control hazard survey
label: BODY

text: of residential customers served by our system.  The purpose of the survey is to help us determine if any of our
label: BODY

text: residential customers have special plumbing or activities on their premises that could increase the risk of
label: BODY

text: contamination to our water system.
label: BODY

text: For most residential customers, the cross-connection control hazard posed to the public water system is minimal.
label: BODY

text: This is because your household plumbing was installed in compliance with the Uniform Plumbing Code.  The
label: BODY

text: Uniform Plumbing Code generally provides adequate protection of your water potable water piping and our public
label: BODY

text: water distribution system from cross connections.  However, a few customers with special plumbing or activities on
label: BODY

text: their premises may pose an increased health risk to other customers served by our system.  These customers may
label: BODY

text: need to have a backflow preventer installed on their service lines or provide alternate protection to prevent
label: BODY

text: contamination of the public water system.
label: BODY

text: Please complete the attached questionnaire by checking the applicable boxes on the table; and
label: BODY

text: return the completed, signed questionnaire by {insert date} to the address shown on the letterhead {or insert
label: BODY

text: address if different}.
label: BODY

text: Thanks in advance for filling out the questionnaire.  We appreciate your cooperation in helping us to protect the
label: BODY

text: drinking water we deliver to our customers.   If you have any questions about the survey or how to fill out the
label: BODY

text: questionnaire, please contact me at {insert phone number}.  We will review your questionnaire and determine
label: BODY

text: whether we need to contact your for further information.
label: BODY

text: Sincerely,
label: BODY

text: Name
label: BODY

text: CCC Program Manager
label: BODY

text: Enclosures:
label: BODY

text: CCC Brochure
label: BODY

text: Dear ________ Water System Customer:
label: BODY

text: Washington State drinking water regulations, WAC 246-290-490, require public water systems to develop and
label: BODY

text: implement cross-connection control programs.  Cross-connection control programs protect public health by
label: BODY

text: preventing contamination of the drinking water supply.  The attached brochure explains what a cross connection is
label: BODY

text: and what you can do to help protect your drinking water.
label: BODY

text: As part of the cross-connection control program, our system must assess the degree of hazard posed by each of our
label: BODY

text: customer's plumbing systems upon the public water system.  Non-residential customers and multi-family residential
label: BODY

text: customers pose a special concern, because of the greater scope and complexity of their plumbing systems, special
label: BODY

text: uses of water on the premises (e.g., manufacturing), fire protection systems, etc.  Depending on the hazard
label: BODY

text: assessment results, you may need to have a backflow preventer installed on your service line or provide alternate
label: BODY

text: protection.
label: BODY

text: A cross-connection survey needs to be conducted for us to make the hazard assessment for your premises.
label: BODY

text: The drinking water regulations require a person with special training, i.e., a Department of Health certified Cross-
label: BODY

text: Connection Specialist (CCS), to conduct the surveys.  Our system’s policy is to have surveys of all non-residential
label: BODY

text: premises and multi-family residential premises conducted by a CCS employed by the customer.  Survey results must
label: BODY

text: be submitted to our system for review.
label: BODY

text: Please arrange for the attached survey form to be completed and returned to this office by {insert date}.  A
label: BODY

text: list of local CCSs who provide this type of service is attached.
label: BODY

text: We appreciate your cooperation in meeting this hazard survey requirement.  If you have any questions, please
label: BODY

text: contact me at {insert phone number}.
label: BODY

text: Sincerely,
label: BODY

text: Name
label: BODY

text: CCC Program Manager
label: BODY

text: Dear ________ Water System Customer:
label: BODY

text: Washington State drinking water regulations, WAC 246-290-490, require public water systems to develop and
label: BODY

text: implement cross-connection control programs.  Cross-connection control programs protect public health by
label: BODY

text: preventing contamination of the drinking water as it is delivered to people served by the water system.  The
label: BODY

text: purpose of this letter is to inform you of a requirement to install a backflow assembly.
label: BODY

text: Our water system’s policy considers each of our customer’s plumbing systems, starting from the termination of the
label: BODY

text: service pipe downstream of the water meter, to pose a potential cross-connection hazard to the public water system.
label: BODY

text: Our policy requires a backflow prevention assembly commensurate with the degree of hazard to be installed on the
label: BODY

text: service line.  The purpose of this backflow prevention assembly is to isolate your plumbing system from the water
label: BODY

text: distribution system.  We’ve attached a copy of Resolution {insert number} describing our cross-connection control
label: BODY

text: policy.
label: BODY

text: We have received the cross-connection control survey report submitted by your Cross-Connection Control
label: BODY

text: Specialist (CCS).  The survey assessed the overall public health hazard posed by your plumbing system (and water
label: BODY

text: use) to the public water system.  We agree with the assessment made by the CCS.  Based on the assessment, a
label: BODY

text: Department of Health-approved {insert type of assembly} is required to be installed on your service line (at a
label: BODY

text: location downstream of the water meter).
label: BODY

text: Please make arrangements for the assembly to be installed by {insert date} or when your plumbing system is
label: BODY

text: modified, whichever comes sooner.  {Optional language: We realize that this expense was not anticipated, so if you
label: BODY

text: are unable to comply with this deadline, please contact us to discuss an alternative date}.  We’ve enclosed a copy of
label: BODY

text: our standard installation drawings for this type of assembly.  Your CCS should oversee the installation of the
label: BODY

text: assembly to ensure compliance with these standards.
label: BODY

text: We appreciate your cooperation in this matter.  If you have any questions, please contact me at {insert phone
label: BODY

text: number}.
label: BODY

text: Sincerely,
label: BODY

text: Name
label: BODY

text: CCC Program Manager
label: BODY

text: cc: {City/County Plumbing Inspector}
label: BODY

text: Enclosures: Standard Installation Drawings

text: Dear ________ Water System Customer:
label: BODY

text: Washington State drinking water regulations, WAC 246-290-490, require public water systems to develop and
label: BODY

text: implement cross-connection control programs to protect the drinking water supply from contamination.  As part of
label: BODY

text: this program, backflow prevention assemblies have been installed on your water service(s) and/or within your
label: BODY

text: plumbing system to protect our water distribution system.  Annual testing is required to ensure that the backflow
label: BODY

text: prevention assemblies properly function.
label: BODY

text: The purpose of this letter is to request that you now arrange for the annual testing of the reduced pressure principle
label: BODY

text: (RPBA), double check valve (DCVA), and/or pressure vacuum breaker (PVBA or SVBA) assembly/assemblies
label: BODY

text: described on the attached list.  A Washington State Department of Health certified backflow assembly tester (BAT)
label: BODY

text: must conduct the testing.  Testing results should be sent to the address above and submitted by {insert date}.
label: BODY

text: For your convenience, we are enclosing a list of backflow assembly testers pre-approved to test assemblies that
label: BODY

text: protect our water system.  Test report forms are also enclosed.  The test report forms need to be properly completed
label: BODY

text: by the BAT, signed by the customer/assembly owner, and returned to us.
label: BODY

text: Note: the Uniform Plumbing Code in effect in Washington also requires annual assembly testing.  In addition to the
label: BODY

text: testing required for the assemblies that protect the public water system (i.e., identified on the attached list), you may
label: BODY

text: wish to have all of the remaining assemblies within your premises tested at this time.
label: BODY

text: If you have any questions, please feel free to contact me at {insert phone number}.
label: BODY

text: Sincerely,
label: BODY

text: Name
label: BODY

text: CCC Program Manager

text: Dear ________ Water System Customer:
label: BODY

text: Washington State drinking water regulations, WAC 246-290-490, require public water systems to implement cross-
label: BODY

text: connection control programs to protect the drinking water supply from contamination.  As part of this program,
label: BODY

text: backflow prevention assemblies were installed on your service or within your premises to protect our water
label: BODY

text: distribution system from contamination.  The WAC requires these assemblies to be tested annually to verify that
label: BODY

text: they are in good working condition.
label: BODY

text: The assembly/assemblies identified in our letter of {insert date} (copy attached) must be tested by a Department of
label: BODY

text: Health certified Backflow Assembly Tester (BAT) upon installation and annually thereafter.  This requirement is a
label: BODY

text: condition of our system continuing to supply potable water to your premises.  According to our records, as of
label: BODY

text: today’s date, you have not submitted the requested Assembly Test Report(s).  If you believe this is in error,
label: BODY

text: please contact me as soon as possible at the number below.
label: BODY

text: If you have not submitted the Assembly Test Reports as requested, please:
label: BODY

text: Immediately employ a DOH-certified BAT to test the listed assembly/assemblies; and
label: BODY

text: Submit a signed copy of the completed Assembly Test Report(s) to me at the address above within 15 days
label: BODY

text: of the date of this letter.
label: BODY

text: Your cooperation in this matter is essential for protecting your drinking water supply and the public water supply
label: BODY

text: from contamination.  Failure to comply with the annual assembly testing requirement will trigger an enforcement
label: BODY

text: action by our system.  Enforcement could include a shut-off of your water service.
label: BODY

text: If you have any questions, please contact me at {insert phone number}.

text: Sincerely,

text: Appendix E contains sample cross-connection control (CCC) Annual Summary Report forms.
label: BODY

text: Per WAC 246-290-490, purveyors are required to complete these forms to report information on
label: BODY

text: the status of a public water system’s CCC program and implementation activities.  When the
label: BODY

text: Department of Health sends out hard copies or electronic copies of the forms, they are color-
label: BODY

text: coded.  Purveyors often refer to the forms by color instead of name.  The respective color of each
label: BODY

text: form is noted below.
label: BODY

text: The three forms are:
label: BODY

text: 1. Cross-Connection Control Activities Annual Summary Report
label: BODY

text: Purveyors use this form to report (for a calendar year) their CCC implementation
label: BODY

text: activities, such as status of high-hazard premises protection, backflow preventer
label: BODY

text: inventory/testing information, and hazard evaluations.  This is the “blue form.”
label: BODY

text: 2. Cross-Connection Control Program Summary Report
label: BODY

text: This form is use to report the type, policies, and provisions of a public water system’s
label: BODY

text: CCC written program.  This is the “cream form.”
label: BODY

text: 3. Exceptions to High Health Hazard Premises Isolation Requirements
label: BODY

text: Purveyors use this form to document and report exceptions to mandatory premises
label: BODY

text: isolation requirements allowed under WAC 246-290-490(4)(b)(iii).  Only purveyors
label: BODY

text: granting exceptions need to complete and submit this form.  This is the “green form.”
label: BODY

text: The forms provided are those used for the reporting year indicated on the forms.  For copies of
label: BODY

text: forms for later years, or for versions suitable for completion on screen using MS Word, contact
label: BODY

text: the DOH Office of Drinking Water (see Appendix F)
